“But can you be sure she’s not the killer?” Angie asks, expression suddenly dark. 

Tenko looks taken aback. “What?”

“Hey, Tenko,” Angie says. “God thinks it’s super nice that you believe in Kaede, but what if she really did kill Himiko or Gonta, you know? If you keep believing in her then, won’t we all die here?”

Without hesitation, Tenko says, “Tenko would rather die than stop believing in her friends. Tenko knows… Tenko knows that someone here murdered Himiko… and that she is never coming back, but hating and mistrusting everyone isn’t the answer. Even if horrible things happen, Tenko will still believe in her friends, and she will do everything that she can to protect them.”

Kaede finds herself near speechless, and every lie she’s told thus far twists in her stomach. She breathes out, “Tenko…”

Tenko says, “Kaede is someone who learns from her mistakes and wants to move forward—killing someone and sacrificing everyone is completely out of the question for her.”

Kokichi regards her impassioned words coolly, and Kaede feels a brief rush of fear when he opens his mouth. But he says, “Kaede’s not the culprit. If you think either of us would lie for each other, you’re pretty stupid, Maki.”

Maki turns a gaze of pure death on him. “Do you want to be killed?”

Kokichi shrugs blandly. “If you want to be executed.”

Maki seems on the verge of physically leaving her podium to attack him, when Kaito cuts in, “Alright, alright—everyone calm the hell down.” He runs a hand through his hair, mumbling, “Why the fuck do I have to be the levelheaded one?”

Kiibo decides to refocus the conversation. “Ah, Kaede, if you not mind me asking this now, earlier you seemed to realize something about Himiko’s death, correct?”

“I… did,” Kaede answers warily, fiddling with the brim of Shuichi’s hat as she debates what she can actually tell them. “Ah, it’s… a bit complicated to explain.”

Miu snorts. “We’re at a fucking trial for a reason—spit it out, blimp tits.”

Kaede glares at her. “I was just thinking about why she was killed. I think it’s safe to say that almost everyone knew that someone else had been killed, even if they didn’t know who, during the blackout.”

“That’s right,” Tsumugi says. “I remember hearing part of the body announcement playing right before the lights went out.”

“So the question is,” Kaede says. “Why would someone—the culprit or anyone else—kill a second person?”

Maki seems to take a pause in her accusations to consider the question, saying, “It is true that a second killing creates more evidence that can be used to track down the culprit. Doing so is inadvisable unless absolutely necessary.”

“So the killer thought it was necessary to bump her off?” Miu asks. “What was she a witness or something?”

Kaede considers this for a moment. “I think… that Himiko was involved somehow in Gonta’s death, but she was killed… probably for unrelated reasons.”

Angie blinks. “Huh? Himiko was involved in Gonta’s death?”

“I’d like to hear more about that as well,” Ryoma says darkly.

Kokichi chirps, “Then let’s all talk about it! C’mon! Some of you are dead weight, so put some effort into it! Quick one of you figure out the proof that Himiko was involved with Gonta’s death before Kaede!”

Kaede just rolls her eyes as the others begin to talk.

(Present your Argument) 

“How the fuck,” Miu says, “Am I supposed to know shit about that!? I was under the floor the whole goddamn time!”

“I investigated under the floor before I became distracted by Miu,” Kiibo says. “I believe the major thing of note other than Miu’s presence there, was the large amount of blood.”

“We said some shit about Gonta bein’ killed under the floor, right?” Kaito says. “Maybe Himiko was killed down there, too?”

Ryoma shakes his head. “Impossible. I was there for almost the entire blackout—never saw her.”

Angie gasps. “Did the killer go after Himiko during the blackout because she saw something at the crime scene?”

“Then they would’ve killed her that night,” Maki asks. “Her time of death was during the blackout. If you even bothered to read the Monokuma File, you should know that.”

“Himiko’s death sounds so horrible,” Tsumugi says, hugging herself. “Being strangled… what a horrible way to die…”

Quietly, Tenko says, “her killer likely did it because it would not leave bloodstains. If they had run into someone during the blackout while covered in blood… then there would be no doubt what they had done…”

Kokichi sighs. “You’re all useless. Just tell ‘em, Kaede.”

“I was under the floor,” Miu mumbles. “What do you fucking want from me?”

(BREAK) 

“The bloodstain,” Kaede says. “That’s the clue that Himiko was at the scene of the crime and probably that she touched Gonta’s body at some point.”

“What?” Ryoma breathes out. 

“The Monokuma File said that she had no injuries other than those to her neck, which wouldn’t have caused her to bleed,” Kaede says. “But when we were investigating her body, we noticed a spot of blood behind one of her ears.”

Kokichi pouts. “I noticed it.”

“My point,” Kaede says, “is that if that blood doesn’t belong to Himiko…”

“It was Gonta’s…” Tenko says quietly.

“Okay,” says Kaito. “But how does blood get behind someone’s fucking ear?”

“I think she got drenched in it,” Kaede says. “During the investigation, Kokichi and I went to Himiko’s room. There… wasn’t much there,” she says, “but in her closet, we found a change of her clothes that were soaked with blood.”

Kiibo nods. “I think I understand. If almost her entire body was covered with blood, she likely washed it off and missed a spot.”

“Oh,” Tsumugi says. “Maybe that’s why parents always tell their children to wash behind their ears…”

Kaito rubs the back of his head. “Tenko’s gonna get fucking pissed at me for saying this, but Himiko was covered in Gonta’s blood at some point and the murder happened in a room she was hanging out in last night? Are we sure she’s not the killer?”

“I already confirmed she wasn’t with Monokuma,” Kokichi says, puffing his cheeks out. “Geeze, Kaito, you never listen to me.”

“God says Monokuma might have lied to protect her,” Angie says. “Sometimes he does things like that even though God doesn’t appreciate it.”

“Why would he protect a culprit who’s dead?” Maki says. “Monokuma just wants his game to be interesting—I doubt executing a corpse would fit that description.”

Kokichi looks near ready to throw a fit, stamping his tiny foot chanting, “No, no, no! Come on! Think about Kaede and Tenko’s story from earlier.”

Kaito frowns. “When they found the body? The fuck does that have to do with Himiko?”

Kiibo says, “Himiko wasn’t there, correct? So according to Kaede’s testimony, the people who discovered Gonta’s body were Tenko, Kokichi, and Kaede, herself.”

“Miu was also apparently there,” Tenko volunteers. “Though we did not know that at the time.”

“Yeah,” says Miu. “And I didn’t see shit ‘til I woke up.”

Kaede pinches the bridge of her nose. “Miu, I don’t think you’re the killer, but I still can’t believe you just took a nap.”

“I already told you, it’s nice and dark and shit down there!” Miu says. “And I wouldn’t have fucking done it if I knew there was a corpse just lying around.”

“Right, so,” says Kokichi. “Miu doesn’t know anything like usual, so she didn’t find the body, but who did?”

“Tenko did,” Kaede says. “After she discovered it, the body announcement went off.”

Maki’s head snaps to her. “Wait. You weren’t all together when you found the body?”

“No,” Kaede says. “Kokichi and I were in a different room. I think we already went over that Tenko was alone with it for a few seconds.”

“And Tenko did nothing to disturb the crime scene,” she answers. 

Maki mutters to herself, “So that’s what Kokichi’s getting out. Monokuma,” she turns to address the bear. “I have a question.”

“Hmm?” he asks. “What is it now? More technicalities that I’ve already explained that need clearing up?”

“Just answer me,” she says. “The rule for the body announcement is that three or more people need to discover a corpse, correct? Does the killer count as one of those people?”

“Sometimes they do,” Monokuma says. “And sometimes they don’t! I make the call to keep things as fair as a bear can make them!”

Maki glares at him, but says, “Fine. But either way, two people discovered Gonta’s body before Tenko. And I think we’ve confirmed one of them has to be Himiko.”

“Himiko…” Tenko breathes out. “She—why didn’t she say anything? She was acting strange this morning, was it because…” Tenko presses her hands to her face. “Why didn’t she say anything…”

“Ah, so,” Tsumugi says hesitantly. “Does that mean that the people Monokuma’s counting for the body discovery are Tenko, Himiko, and one other person who might be the killer?”

Kaito runs a hand over his face. “If they’re the killer, I get it if they kept quiet, but if they’re not, does that mean two fucking people found a corpse and said nothing?”

Miu slams both her hands on her podium. “I told you! I fucking told you!” she jabs a finger in Kokichi’s direction. “One in the fucking morning, and he’s prancing around the fourth floor like the goddamn sugar plum fairy!”

Kokichi doesn’t respond, and Kaede looks at him searchingly as she says, “Kokichi was already on the fourth floor when Tenko and I arrived. It was like he was waiting for us…”

Ryoma stares at him with dead eyes. “Miu said the door to the room he trapped her in was already open, which means he was able to pick the locks she sent up.”

“And that would explain the locked room, too,” Tsumugi mumbles.

“Ooh!” says Angie. “And the threatening note! Gonta probably didn’t trust Kokichi anymore after the bug appreciation party incident!”

“Also,” Kaito says. “This is just me guessing—but doesn’t stabbing the statues with swords sound like the kind of shit Kokichi would do just to mess with us?”

Maki says, “The reason why he handcuffed himself to Kaede before the blackout finally makes sense. He did it so he’d be one of the only people with an alibi for Himiko’s death.” 

Kiibo frowns. “That would mean Kokichi would have had to have known the blackout would occur and that Himiko would be killed during it.”

“Maybe he set that up, too,” Ryoma says. “If Himiko was a witness, maybe her death was some pre-setup trap or something he could activate without having to actually be there.”

Angie hums. “Kokichi does like playing pranks—God says it would make sense for him to know how to set something like that up…”

Miu stands looking more triumphant than ever, and slams her hands on her podium in time with her words. “I. Fucking. Told. You.”

Kokichi remains silent, even as his podium moves to the center of the room for everyone to level their accusations at him. In the eye of the storm, he seems completely calm. 

Kaede stares hard at the back of his head, wandering what could possibly be going through his mind as the other continue to condemn him into whatever grave he’s made for himself. The anger and bitterness she had felt towards him only moments before the trial had begun fades away as she keeps watching him, his every action during the investigation running through her mind. 

Were the words he said and the things he did actions of a killer? Looking back, his hand had guided almost every part of the investigation, but. She bites her lip. She had done the same thing only two days after the game’s beginning. 

While Kaede struggles, Kokichi seems almost bored and interrupts Miu’s tirade against him to say, “So—this is a rather convenient conclusion to come to, isn’t it? I doubt this means anything to any of you, but I have to wonder what happens to the game if I die here. I’ve certainly made enough enemies with enough people—one person in particular—that there’s a chance things could fall apart for the sake of revenge.” He hums. “I’d say this is that person’s trap, but,” he grins, folding his hands behind his head. “I brought most of this on myself.”

“You brought it on your dumbass because you’re the killer,” Miu snarls.

Kaito rubs the back of his head. “What you’re saying—is this your confession or something?”

Kokichi shakes his head. “No. More like,” he pauses in thought briefly. “More like a warning.”

Quietly, Kaede can’t help but ask, “Warning against what?”

He turns to her, a knowing smile on his face. “Figured you’d be the one to ask. Just a warning that if I die here and the rules break again, this killing game will end exactly how it was intended to.” He winks at her. “That’s all. You’re pretty smart, Kaede. I’m sure you’ll figure it out.”

Kaede stares at him in near shock while her mind races around his words, searching for the answers hidden and twisted somewhere, anywhere in his sunny expression. 

Maki says, “Stop talking. Your empty threats don’t mean anything. They just show how desperate you are.”

“Maki,” he says. “You should really stop talking like you know anything.”

Maki scowls, her red eyes fixed on him as she says, “Monokuma, I think we’re ready to vote.”

“No!” Kaede shouts almost involuntarily. The others turn to her, and she finds herself sweating under their stares. She falters, looking over them, and trips on her words, stuttering, “E-Everyone, please. There’s still so much about this case that we haven’t figured out. Voting for Kokichi—voting for anyone now—would be a huge mistake.”

Miu groans. “Again with this shit? Bakamatsu, come on.”

Kaede blinks at her. “Huh?”

Maki sighs. “Well, I think that should clear up any of our doubts. Gonta’s murder is open and shut then—Kokichi’s the killer, and Kaede is protecting him for some godforsaken reason. Again.”

“What? Didn’t you hear what I just said?” Kaede grips the edges of her podium, desperation surging over her. “Why won’t any of you listen to me? I know there’s evidence against him, but,” she searches for anything, “but there’s too much we haven’t cleared up yet. And Kokichi helped me investigate the entire time, even,” she waves vaguely, “even pointing out stuff I missed. It makes no sense for him to be the killer.”

No one responds to her, and in the following silence she says, “Why won’t you believe me?”

“Look, Kaede,” Kaito says with a sigh. “I know you how you feel about condemning the killer, but c’mon. It fucking has to be him. Maybe he helped us out with the investigation and shit, but that doesn’t just cancel out the mountain of evidence against him, and,” he sends a glance towards Ryoma, “I think it’d be better if we didn’t drag this trial out, you know?”

The attention directed towards him isn’t lost on Ryoma, and he just pulls his hat down. “If we have our answer,” he says in a low voice. “Then we should just end this already…”

“So,” says Miu. “Does that mean we’re starting the fucking vote or what?”

“No!” shouts Kaede. “If you all vote for Kokichi, we’re going to die!”

“You know, I have to agree with Kaede,” Kokichi says conversationally, finally coming to his own defense. “But, the idea that I’m the culprit sure is a comforting lie. I can see why you all like it so much.”

“Shut up,” says Ryoma. “Just shut up.” 

In the uneasy silence following his words, Angie says, “Sooo, does that mean we should vote now?”

“Yeah,” says Ryoma. “I’m done listening to him.”

“Wait!” shouts Kaede. “Ryoma, I know how you feel, but—”

“Bullshit,” says Ryoma, his voice crueler than Kaede has ever heard it before. 

Kaede blinks. “Huh?”

“You think you get it because Shuichi died?” he says. “Is that it? You knew him for two days. You knew him, and you knew you had other people around you. You still have your family, your friends on the outside,” he gestures to Kaito, standing two podiums away, “hell, you have friends in here. So no, you don’t understand how I feel, and watching you defend Gonta’s killer makes me sick.”

Kaede finds herself speechless other than breathing out, “Ryoma…”

Kaito says, “Hey, Ryoma, don’t you think that was kind of harsh?”

Ryoma ignores him. “Monokuma, I’m ready to vote.”

“Oh,” says Kokichi. “My, what a tragic turn of events. It looks like Gonta’s sacrifice will all be for nothing then.” 

“I thought I told you to shut up,” Ryoma says.

“Ryoma, please,” says Kiibo. “Even though you are still grieving, Kaito was right. Please do not speak so harshly to your fellow classmates. Kaede,” he turns to her. “I am aware that you do not think Kokichi is the culprit, and though I would like to discover the truth behind the other mysteries in this case myself, I believe that if only the two of you are against voting now, we cannot have a debate.”

Kaede works her mouth uselessly to find the right words before saying, “No… no one else thinks we should keep talking? I know things look bad for Kokichi, but like Kiibo said, there are still mysteries we haven’t solved yet. There has to be more to this case.”

Silence follows, and Kaede pleads, “I’ll debate with you or hear your arguments, and if Kokichi is the culprit then, I’ll vote for him, but right now, I’m begging you all not to do this.”

More silence as her classmates idly trade skeptical looks, and Kaede hears her heart roaring in her ears, until one voice rings out.

“Tenko… Tenko didn’t investigate Gonta’s body… and she doesn’t have proof that Kokichi’s innocent, but,” she takes a deep breath, steadying herself. “Tenko also does not think he did it. Even though Kokichi is one of the worst boys Tenko has ever met, she knows he would never kill someone. So Tenko will argue on Kaede’s side.”

Kaede says, “Tenko…”

Kokichi says, “Yay! Tenko also doesn’t want to die!”

Tenko glares at him as Kaede clears her throat, turning to address Monokuma. “So,” she says. “I know it’s uneven, but is three versus seven good enough for a debate?”

Kiibo nods. “I would also all like to continue our discussion. I will argue on Kaede’s side.”

Kaede shoots him a relived smile. “Thanks, Kiibo.”

Kokichi says, “Aw, Kiiboy’s one of the people who likes me? Boo…”

Monokuma tilts his furry head. “Hmm, so four against six? A bit lopsided certainly, but my mother did always tell me to turn a blind eye to one’s imperfections, soooo,” he holds the key high over his head, “here we gooooo!”

Kaede grips the edges of her podium to steady herself as they all begin to lift into the air. She looks across the way at Ryoma who stares at her, nearly boiling over with his own frustration and hatred over the situation. The others lined up on his side all bear their own expressions of various degrees of aggravation and annoyance. 

She takes a deep breath and meets Ryoma’s hardened gaze with her own fierce determination. Standing strong, however, is not her biggest concern, as Kaede numbly thinks just how little proof she has to prove her point. Kokichi’s standing next to her, as unconcerned as ever and simply smiles back when he catches her staring at him out of the corner of her eye.

Ryoma starts talking, his first words dulled into nothing over the roaring in her ears as she decides the only way out of this and towards the truth of the case is to lie her heart out.

Chapter End Notes

Actually back to posting on a Saturday! I've been casually rewatching DR1 and 2 to get a feel for trials in general, so if you see anything that seems like a reference to the first two games, it probably is, haha.

Trial V

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

If she lies, Kaede realizes, Tenko will follow along, Kokichi will be too amused to protest, and Kiibo will be confused. Her eyes dart to Kokichi standing next to her, smiling as if he wasn’t staring his execution dead in the face. She looks back to Ryoma and straightens her hat forward. 



(BEGIN) 

Ryoma starts, “Every piece of evidence in this case points to Kokichi. We have no reason to suspect anyone else.”

Kiibo is the first to respond to him, “Though there may be some evidence, we have not discussed everything enough to declare Kokichi is the only person capable of being the killer.”

Miu shouts, “He basically fucking admitted he found the body! Only the killer would keep quiet about shit like that!”

“Kokichi likely had other reasons for not telling us,” Tenko answers. “And he did not attempt to stop us from discovering it this morning.”

“He already confessed to being on the fourth floor that night,” Kaito says. “And it’s really fucking suspicious that he’d trap Miu up there.”

Kokichi smiles. “There’s nothing that proves my playing a trick on Miu’s related to the murder at all, especially since she doesn’t know anything about the case.”

“But,” Tsumugi mumbles, “how else are we supposed to explain the locked room? Kokichi is the only person who could have gotten in…”

Kaede sees her opportunity. “This morning, Himiko told us she lost her keys—the killer probably found them.”

Angie hums. “But the crime scene was really weird. God says only someone like Kokichi would do that.”

“That is not evidence,” Kiibo says. “Though Kokichi likes pranks, we cannot assume he did that without real proof.”

“It’s highly suspicious that Kokichi set himself up to be one of the only people with an alibi during the blackout,” Maki says. 

Kaede quickly counters, “Suspicious or not, an alibi is an alibi, and,” she chances a look towards him, “Kokichi was just as surprised about the blackout as anyone.”

Ryoma just glares. “We already have enough information to conclude this case. Stop pretending otherwise.”

Tenko glares back. “Himiko’s death is just as important as Gonta’s. If we vote now, we will never find justice for her, and Tenko will never allow that!”



(BREAK) 

They descend, and Ryoma doesn’t say a word, simply glaring at some aimless spot in front of him. 

Tenko repeats, “Until we discover why Himiko had to die, Tenko refuses to vote for anyone.” She turns to address everyone. “Deciding to vote now because it’s convenient is an insult to both Himiko and Gonta. If we were truly their friends, then we wouldn’t stop fighting until we find the absolute truth about what happened to them.”

“Fuck…” Kaito sighs. “Fine, I get it. I have no fucking clue who else it could be, but… guess there’s always a chance it’s not Kokichi.”

Kokichi just hums. “Hmm, I agree. Tenko makes a nice point, but I have a feeling she’s going to be disappointed.”

Kaede blinks. “What does that mean?”

“It means he’s still suspicious as fuck,” Miu answers, eyes narrowed. “Listen here, ass clown, just ‘cause we’re not executing you yet doesn’t mean you’re innocent.”

“Man,” Kokichi sighs. “Some people just get so hung up on the lies they like best. It’s kind of sad…”

“Stop talking,” Maki snaps. “And stop trying to weasel out of this, especially since there’s still holes in your argument, or more specifically,” she turns her glare on Kaede, “Kaede’s.”

Kaede bites back the fear that immediately seizes her. “What are you talking about?”

“You said Himiko didn’t have the keys to get into the three rooms this morning,” Maki says. “So how did you and Tenko get in?”

Kaede pales, but manages to stammer out, “I-I already said that Kokichi was there with us. He unlocked the doors.”

“That’s right!” Kokichi says brightly, folding his arms behind his head. “Himiko already told me she lost her keys, so I was waiting up there to let Kaede and Tenko in.”

Ryoma finally speaks up. “Himiko told you to let them in? You?”

Kokichi pouts. “Is it really that hard to believe? It’s the truth…”

Kaito rubs the back of his head. “Now that you’ve said that, I’m having trouble believing it.”

Kokichi starts sniffling. “Kaito has no faith in me… and I thought he believed in everyone even though that’s really stupid…”

“God, do I still hope you’re the killer,” Kaito says.

Kiibo says, “If we may, now that we’ve decided to put off the vote, there are a few things I would like to discuss further, such as what Himiko’s involvement in the case was, particularly if Kokichi was telling the truth just now.”

“Tenko would like to know that as well,” she says.

Tsumugi says, “Well, um, are we still assuming Kokichi discovered the body last night? Before Miu went to the fourth floor?”

“Whether we are,” Maki says with a pointed look to Kaede, “doesn’t seem to be up to us but we should.”

“Which means,” Kaito quickly cuts in. “Tenko, Himiko, and Kokichi were the first three people, not counting the killer.”

Kiibo nods. “Tenko found Gonta this morning, Kokichi likely sometime before the… incident with Miu, which would be between midnight and one in the morning.”

“Hmm, Angie remembers that Kokichi likes to lurk around the fourth floor at night,” Angie says. “Sooooo God thinks he probably found it sometime then.”

Kaito groans. “You were actually being serious when you said you liked creeping around in the dark at night…”

“Of course!” Kokichi says. “Would I lie to you, Kaito?”

Kaito pinches the bridge of his nose, while Kaede says, “Which means the only one we don’t know the time for is Himiko, other than it had to be before this morning when Tenko and I went to the fourth floor.”

“When we saw Himiko this morning,” Tenko steps into clarify, “she was coming downstairs from the fourth floor. She said we should go upstairs to help prepare for her magic show, and that she… needed to do something.”

“Oh,” Tsumugi says. “She didn’t happen to mention what it was, did she?”

“No,” Kaede says. “And unless anyone here can say otherwise, I don’t think anyone saw her after that either.”

Angie hums. “Angie saw reeeeally Himiko early this morning in the cafeteria. Angie was just making tea and Himiko came to get some since she said she was really tired.”

“I do remember you mentioning seeing her,” Kaede says. “Did she say or do anything else?”

“Nope!” Angie says. “All Himiko said was that she just woke up and was going to prepare for her magic show super early. She was really nervous, so she gave Angie a big hug before leaving and said goodbye! Sooo God thinks that Himiko probably discovered Gonta after that.”

“Huh? The fuck do you think that for?” Miu asks.

“Because Himiko didn’t mention anything to Angie,” Angie says. 

“And if she discovered the body, she probably would’ve said something, huh?” Kaito says, frowning. “But she didn’t say anything to Kaede or Tenko, either right?”

Kokichi says, “I think this is a nice first step in figuring out what role Himiko played in this case. So, Kaede—you seem to be doing most of the heavy lifting anyway—care to point out what the answer is?”

Kaede frowns at him, but the other continue to talk in the background even as Kokichi smiles at whatever game he’s playing with her.

(Present your Argument) 

“This morning, Angie saw Himiko really early!” Angie says. “She said she was going up to the fourth floor, so she probably discovered Gonta’s body right after that!”

“What time was that approximately?” Kiibo asks.

“Hmm… God says it was about half past six,” Angie says. 

“Morning announcements are at seven-thirty,” Tenko says. “Tenko and Kaede saw Himiko immediately after the one for today played.”

“God says everyone else should have been getting up at that time, too,” Angie says. “Since that’s when curfew ends for non-student council members.”

“So our timeline is,” Kiibo says, “Himiko discovered the body this morning after speaking with Angie but before running into Kaede and Tenko, and no one else saw her before the blackout.”

Angie claps her hands over her head. “God says that as long as Himiko didn’t go back to the dorms, then she wouldn’t have had to worry about running into anyone!”

“She also likely saw Kokichi this morning,” Tenko says. “Though Tenko is doubtful that helps us pin down a timeframe.”

Kaito sighs. “It always fucking comes back to Kokichi…”

Kokichi grins, folding his hands behind his head. “I’m pretty important.”

(BREAK) 

“Wait, Angie,” Kaede says. “Himiko definitely returned to her room after discovering the body. It’s the only thing that makes sense.”

“Huh?” Angie asks. “But if Himiko tried to go to her room this morning, then God says that everyone totally would have seen her.” She hums, “Kaede, are you saying everyone is lying about seeing her?”

“N-No,” Kaede says, mildly taken aback. “I’m saying that I have evidence that shows Himiko went back to her room sometime between discovering the blackout and this morning.”

“She mentioned it earlier,” Maki says. “Kaede said she and Kokichi went to Himiko’s room during the investigation and found bloody clothes, which are the entire reason we’re even assuming Himiko was involved in the first place.”

Kiibo nods. “I see. Whatever interaction Himiko had with the crime scene resulted in her being covered in blood, and unless anyone witnessed her returning to her room in such a state, we can assume she did not do it this morning.”

Kaito, “Says I was in the dorms all fucking morning. Never saw her or anyone else covered in blood.”

Maki crosses her arms. “Of course you never saw anyone. You were in your room sleeping.”

“Well, I still didn’t see or hear anyone after everyone left when the morning announcement went off,” Kaito says. “And I think someone running around covered in blood would probably attract some yelling.”

“And all of that,” Kaede says. “Means we can safely assume Himiko found the body before this morning.”

“Does that mean she just… decided not to tell anyone?” Tsumugi asks. “Why would she keep something like that secret?”

“Wrong,” Maki says. “Kokichi already said Himiko told him.”

“Wrong!” Kokichi cheers. “I said Himiko told me to let Kaede and Tenko into the death room.”

Ryoma finally speaks up again. “So the two of you were working together,” he says in a frighteningly quiet voice. “Is that it?”

“Huh?” Angie tilts her head to the side. “Who was working together?”

Maki says, “If we’re to believe even half the things Kokichi has said—which admittedly is a risk—then we can assume that there is definitely a connection between Himiko’s involvement in Gonta’s death and his.”

“I am unsure what that connection would be,” Kiibo says. “However, I do find it difficult to believe that both of them would discover a body and choose to say nothing without any communication between them.”

“So the loli and the shota were working together,” Miu says. “How ‘bout this then—one of ‘em was the killer and the other was their accomplice. And then!” she jabs a finger at Kokichi, “during the blackout the fucking ass gremlin bumped Himiko off to keep her quiet!”

Kokichi yawns. “Geeze, Miu, how slow can you be? We already decided it’s not me.”

“We didn’t,” Maki snaps. “We just decided to figure out exactly how guilty you are before executing you.”

He shrugs. “Fine, fine.” He yawns again, rubbing at his eyes. “Man, I’m getting so bored. We’ve talked for so long, and we’re still going in circles. Maybe I should give you guys a hint or something to speed things along…”

Kaede looks at him skeptically. “What kind of hint?”

“The fact that he’s even giving hints is fucking suspicious!” Miu shouts.

“Shut up,” Kaito says. “Kokichi withholding information ‘cause he thinks it’s funny or some shit is nothing new.” He looks to him. “Just tell us already.”

Kokichi tilts his head. “Will you say please?”

Kaede rolls her eyes. “Kokichi, will you please—”

He puffs out his cheeks. “I wasn’t asking you,” and his eyes practically sparkle when he turns to Kaito. 

Kaito says, “Oh, fuck no. Kaede, we can do this without him, so—”

“It’s a really good hint!” Kokichi says. “Don’t you want to be everyone’s hero, Kaito?”

Miu cackles, “Looks like we know what shota gets off on now.”

Kokichi scowls, and Kaito’s eyes dart between the two of them before he says, “How about I hit Miu later instead?”

“Deal!” Kokichi says. 

“What!?” Miu squawks.

“Miu!” Kokichi says. “Shut up! I need to tell everyone that I talked to Himiko before I saw you last night!”

Kaede blinks. “Did you just… give us the time frame for the incident? Just like that?”

“For the discoveries anyway,” Maki says. “It would seem he did.”

Kokichi smiles brightly. “I like to be helpful.”

“Now that’s a fucking lie,” Kaito grumbles.

“Miu,” Kiibo says. “Kokichi came to your lab at one last night, correct? Did you see anyone else when you went up the fourth floor?”

“N-No,” she stutters. “I-I mean, yeah, Kokichi started banging on my door at one in the fucking morning, but I didn’t see anyone else last night ‘sides him.” She frowns. “Also none of you assholes showed up when I screamed for help either.”

“If Himiko was working with Kokichi,” Ryoma sighs. “She probably knew that trapping Miu was part of his plan…” he shakes his head. “Whatever the hell his stupid plan was.”

Tenko stares at the ground. “But why? Why would Himiko agree to work with Kokichi?”

“I already said!” Miu shouts. “Killer and accomplice! What the fuck else do you need?”

“A reason why anyone would agree to such an arrangement,” Maki says.

“Yeah,” Kaito says. “It’s in Monokuma’s shitty rules that only person can graduate, right? The hell would anyone work together then?” He glances to Kokichi who beams back. “Also why the hell would anyone work with Kokichi?”

“I think the whys of this case will have to come later,” Maki says. “Especially since I doubt Kokichi’s about to start talking anytime soon.”

Tenko frowns. “But Kokichi just talked. He told us the timeframe and that he was working with Himiko.”

“Yeah!” says Angie. “God says that sure is a lot for Kokichi to come just come out and say.”

Maki begins fiddling with her hair in a poor attempt to hide her embarrassment while Kokichi laughs. “Looks like Maki needs to pay more attention instead of just saying things she thinks will make her look cool.”

“That’s not what I was doing,” Maki snaps.

Kokichi waves his hand. “Sure, sure, whatever.” 

Kiibo says, “If no one minds, there is another question I would like to ask regarding the idea that Himiko and Kokichi were working together.”

“Fucking ask it, Kiibs,” Miu says. “Got to be better than listening to shota fucking go on and on.”

“Well,” Kiibo says. “If Himiko and Kokichi were working together last night between Gonta’s time of death at midnight and Tenko’s discovery this morning, why do we only have evidence that Himiko was covered in blood?”

“Oh, I get it,” says Kaito. “What do you say Kokichi? You get sprayed with blood, too?”

Distantly, Ryoma just sighs, as Kokichi sticks out his tongue. “No! That’d be really gross, and blood stains white clothes really badly, right Kaito?”

Kaito glares. “What that the hell is that supposed to mean?”

Kokichi presses a finger to his lips. “It’s okay. We can talk about your incident in the cafeteria this morning later.”

Kaede senses the shouting match on the tip of Kaito’s tongue, and quickly cuts in, “We only know Himiko was covered in blood at some point because we found some on her and a set of her clothes that were bloody.”

“That’s right,” says Tsumugi. “Did anyone go to Kokichi’s room during the investigation?”

Kaito snorts. “Anyone dig through Kokichi’s closet?”

Kaede sighs. “Actually, yes. Kokichi told me the key to the handcuffs was in his room so we went there after searching Himiko’s.”

Maki frowns. “Earlier you said Kokichi had the key with him the whole time.”

“And I also said he lied about that,” Kaede says. 

“Soooo,” Angie says. “If Kokichi lied, does that mean he wanted Kaede to go to his room with him?”

“Doubt it,” Miu says. “I’ll fucking shove this podium up my ass if shota swings that way.”

“The point is,” Kaede says. “I went to Kokichi’s room with him and actually saw the inside of his closet, and there wasn’t anything even remotely bloody in there.”

“Kaede and Kokichi were also walking around together for most of the day,” Tenko adds. “Kaede likely would have noticed in Kokichi had blood anywhere on him like Himiko did.”

Angie hums. “Maybe Kokichi just washed it off really well? Ooh, or God thinks maybe he just hid his clothes somewhere else like the bathroom.”

“If it matters,” Tsumugi adds. “I actually went to Kirumi’s lab this morning to try and do laundry, and I didn’t see Kokichi’s or anyone else’s clothes while I was there.”

Miu shrivels up her nose in disgust. “Eww. Does that mean no one’s been washing their clothes?”

“Not the point,” Kaito says. 

She cackles. “Well that fucking answers that.”

“H-Hey!” Kaito shouts. “I fucking do laundry sometimes!”

“He has to,” Kokichi says brightly. “Otherwise Kaito would run out of stuff not covered in blood.”

Kaito growls, “I thought I told you to shut the fuck up.”

Kokichi smiles. “You didn’t. At least not recently.”

“What happened to Kaito this morning has nothing to do with the cases,” Kaede says firmly. “Kokichi, if you want to talk about it with him, you can do it later.”

Kokichi’s grin stretches uncomfortably far. “Oh, I plan to.”

Kaito grits his teeth. “Kaede,” he barks. “Just keep the conversation moving, alright? What do we need to talk about next?”

“Yeah, Kaede!” Kokichi says. “Do everything! Kaito needs your help!”

Despite the many times Kaede has seen the two go back and forth, there’s an anger lining Kaito’s words that she hasn’t heard before. “I don’t!” he shouts. “I just—! Kaede,” he yells again, “Himiko was covered in blood—Kokichi wasn’t. Why the fuck is that important?”

Maki answers before her. “It means between the two of them, only Himiko ever touched the body.”

“I think that’s true,” Kaede says. “But there’s still more questions.”

“Like how the fuck you get blood behind your ear from doing a corpse?” Miu asks. 

“Shut up,” Ryoma snaps.

Miu recoils. “I-I-I’m just a-asking ‘cause it’s w-weird, right?”

Kiibo nods. “It is. And it also makes me wonder what the purpose in touching the body was in the first place. Also, if we are to assume Kokichi is not the culprit, then I would like to know what the killer’s timeframe was in setting up the scene of the crime.”

Tenko fidgets in place. “What do you mean?”

“We have already established that the crime scene was setup in a very specific way,” Kiibo says. “And that even for the strongest of us here, moving someone as heavy as Gonta would likely be a feat that would take a great amount of time in order to accomplish due to the sheer labor required.”

“Hmm?” Angie tilts her head. “Is something wrong with that?”

“I believe there is,” Kiibo says. “Kokichi brought Miu to the fourth floor an hour after Gonta’s time of death, meaning he discovered the body before then.”

“From what we have discussed, Himiko probably found Gonta’s body around then, as well,” Tenko says, still staring at the ground. “And it is likely the killer would have done something to silence them if they had noticed either of Himiko or Kokichi after committing their crime.”

“Which means we can assume the killer left the crime scene before then,” Kaede says, furrowing her brow. “And that also means they had less than an hour to set everything up.”

Kokichi presses a finger to his lips. “I think this mystery might be my very favorite of this case. So, Kaede,” he shoots her a beaming smile, “do your best, and don’t be boring!”

(Present your Argument) 

“Based on Kokichi’s testimony,” Kiibo says. “The killer set up the crime scene in less than one hour last night.”

“Ooh!” says Angie. “God says they must be really, really fast!”

“Or really strong, right?” says Tsumugi. “Because they had to move Gonta’s body?”

“Kokichi’s a fucking freak,” Kaito says, “and was probably already wandering around on the fourth floor right when the crime scene was being setup.”

Angie tilts her head to one side. “So then Kokichi hid from the killer?” and the other. “Or did the killer hide from Kokichi?”

“Himiko was also likely there,” Tenko says softly. 

“So the killer hid from them both!” Angie announces. 

“In the middle of setting up the fucking crime scene?” Kaito says. 

“The idea that the killer was still on the fourth floor when Miu arrived is hard to believe,” says Kiibo. “Perhaps they came back to set up the crime scene after she fell into Kokichi’s trap.”

“So the culprit returned to the scene of the crime after Himiko, Kokichi, and Miu discovered what they had done,” Maki says dully, “and didn’t see any of them or do anything about Miu even though she was literally yelling from the next room.”

“A-Admittedly that is unlikely…” Kiibo stutters.

“God says the culprit is really fast, then!” Angie concludes.

(BREAK) 

“Kiibo,” Kaede says. “That’s it. The culprit had already left by the time Miu came to the fourth floor. In fact, they probably had left to go back to their room for the night before Kokichi showed up either.”

“So you’re saying the killer actually did return to the scene of the crime?” Maki asks. “And they failed to notice three potential witnesses?” 

Kaede shakes her head. “No, I’m saying I think the simplest solution is the answer. The people who set up the crime scene were the people who were on the fourth floor and had all night to do it: Himiko and Kokichi.”

Very slowly, Ryoma says, “It wasn’t… the killer didn’t…” he shakes his head, words seeming to fail him. 

Hesitantly, Tenko says, “Is that why Himiko was covered in blood? Was she the one who moved the body?”

Ryoma sighs again. “Kokichi probably could have helped her, too, without getting covered in blood. Gonta’s… Gonta’s stab wound mostly only got the front of his shirt bloody. If you focused only on pulling him by his arms or his side… you could do it.” He shrugs, blandly fiddling with the cigarette in his hands and staring someplace far away. “His blood was dry this morning, but that’s how I moved him.”

“And Ryoma’s looking pretty clean, huh?” Kokichi asks.

Kiibo still has his hand to his mouth, thinking deeply. “If we also continue our assumption that they had all night, there is also the possibility that they could have waited for the blood to dry a bit before attempting to move him.”

“Okay, okay,” Kaito says waving his hands. “I get your reasoning and shit, but can we not ignore that this is fucking insane!? I never went there, but literally everyone has said how fucking weird the crime scene was, and now we’re assuming two people who aren’t the culprit did it?”

“It is rather strange when you put it that way…” Tsumugi says. “Moving the body, stabbing the statues with the swords… did the killer really do neither of those things?”

Miu slams a hand on her podium. “How many times do I have to tell you assholes!? Kokichi literally did fucking everything in big dick’s murder! How in the fuck is he not the killer!?”

“Because I’m not!” Kokichi says. “Geeze, Miu, you sound like a broken record.”

“Kokichi,” Kaede says. “I’m going to ask you this straight out, and I expect a real answer.”

“A poor thing to do when it comes to him,” Maki says.

Kaede ignores her, focusing her attention solely on Kokichi. “Did you or did you not set up Angie’s statues and stab them with Himiko’s swords?”

“That’s the part you’re concerned about?” Miu says.

“Miu,” Kaede says, snapping her head to face the other girl. “The statues weren’t in the ritual room by the time you got locked in there, right?”

“Right…” she says slowly. “I woulda tired using one as a battering ram and thrust the head into the do—”

“So, Kokichi,” Kaede turns her attention back to him. “I need an answer right now.”

Kokichi puffs out his cheeks. “Well, it’s hard to answer because you’re asking me two different questions.”

“But she’s not?” Kaito says.

Kokichi waves a dismissive hand in his direction. “Hey, Kaito, why don’t you sit this one out and let someone who actually knows what they’re saying do the talking, hmm?”

“Shut the fuck up,” Kaito growls. “Are you trying to say that only you and Kaede know anything?”

“That’s not what I’m saying…” Kokichi says tilting his head. “But it is true.” He shrugs and gives Kaito a bland look. “Sorry, Kaito, you’re nice to look at, but you’re not really much of a hero, huh?”

To Kaede’s surprise, Kaito doesn’t bite back at him but instead seems genuinely taken off guard. Maki snaps, “Stop insulting him for your own amusement. It’s tiring and it gets us nowhere.”

“Fine then,” Kokichi says before turning back to Kaede. “And to answer your question, Kaede, no and yes.”

“That is not a real answer,” Tenko says. “And Kaede specifically asked you to—”

“I heard her,” he says, rolling his eyes. “And I answered. No and yes.”

Kaede sighs. “Fine. At least you admit you had a hand in setting up the crime scene. Chances are we aren’t going to find out a whole lot of whys in this case until we find the culprit, but,” she presses a hand to her forehead, “Kokichi what purpose did you possibly have in doing all of that?”

“It was probably just to make the crime more interesting,” Maki says. “I think we can all agree Kokichi enjoys doing idiotic things like that.”

Kokichi giggles. “Man, Maki thinks she knows everything. It’s so funny!”

“Then ignore her,” Kaede says, not missing the way Maki scowls at her, “and answer my question. I thought the crime scene was strange during the whole investigation because I couldn’t even begin to imagine how it would have helped the killer, but knowing someone other than the killer did it just makes things stranger.”

“I did it to help everyone,” Kokichi beams. “I wanted to give you guys a few hints. See, try imaging what the crime scene looked like before my help.”

“What help?” Ryoma scoffs. “The only thing you’ve helped do is show us how much of a freak you are.”

Tsumugi hugs her arms to her chest. “To think someone’s enjoying the killing game so much to just toy with us like this…”

Kaede furrows her brow. “I think we should listen to him.”

Miu says, “You always wanna fucking listen to him. What got a crush on whiny, pasty, and emo number two?”

Kaede glares at her darkly from under her hat. “Miu, I am actually very angry at you right now, but that isn’t important.” 

Miu wilts. “I-I just meant—”

“How the crime scene looked before Kokichi arrived,” Kiibo says, thinking aloud. “We still have not established why he was down there or how he was killed in such a position, but Gonta was under the floor, correct?” 

“And the statues Angie created would not have been there,” Tenko adds.

“The room…” Ryoma says. “It… it would have been completely normal looking…”

Angie presses her hands to her cheeks. “Would we have even found the body?”

“I… don’t know,” Kaede says. “What happens if someone’s killed, but we never discover their corpse?”

“There can’t be a class trial, right?” Kaito says finally. “Maybe… maybe the killer didn’t want to have a trial at all, then.”

Kokichi smiles proudly. “Aw, looks like Kaito has a brain in there somewhere, even if he still needs to rely on Kaede for everything.”

Kaito sends him a tired glare but remains silent, other than mumbling, “Just shut up.”

Tenko says, “Wait, does that mean Kokichi manipulated the crime scene to make us discover the body that means he wanted a class trial, correct?”

“Wait,” Miu says, seemingly recovered, “The gorgeous genius inventor Miu Iruma has a better question that you’re all probably pissing all over yourselves to hear.”

She pauses dramatically, and after a moment of silence she nudges Kiibo’s shoulder, prompting him to ask, “What is your question, Miu?”

“Glad you asked, Kiibs!” she says. “So, get this—big dick’s body is under the floor before the loli-shota duo arrive on the scene, yeah? Did they just decide to get down and dirty under the floor for no reason?”

Kaede blinks. “That’s actually a really good point.”

“D-Don’t sound so surprised!” Miu shouts back. “I have lots of good points!”

Tenko’s voice is soft when she says, “Kokichi said he and Himiko worked together… Tenko has no idea why Himiko would agree to such a thing, but the fact that they did means that maybe one of them discovered Gonta’s body and… simply told the other?”

Kaede nods. “That makes sense. Also, if they did work together, we probably shouldn’t assume they both found Gonta independently, especially given the original positioning of his body.”

Angie hums. “We keep talking about how Gonta was under the floor when he died, but God still doesn’t know why. Ooh,” she clasps her hands together, “and we don’t know how he was killed yet either!”

“And we still have very few clues to explain why or how Himiko was killed later,” Kiibo adds. 

“Her death is probably related to whatever plan she had with Kokichi,” Maki says. “In Kaede’s testimony, she said Himiko came down from the fourth floor where Kokichi was waiting for them to arrive. It’s likely the two had been planning something right up until that point.”

“And the second part of their plan resulted in Himiko’s death?” Tsumugi asks. “So even if Kokichi isn’t the culprit, did he still trick her into getting herself killed?”

Tenko shouts, “That can’t be what happened! Because—because Himiko would never fall for a horrible boy’s awful—”

“But what if it’s true?” Kokichi asks blankly. 

Kaede just stares at him in shock as a sudden silence crashes over them.

After a moment of hesitation, Kaito manages to stutter, “I-Is that a confession? Like, for fucking real this time?”

Then Kokichi giggles. “Geeze, you guys. Can’t you tell a lie when you hear one?”

“You’re being suspected of murder,” Ryoma says. “You do realize that.”

“Enough already!” Tenko yells. “Tenko is-is—is so tired of this.” She lets out a sigh and seems so exhausted as she shakes her head. “We have been arguing and yelling at each other for so long, and we are still no closer to figuring out why Himiko died than when we started.”

Kaede murmurs, “Tenko…”

Maki says, “Why do you have a problem? Kokichi clearly had a hand in Himiko’s death—defending him makes no logical sense.”

Tenko just shakes her head again. “Tenko is tired of lies and insults and everyone thinking of themselves,” she says, “and Tenko knows that Kokichi is hiding something, and she doesn’t know why. But she also knows that he would never kill anyone, and we are wasting time accusing him.” She takes a deep breath. “Tenko wants to find the truth in this trial so Gonta and Himiko can have justice—so their deaths will matter. If Tenko just fought and clawed at everyone for her own survival, then she would be no different than the killer.”

A new silence falls over the others, though one more of acceptance than discomfort. However, after a moment, Maki’s voice breaks the quiet again, “ignoring the platitudes,” she begins, and Kaede braces herself for whatever is to come next, “you keep saying you believe in Kokichi and that he wouldn’t kill someone. Why is that?”

Tenko falters. “T-Tenko just believes in him.”

“Ooh, Tenko,” says Angie, “earlier you said you’d rather die than not believe in your friends, soooo is Kokichi your friend? Ooh, what if he killed Himiko—would he still be your friend then?”

Kokichi mercifully remains silent as Tenko says, “Tenko just knows that it is impossible for Kokichi to have committed this crime.”

Kaede nods hurriedly. “I agree. And,” she looks over Kokichi’s head to Tenko standing a few podiums away, “I also want to work with everyone to find justice for our friends. I think that’s really the only thing we can do.” Tenko smiles back at her, and Kaede turns to say, “So let’s turn our attention to Himiko’s case so we can finally get a fuller picture of her involvement and why the killer went after her.”

“Ah,” says Tsumugi. “I mean, I want to find justice for my friends, too, but does Himiko’s case matter?”

“A fair point,” Maki says. “We only need to vote for whoever killed Gonta. Didn’t the two of you just go on and on about wasting time on unnecessary things?”

“Maki,” Kaito says. “Who gives a shit about which death we need to figure out?” He slams his fists together. “Fuck Monokuma’s rules—Himiko and Gonta are both fucking relying on us to find out what happened to them, and that’s what we’re going to do.”

Kokichi smiles. “Spoken like a real fake hero, Kaito. But anyway,” he ignores the scowl Kaito’s face morphs into, “why don’t we figure out Himiko’s cause of death? That should clear up most of Kaede’s questions.”

“Not all of our questions?” Ryoma says lowly.

“Nope!” Kokichi cheers. “Just Kaede’s!” He tilts his head to the side. “And maybe Miu’s, but I think she’s too stupid to get it.”

Miu rises to his provocation again, but Kaede ignores them, instead exchanging a shared supportive smile with Tenko before launching into the next debate.

(Present your Argument) 

“If you know what Himiko was doing during the blackout,” Kokichi says. “Then you can figure out everything about her cause of death! It’s almost like you’re playing on easy mode after figuring that out…”

“Himiko’s cause of death,” Tsumugi says. “The Monokuma File said she was strangled, right? Is there anything else to that?”

“It also said the killer used some sort of object!” Angie says. “Angie thinks it was a rope!”

“Tenko investigated Himiko’s injuries,” Tenko says. “Whatever… whatever was wrapped around her neck was likely more solid and bulky than a rope.”

“More solid?” Kaito echoes. “What do you mean?”

Tenko says, “like something heavier.” She looks down at the ground, “something that would cut into her neck more…”

“A rope wouldn’t do that?” Tsumugi asks. 

Angie steeples her hands. “Angie will pray for Himiko. Maybe her spirit can tell us what happened.”

“Ooh, Kaito,” Kokichi chimes in, “is this the part where you say, ‘there are no ghosts and I’m super tough!’”

Kaito glares at him. “Just shut up.”

Tenko wrings her hands. “Maybe Tenko’s report was wrong and it was a rope…”

“God doesn’t know where the killer could find anything that wasn’t a rope,” Angie adds. “Even in the storage room.”

(BREAK) 

Kaede chooses her words carefully as she speaks next. “Hey, Miu, before I go any further, I need you to do me a favor and think really carefully before you say anything.”

“I always think about the shit I say,” Miu answers, tossing her hair over her shoulder.

Ryoma sends her a skeptical look. “Kaede, you’re really not doing yourself any favors in looking innocent right now.”

Kaede can only sigh. “I know, but it really can’t be helped if… some of the details surrounding Himiko’s case are what I think they are.”

Tenko looks at her with clear concern. Choosing her words deliberately, she says, “Tenko still believes in Kaede, but what about Himiko’s case do you and Miu need to be careful talking about?”

“I’m really sorry,” Kaede says. “I’ll tell you later. But, if it’s alright, there’s a few questions I need to ask you about Himiko’s body.”

Tenko suddenly looks uncomfortable but says, “Okay… Tenko went over what she knows already, but she will still try to answer.”

“Thank you,” Kaede says. “We all know the Monokuma File says that the culprit used an object like a rope to kill her, but you said it was likely something harder and thicker, right?”

Tenko nods, ignoring Miu snorting in the background. “That’s right…”

“Is there any chance,” Kaede takes a deep breath, “that it could have been a bundle of cables?”

Tenko stares at her blankly for a moment. “Tenko… wouldn’t know…”

“Like,” Kaede gestures vaguely. “A bunch of cables all bound together. They’d be strong and thick and would probably leave an uneven pattern when they cut into someone’s neck. Himiko’s wounds looked something like that, right?”

Tenko furrows her brow. “That is true, but where did the culprit—”

Suddenly Miu screams, “Oh shit! Oh shit!”

“Looks like Miu figured it out,” Kokichi hums. 

“I’m afraid I am not following,” Kiibo says. “If a bundle of cables was the weapon, does that mean Himiko was killed in the computer room?”

Ryoma shakes his head. “I was upstairs during the whole investigation. If someone walked past me to go there during the blackout, I would’ve heard.”

“And Ryoma definitely would have fucking heard if Himiko started fighting against her killer or something,” Kaito adds. “So if we’re assuming it was a bunch of cables…” he trails off. “Why are we assuming a bunch of cables was the murder weapon?”

“This is mostly speculation, I admit,” Kaede says. “And I know you guys don’t have all the information I do, but I’m fairly certain Himiko was killed somewhere… specific.”

Miu says, “You can fucking say that again.” She snaps her fingers. “Hey! Any of you assholes see pancake during the blackout?”

“Tenko searched the school for her,” Tenko says. “But… she was not able to find her or wherever she was being killed…”

“And quite unfortunately,” Kokichi says. “I already asked everyone when I was with Kaede, and it turns out we were the only two who were together the whole time.”

Miu quickly adds, “A-And we already said that I have an alibi and shit.”

Maki looks between them. “Funny that the only three people who seem to have any idea what’s going on are the only ones with alibis.”

“Yeah,” Kaito says. “I mean, not the suspecting you guys part, but like,” he rubs at the back of his head, “what the fuck is going on?”

Kiibo says, “From… what I can follow, it seems Kaede, Miu, and Kokichi are all in agreement about the weapon used to kill Himiko, and its description does fit with Tenko’s autopsy report. However, why they are all so sure is… unclear, though it seems to have something to do with where Himiko was killed.”

“But we don’t know where that was,” Tsumugi says. “Right?”

“If Tenko couldn’t find Himiko during the blackout,” Angie says, “God doesn’t think anyone could!”

Kaede fidgets with Shuichi’s hat, internally struggling with what she can actually say aloud. Tenko’s far too concerned stare and voice softly calling out, “Kaede?” does nothing to help.

Miu decides to step in. “Wait one fucking second! The amazing archangel Miu Iruma just realized something!”

Kaede regards her warily, debating even acknowledging her before saying, “Miu, remember what I said. Please think carefully…”

She waves a hand dismissively at her. “Yeah, yeah—I got it. But,” she dramatically gestures to herself. “The only fucking people who should know anything about anything are me and Bakamatsu so why,” for perhaps the hundredth time that day Kaede absently thinks, Miu jabs an accusatory finger in Kokichi’s direction, “does he know anything!?”

Kokichi shrugs. “‘Cause I know everything.”

“No,” Kaede says. “Miu’s right. Why would you… and why would Himiko even know about that place?”

Kokichi grins. “Someone told someone!”

“The only people who should know…” Kaede says again, “are me, Miu, and the…” she trails off, glancing at the variety of confused and frustrated faces lining the court room. She swallows and makes a decision. “And the mastermind.”

A general murmur of, “Mastermind?” seems to start up, but Kokichi’s voice quickly cuts over the group. “The door to Miu’s lab isn’t soundproof,” he says, all previous playfulness vanishing from his voice. “That’s why I knew.”

Miu immediately shouts, “So you were fucking listening in on us, you little pervert!”

She keeps yelling, but Kaede just stares at him, attempting to piece through all the words she knows he’s not saying. Piece together why he all but outright told her to shut up.

More accusations fly at Kokichi, and Kaede puts together the information only she and Kokichi know. Himiko used one of Miu’s EMPs to cause the blackout. She was killed using the cables in the mastermind’s secret room. And everything that happened was part of some plan she had with Kokichi. The whys of the situation remain elusive, but over the rising din, Kaede says, “Himiko’s death isn’t related to Gonta’s.”

Tenko is the first to respond, asking, “What?” far too helplessly.

Kaede takes a deep breath. “I know I’m being secretive, but I have reason to believe that Gonta’s killer and Himiko’s are not the same person. Which means…” she turns to address everyone. “Even if we discover who killed Himiko, we can’t do anything about it.”

“But,” Kaito says, “didn’t we just all say we were gonna find justice for her? That we weren’t going to—”

“If you think this is about justice or friendship,” Kokichi says, “then you will never learn the truth behind this case. But then again,” he beams at him, “I didn’t expect you to in the first place.”

Kaito’s hands tighten into fists. “The hell is that supposed to mean?”

“Calm down,” Kaede says. “I don’t know why Kokichi’s saying some of the things he is, but he’s right that there are some serious problems in trying to figure out the culprit behind Himiko’s death.”

“Like the fact that none of you sluts should have been able to do it?” Miu says.

Kaede chooses to ignore her comment, continuing forward, “Himiko was responsible for the blackout, and to cause the blackout, she went to a secret place that only me, Miu and apparently Kokichi should have known about. However, we all have alibis,” she suddenly realizes something all at once, “Kokichi set it up to make sure it would be impossible for any of us to go after her. Isn’t that why you handcuffed yourself to me and trapped Miu upstairs last night?”

Kokichi rocks back and forth on his heels. “Maybe.”

Kaito shakes his head. “All that fucking means is that is had to be someone else, right? Isn’t narrowing down suspects a good thing?”

Kaede says, “The problem is that with the exception of me and Kokichi, everyone else was alone at some point during the blackout, and there’s no time of death on the Monokuma File.”

“Which means she could have been killed at any point after the power went off,” Maki says. “Strangling someone as weak and frail as Himiko probably wouldn’t take a lot of time, and it wouldn’t require the killer to clean up any blood.”

Angie adds, “Ooh, but wasn’t Himiko’s body in the cafeteria? Doesn’t that mean the killer carried her there?”

“It does,” Kaede says. “But did anyone see anyone carrying her there?” 

“Moving Himiko’s body…” Tenko says. “It probably wouldn’t have taken the killer much time…”

“So, um,” Tsumugi says. “What does all this mean? Himiko’s killer is still one of us, right?”

“They are,” Kaede says firmly. “And that person is the mastermind.”

Maki shakes her head. “Didn’t you say that before? With Rantaro’s death?”

“I thought we agreed Monokuma killed Rantaro or something,” Kaito says.

“No,” Maki says, “we didn’t.”

“Kaede’s right,” Kokichi adds. “Himiko’s death is impossible to figure out, so let’s go back to talking about Gonta.”

“Wait!” Tenko shouts. “Y-Himiko’s death is not impossible! There is a solution that we can find here, right?” She looks to Kaede with pleading eyes. “Right? Himiko’s killer—there’s absolutely no way we can just ignore them, a-and,” she moves to wipe away the tears forming in her eyes, “a-and just let them keep hiding and living with all of us… if we don’t find them here, that’s… that’s what’s going to happen…”

Kaito nods. “There’s no way in hell we’re going to allow that. Especially if they are the mastermind, that means we can end this whole fucking thing right now!”

“And then God says we can all go home!” Angie says.

“If we find out who killed Himiko…” Ryoma says. “We can all leave.”

“No,” Maki says. “That’s not how the rules work. Himiko died second, and Monokuma’s already made it abundantly clear that even if we do figure out who killed her, they won’t be executed.”

“B-But that means,” Tsumugi stutters, “that we just have to live with a murderer?”

Carefully, Kiibo says, “Pardon me if this theory is off base, but is there a chance the culprit explicitly took action after Gonta’s death so that rule would protect them?”

Ryoma lets out a sigh. “If Himiko’s killer really is the mastermind, then they would have known what happened to Gonta, and that they could kill anyone who got in their way without consequences…”

“And starting the blackout,” Angie says. “If Kaede’s right and Himiko did that, God thinks the mastermind probably didn’t like that very much.”

“W-Wait,” Miu stutters, suddenly shaking, “th-the rip-your-tits-off-and-eat-them-mastermind—that mastermind—st-strangled someone cause they fucked with their shit?”

“That’s what we’ve been saying, yes,” Maki says.

Miu’s eyes are wide with panic, and her words come fast and frantic, “s-so if you know about that p-place or fucking made something, o-or—!” she directs her gaze to Monokuma, “I swear to fucking God it was all Bakamatsu!” she shouts, “I-I didn’t fucking do anything! S-So d-don’t—!”

“Miu,” Kiibo says, “Are you alright?”

“Am I alright!?” she screeches. “The mastermind’s gonna—gonna fucking kill me in my sleep!” She begins clawing at her head, chanting, “I have to get out of here, I have to get out of here,” under her breath. “This place is hell! I-I am not going to fucking die here!”

“Don’t be silly, Miu,” Kokichi says. “The mastermind can only get away with killing you if someone else dies first!” He puffs out his cheeks. “Also the mastermind killing someone is so rude—totally ruins the game. Soooo,” he folds his hands behind his head, “let’s go back to talking about Gonta’s death.”

“How the fuck can you say that!?” Kaito shouts. “We just figured out who killed Himiko—”

“We didn’t,” Kokichi says. “But if Kaito found any clues while he was investigating, I’d be happy to hear!”

Kaito turns away from him, mumbling darkly, “you know I didn’t fucking investigate.”

“That’s right!” Kokichi says. “The only people who investigated were me and Kaede, and I say we move on to Gonta’s death.” He turns to Kaede, “and Kaede says…?”

Kaede knows he’s testing her, and Kaito and Tenko’s stares weigh heavily on her when she finally says, “We shouldn’t ignore what happened to Himiko, but for the time being—in order to get through this trial—we need to find out who killed Gonta. If we don’t, we’ll all die here, and then we’ll never discover Himiko’s true killer.”

With the exception of Miu still mumbling to herself, a heavy silence hangs over the room. The inspiration that Tenko’s words moments earlier had inspired completely vanishes in the face of the reality of their situation, and Kaede realizes again that she has to be the one moving them forward. She straightens her hat, and says, “There are still a few big mysteries surrounding Gonta’s death. If we want to find his killer, we need to start with those.”

It’s not a surprise that Ryoma is the first one to respond. “Why he was under the floor,” he says. “Still don’t know the answer to that.”

“Why did Himiko agree to help Kokichi in creating the crime scene, too,” Tenko adds, shaking her head. “Himiko was so worried about helping everyone… Tenko can’t believe she would decide to trick us for no reason.”

“Though he has proved to enjoy being uncooperative for the sake of it,” Kiibo says, “we still also do not know the true nature behind Kokichi’s plan and how it relates to Gonta’s death.”

“Also,” Tsumugi says, “I don’t think we ever agreed on what the murder weapon in Gonta’s case was.”

Kaede nods. “All of that sounds right, and I think we should start with how Gonta and possibly the culprit got under the floor.” 

Kaito crosses his arms. “So we’re just fucking moving on.”

Kaede sighs. “We have no other choice…”

(Present your Argument) 

Kiibo says, “I believe I was the first to discover some of the floorboards were loose this morning. During the investigation, it was remarkably easy to simply move them out of place.”

“The floorboards in Miu’s room were also loose,” Kokichi says. “That’s how the cockroach was able to scuttle under the floor.”

Miu mutters, “Shut up—shut up!” still pulling at her hair.

Kiibo seems slightly taken aback but says, “Erm, the opening in the floorboards under the middle was rather large. Even someone like Gonta probably could have gone through easily enough to get underneath the floor.”

“Kokichi and Kaede spent a lot of time down there,” Ryoma says. “Think they were able to access each room.”

“Oh, does that mean every room had the floor cut up in the same way?” Tsumugi asks.

Kokichi sniffles. “I got all dirty crawling around under there, especially when we had to follow the blood trail…”

“Blood trail?” Kaito repeats.

“Oh?” Kokichi taps a finger to his chin. “Did I forget to mention that when I did all the work for you?”

Maki snaps, “Stop letting him get to you.”

“There was a large amount of blood under the floor,” Kiibo confirms, “However, it was slightly off center from where the floorboards could be easily removed, though if Gonta was moved, I suppose there is a logical explanation for that as well.”

(BREAK) 

“Wait, that’s wrong,” Kaede says. “During the investigation, it is true that each of the three rooms had some of their floorboards cut up, but while the middle room and ritual room seemed to have the same consistency in the way the floor was sawed open, the last room was different.”

“So the killer did something different to get under the floor in the last room,” Kiibo says. “Is that correct?”

Kaede nods. “I think so. When we were investigating, Kokichi and I found two different saws—one that was a normal handsaw hidden in the ritual room and the other was the large circular saw Himiko was supposed to use for one of her magic tricks.”

“But why would the killer do that?” Tsumugi asks. “Was there a reason why they needed to use two different saws?”

“I would like to know that as well,” Kiibo says. “Also, I would like to know the culprit’s purpose in going under the floor.”

“Kaede said Himiko lost her keys,” Ryoma adds. “Maybe the killer had those so they could get into some of the rooms, but needed a way to move to the ones they didn’t have a key to.”

Kaede furrows her brow. Though he’s working off her lie, something about Ryoma’s words click in her brain. “One of the issues we had in the beginning was how this case was a locked room, but Ryoma’s right. The killer only needed to be able to get into one of the rooms and then saw up the floor to move to freely to the others.”

“But,” Tenko says, “Why did the killer need to go to each room? All that was in the final room was stuff for Himiko’s magic show…”

“And that was also the only room that was different,” Kaede says. “So maybe… the killer didn’t go there.”

“So someone else sawed through the floor?” Angie asks. “Hmm… Angie doesn’t know why anyone would do that.” She clasps her hands together over her head. “Angie will try asking God to see if he knows.”

“I don’t think we have to do that,” Kaede says. “After all, last night, Himiko—”

“Himiko dropped one of her keys…” Tenko says. “The cracks in the floor were not very wide, but Tenko remembers that the key was still small enough to slip through. It… was very important to Himiko that she retrieve it herself… so important that Tenko let her stay there while she went to bed.” Tenko shakes her head. “If only Tenko had helped her, then maybe Himiko—maybe she…”

Kaede says gently, “You couldn’t have known, and you can’t blame yourself for not being able to predict the future. But,” she straightens her hat, “I think it’s safe to say that Himiko was the one cut up the floor in that room, especially since when I examined the setup for her magic trick, there were no signs of force in removing the saw blade, indicating whoever took it apart knew what they were doing.”

“Wait,” Maki says, “isn’t that a contradiction?”

Kaede frowns. “To what?” 

“You said Himiko lost her keys,” she continues. “If she retrieved it from under the floor, then she would have had it this morning.”

“Maybe Himiko lost it again?” Angie asks.

“No,” Maki says. “Tenko just said it important to her to get her keys back when she lost them. Why would she carelessly lose them again?”

“There were two rooms Himiko had keys to on the fourth floor,” Kaede says quickly. “She just lost her key to one of them.”

“And that key was less important than the other?” Maki persists.

“Maybe she was in a panic this morning?” Tsumugi suggests. “Especially if she was on her way to start the blackout…” she shakes her head. “How did Himiko start the blackout?”

Kaede stutters, “Uh, that’s not important. None of this is. All that matters is that Himiko and the killer both independently used different saws to get under the floor.”

Maki shakes her head. “That isn’t an answer to my question, and it’s suspicious that you’re refusing to answer.”

Kaede finds herself faltering when Kokichi comes to her rescue. “I know! I know!” he shouts, waving an arm in the air. “Himiko lied about losing her keys, right Kaede?”

Kaede blinks. “She did?”

He puffs out his cheeks. “Geeze, Kaede, do you really not remember? What did we find in Himiko’s room besides her clothes? It was shiny and gold and—”

“Th-That’s right,” Kaede says. “Folded up in her bloody clothes, there was… one of her keys and another key covered in gold glitter.”

“Uh, why the fuck would Himiko or anyone else have something like that?” Kaito asks. 

Kokichi ignores him. “The pretty shiny key was also kinda bloody, but then again, it was wrapped in bloody clothing!”

Ryoma shakes his head. “Where does any of this get us? Himiko went under the floor, got her key, and then she decided to help disguise a crime scene because Kokichi talked her into it?”

Kokichi says, “I am awfully convincing.”

“Also,” Kiibo says. “Did Himiko manage to do all of that without the killer noticing? Did she do it before or after Gonta was killed?”

“We left Himiko around when nighttime announcement played,” Kaede says. “So that was ten, and the Gonta’s death was at midnight, though he likely arrived there a little before that.”

“So Himiko was there the whole time?” says Angie. “What about Kokichi? Was he with her?”

Kaito snorts. “If Kokichi was there, the killer probably would have noticed them. Kokichi’s fucking loud.”

“I am not!” Kokichi whines. “Kaito’s picking on me…”

“I don’t know about Kokichi,” Kaede says, “and this is mostly just a theory, but…” she reaches up to fiddle with brim of her hat, “but I think Himiko may have been there when the murder occurred.”

“Kaede,” Tenko says. “Tenko does not think that’s possible because if Himiko witnessed the murder firsthand, then she would have known who the killer is.”

Ryoma’s harsh voice cuts through the room, “and wouldn’t that mean Kokichi knows, too?”

He smiles widely. “It sure is a possibility, huh? But,” he starts rubbing at his teary eyes, “even if I told you guys, none of you would believe me… you’d probably just vote for me even though I left so many hints…”

“So you do know,” Ryoma says, voice deathly quiet. “Then spit it out already.”

“Um, not to defend Kokichi,” Tsumugi says, “but isn’t the idea that Himiko saw the murder take place just an assumption? I-I mean it might be true, but I don’t think there’s any evidence…”

“Oh, yeah, Tsumugi,” says Angie. “That’s true. That’s true.”

Kiibo nods. “We also still have yet to answer the mystery of why Gonta was under the floor in the first place. For Kaede’s theory to work, would that mean both Gonta and Himiko were under the floor at the same time?”

“And the killer didn’t notice her?” Kaito says. “But didn’t they saw up the floor as an escape route? I mean, Himiko’s pretty fucking small, but I think the killer would probably see her if she was lurking under the floor.”

Kaede straightens her shoulders. “I think that might trace back to what Himiko was doing under the floor at the time Gonta was killed. It’s something Kokichi and I accidentally discovered, too.” She sets her hat forward on her head. “And I think it might also be the answer to why Himiko did what she did.”

(Present your Argument) 

“This case started,” Kiibo says, “with the killer threatening Gonta into coming up to the fourth floor and then tricking him into going under the floor.”

“What was the killer’s trick?” Tsumugi asks. “Did they maybe pretend to drop something through the floorboards like Himiko did?”

“What was Himiko doing all that time?” Tenko asks quietly. “She-She got her key and then…”

“She obviously had to go back up,” Kaito says. “Otherwise the killer would have fucking noticed her.”

“It is dark down there,” Kiibo says. “If Himiko was simply crawling around in the dark, it is doubtful that she would have seen anything, and if she had a light, the killer likely would have seen it.”

“Maybe she took a nap like Miu!” Kokichi says.

“Maybe you should shut the fuck up!” Miu says.

“Oh?” Angie asks. “But if Himiko took a nap under the floor, she would have missed everything!”

“Just like Miu!” Kokichi cheers.

(BREAK) 

“No, Kiibo,” Kaede says. “That’s not true.”

He frowns. “Did I make a mistake?”

She nods. “Yes, during the investigation, Kokichi and I actually figured out that if you’re moving underneath the floor and you use a light source like your monopad aimed at the ground, it’s actually pretty easy to go unnoticed by anyone above you.”

“Ah!” says Angie. “Angie remembers that! But,” she places a finger on her chin. “Is that what Himiko did?” 

“I remember that, too,” Ryoma says. “You guys were loud because Kokichi kept whining, but I didn’t notice any light, and…” he sighs, “I was looking at the ground near where Kiibo pulled the floorboards up for most of the investigation.”

“R-Right…” Kaede says. “And not only that, but I think what Tsumugi said was also true.”

“Huh?” she asks. “Me?”

“The key covered in gold glitter that Kokichi and I found in Himiko’s room,” Kaede says. “We, um, tested it after finding it, and it turns out it was the key to the ritual room.”

“Angie’s key?” Angie asks. “Is that where it went? But why did Himiko take it?”

“Why the fuck would someone even cover a key in glitter in the first place?” Kaito asks. “They want it to be special or stand out or something?”

Kaede nods. “I think that’s exactly it. Something else I discovered during the investigation is that the glitter on the key still really stands out with even just a little bit of light. Not to mention, going to the trouble of covering something gold glitter was likely a very deliberate choice on the killer’s part, especially since the glitter sticks to stuff really easily.”

“So you’re saying the killer went to the trouble of preparing a special key to stand out in the dark,” Maki says. “And they did that because?”

“Oh, um,” Tsumugi says. “You said you think I got it right, when I plainly said that—I think it was—the killer tricked Gonta by pretending to accidentally drop something under the floor?”

“But if that happened,” Kiibo says, “and Himiko happened to be under the floor to retrieve her own key at the same time—”

“—or waking up from a nap after getting her key because of all the noise,” Kokichi adds. “Gonta’s really heavy so he has really loud footsteps, like—” 

Kokichi begins making sound effects akin to Godzilla crashing through a city. Kiibo chooses to ignore him. “Ah, so if Himiko was under the floor while the culprit was attempting to lure Gonta by dropping the shining key, she logically would have seen it as well, correct?”

“And, what?” Kaito asks, rubbing the back of his head. “They both go after it at the same fucking time or something? I mean, Gonta was into being a gentleman and shit, so I get why he would do it—”

“No,” Ryoma says. “He came into the room being threatened—a room full of swords. There’s no way he would just do what the killer said.”

“Maybe he felt like he had to,” Tenko says. “Because of the killer’s note… If it was Tenko and Himiko was being threatened, she would have done it.”

Ryoma shakes his head. “He wouldn’t do that. Gonta… he always said he was an idiot, but he wasn’t. And,” Ryoma lets out a sigh, looking at the ground, “I refuse to believe he’d just let himself be killed like that.”

“What if,” Kaede says, “what if he did it to protect Himiko?”

“What?” Ryoma asks.

“There’s actually some evidence for this, too, but,” Kaede begins, voice soft, “Gonta had really good vision, right? He and you would look for bugs outside that no one else could see.”

Ryoma pulls his hat lower but remains silent. 

Kaede keeps going. “So maybe—even if the killer didn’t—Gonta saw Himiko moving underneath the floor towards the key, which… was probably also the killer’s mark about where to stab in the dark.”

“That’s a nice theory,” Maki says. “But if you’re just saying all that to make Ryoma feel better, you aren’t accomplishing much.”
