Kokichi grins. “My Kaito knows I only tell helpful lies, too!”

Kaede looks between them. “Well, I think that’s everything. Thanks for your help.”

Kaito salutes her. “You got it.”

Kaede tries to smile back as nonchalantly as she can as Kaito shuts the door. She hears the two of them begin to argue over something inane, and she clenches her jaw, trying not to dwell on just how much their story conflicted with the one Ryoma had told her earlier.

-

When the doors to the school close behind her, Kaede resolves to take a brief trip to the bathroom to splash water on her face to calm every raging emotion threatening to overtake her before heading back to the computer room. She makes the walk in peace until she notices Maki standing alone outside the girls’ bathroom, leaning against the wall with her arms crossed. 

“Maki?” she says. “What are you doing?”

“Waiting for Miu,” Maki says. “She was working in her lab, and then suddenly shouted that she had to go to the bathroom. So,” she shrugs. “I’m waiting to force her to explain herself when she’s done.”

Kaede frowns. “Has she been in there long?”

“Almost twenty minutes now,” Maki says. “Of course, I’m sure if I bring that up she’ll say something disgusting.”

“That’s… probably true,” Kaede says before shaking her head. “Anyway, Maki, I want to ask you something. Tenko said you logged out of the program ear—”

“I did,” she says. “Is there a problem with that?”

Kaede resists the urge to roll her eyes. “You really don’t need to withhold information from me for literally everything.”

“If it’s not important to the trial,” Maki says. “Then I see no reason why I need to tell anyone what I was doing.”

Kaede can’t stop herself from glaring. Then she says, “Tenko said she saw you watching Kokichi. What do you have to say about that?”

“I’d say she’s always had a wildly out of control imagination,” Maki says evenly. “Also, I understand the two of you are attached at the hip, but Tenko’s a rather poor choice for an investigation partner in my opinion.”

“Well, Maki, I really don’t care about your opinion,” Kaede replies. “And I have no idea why you think I do.”

Maki’s face darkens, and she opens her mouth to speak when the door to the girls’ bathroom suddenly slams open.

They both turn to see Miu framed in the doorway, her monopad held in one hand. Her eyes dart between them, and she says, “Can’t a girl fucking shit in peace?”

Kaede sighs. “Miu, were you able to figure out anything about what happened to Kiibo?”

Miu runs a hand through her hair. “Almost everything was fucking fried—nothing in his body would respond to any commands—honestly most of him is fucking scrap metal now.”

“Poor Kiibo,” Kaede says, looking at the ground. 

“His main A.I. was shot to shit, too,” Miu says before breaking out into a bright, genuine smile. “So it’s a really good fucking thing I set his A.I. to back up earlier.”

“You saved him!?” Kaede says.

Miu turns the monopad towards them. “Check it out, baby—maybe his body’s gone, but Kiibs isn’t out of the game yet.”

Kaede stares intently at the screen and notices out of the corner of her eye that Maki does as well as it lights up. Then Kiibo’s face is blinking at them. “Kiibo,” Kaede breathes out. “Is that you?”

He smiles. “Hello, Kaede and Maki! I am afraid my processes are limited now, but—”

“Do you know who killed you?” Maki asks.

His smile falters. “I… was killed?”

Kaede looks up at Miu in confusion. “What?”

“I set him to back his A.I. up at midnight every night,” Miu says. “Which means,” she sighs, “this is a copy of Kiibo who doesn’t have any memories of what happened after that.”

“And he lives in your monopad,” Maki says.

“I did my fucking best!” Miu screams, not flinching even under Maki’s cold glare. “I fucking saved him!”

Kiibo’s voice calls out, “Miu, are you alright? Is something wrong—”

“No,” she says. “Everything’s fine—and the fucking trial’s cancelled now, right?”

Kaede blinks. “Oh. That’s actually a really good—”

“Wrong!” says a voice behind them, and all three girls spin around to see Monokuma back from the dead behind them.

Maki’s the first to recover, asking, “What do you mean ‘wrong?’”

“I mean of course there’s going to be a trial!” he says. “Even if the victim isn’t dead, their body was discovered and a victim they remain—that’s why we could count a robot like Kiibo at all!”

“But,” Kaede’s mind races. “Wait. We’re going to have a trial when there isn’t a victim!?”

“There may not be a victim,” Monokuma says, bringing his paws to his mouth. “But there certainly was an attempt to graduate, and there certainly is a blackened among you.”

“But if Kiibo’s fine—”

“He was still murdered,” Maki says. “Like Miu said,” she gestures towards the monopad. “This is just a copy. If you cloned someone after you killed them, you couldn’t just say that undid their death.”

“So you want someone else to die!?” Kaede shouts at her. 

“Please, ladies,” Monokuma says. “Save it for the class trial—speaking of which, I think it’s about time we get that ball rolling!”

Kaede turns back to him. “No, this is—”

A chime goes off to echo Monokuma’s words, and Kaede uselessly shouts over it, “He’s not dead!”

Monokuma disappears in the midst of a fit of laughter, and Kaede distantly hears Kiibo say, “Was someone killed?”

Chapter End Notes

The entire time I was writing this chapter I was making "sometimes I can still hear his voice" jokes to myself. But, for the record as described, Kiibo is still officially dead, and isn't going to participate in a lot of things because of that. Also English V3 is out and that is great (even though I'm still on chapter 1)! 

Another quick announcement is that hopefully I will be able to update next week, though I might not due to having some midterms coming up. If I am unable to update, I will instead start doing something I've been meaning to do for a while now, which is go back through this story from the beginning to generally edit typos, clean up language, etc., just to make it better overall!

Trial VII

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

Maki storms away, her hair whipping after her and trailing slightly aloft from the speed she moves at. Kaede can’t help but glare after her, curling her hands into fists, purely from her own frustration. She’s very aware how illogical and rude it would be to hope someone is the killer, as no one deserves Monokuma’s executions. But if the culprit has to be someone… Kaede shakes her head to rid herself of her guilt over her own horrid thoughts, and turns back to Miu.

She shifts awkwardly on the spot, gripping tightly onto her monopad—or, Kaede, supposes, Kiibo—as he says, “There’s going to be a trial?”

Kaede exchanges a look with Miu and lets out a sigh. “Someone… destroyed your body, Kiibo, and Monokuma’s counting it as a corpse,” she says. “Even if you’re fine, we still need to figure out who did this to you.”

“Still need to fucking execute someone,” Miu mutters darkly under her breath. 

Kaede bites her lip, pausing for a moment as Kiibo says, “I… see. I am afraid I will be of little help in the trial due to, ah, my current circumstances.”

“Don’t need to solve your own fucking murder,” Miu says. “Bakamatsu’ll figure out who fucked you in the ass before you even finished installing.”

“Finished installing?” Kaede echoes. “Is Kiibo—”

Miu waves a hand. “He’s got a bunch more shit to run that takes longer to finish than some people around here if you know who I’m talking about.”

Kaede furrows her brow at Miu’s specific turn of phrase as Kiibo interjects, “I believe Miu is referring to the fact that while I am able to speak to you now, there are several more parts of myself that are still be configured. Fortunately, it seems this software is strangely compatible with my own.”

“Huh,” Kaede says. “I don’t really know a lot about computers, but that’s…” she looks up to Miu. “Actually that sounds really weird.”

She just shrugs in response. “Don’t know what to fucking tell you—I thought it was gonna be actual hell, but it fit perfectly—nice and tight, with no—”

“Anyway,” Kaede says quickly. “Kiibo, if you need to… focus on installing yourself or something, it’s okay.”

“Yeah!” Miu says, her enthusiasm surprising Kaede. “Make sure you’re at a hundred percent and all that shit!”

Kiibo seems a bit confused as well, saying, “That is my goal, so I will try. Very well then,” he smiles. “I will attempt to join the trial after I have finished. However,” his smile falters. “If there is still time to bring this up, there is one issue that is troubling me.”

Miu frowns. “What? I didn’t fuck anything up—I checked like eighty million times to make sure it was right.”

“It is the only thing that that seems to be amiss,” he adds quickly, though remaining persistent in his train of thought. “Though all other parts of my A.I. seem to be functioning correctly thus far, given their limited spaces, I can no longer hear my inner voice.”

Kaede isn’t sure how to respond to that question, and looks over him to Miu as she says, “Oh, um, is that not part of your programming, then?”

“The only thing I backed up was the A.I. itself,” Miu says. “If God or your conscience or the fucking devil on your shoulder wasn’t part of that, then it’s shot to shit.”

“I see,” Kiibo says. “That is rather unfortunate… but I suppose there is nothing that can be done.”

“Uh,” Miu’s bravado falters, and she mumbles, “S-Sorry, Kiibs… you—your inner something was really important to you, uh,” she suddenly begins to stammer, “I-I can look over your body and see if I can figure it out later! I’ll go over every part and work you all night until I find the special spot!”

Kaede winces, though Kiibo doesn’t appear to pick up the double meaning of her words, saying, “Thank you, Miu! After this trial, I’m sure you will sort everything out! I shall leave my hope with you.”

“Ah—” Miu stutters. “Y-Yeah, s-sure—I’m pretty fucking great, so, uh, I’ll help you out and shit after the stupid trial o-or whatever…”

He smiles. “Thank you, Miu. I will be counting on you then to look after me, and I will hopefully join you again later. Goodbye for now.”

“Yeah, bye, Kiibs…” she says, her cheerfulness suddenly fading away.

“Bye, Kiibo,” Kaede says. “Do your best to recover, and we’ll find out why this happened to you.”

“Thank you, Kaede,” he says. “Well, is you’ll excuse me, I will be shutting down now until I am more fully operational. Please, do your best until then.”

He smiles again at them, and then screen flickers for a second before turning off completely. Kaede blinks. “He can just turn himself off?”

Miu says, “He can do a bunch of shit—like I said, I’ll keep an eye on how he’s doing during the trial, but I don’t think he’ll need any help if I set everything up right, and,” she tosses her hair over her shoulder, “since I am the great Miu Iruma, there’s no fucking doubt that he’s good to go—no need to think twice.”

“Didn’t you say you checked a bunch of times first to make sure he was running, right?” Kaede asks.

“W-Well, you also can’t rush genius!” Miu spits back. “I mean, yeah, I could shat out better crap than you with my eyes closed, but there’s some shit you gotta finesse, you know!”

Kaede rolls her eyes, but can’t help smile. “And Kiibo’s wellbeing is one of those things you wanted to make sure you did right, isn’t it?”

Miu freezes for a moment before moving to shove her monopad back into her pocket. “Shut the fuck up,” she tosses her hair over her shoulder. “As if a frigid virgin like you knows anything.”

Kaede just shakes her head before looking the soberness of their situation fall back over her. “Anyway, while this is really good news, we still need to—”

“I know!” Miu snaps. “As if I don’t fucking know! Especially after all that crap everyone always says about finding justice, and—”

“No,” Kaede says. “I know. What we have to do next… there’s nothing just about it, not just because Kiibo’s alive, either.” She squeezes her eyes shut for a moment. “The trials have never been about justice or finding the truth—they’re just there to make us suffer. But,” she looks at Miu, trying to summon what little inspiration she has, “we still have to get through them, and I’m still going to uncover what happened here, for the good of everyone.”

Miu frowns, pulling at her hair, “I guess—long as my ass doesn’t get killed, I don’t really give a shit what you uncover…”

“Ah, well,” Kaede falters. “I guess—oh!” she suddenly springs to attention. “I just remembered, I need to go check something with Tenko before the trial—ugh, I hope there’s enough time left.”

Miu snorts. “You don’t have to fucking hold my hand on the way there. I can go to the goddamn trial myself—not like I don’t know where it is.”

“Alright then,” Kaede says, already beginning to jog away from her, “I’ll see you later then, Miu!”

Miu gives her a dull wave goodbye as Kaede starts sprinting back to the computer room, wondering just how much time she’ll have to go over what for all she knows might be the most important piece of evidence.

Tenko’s exiting the computer room with a long folded piece of paper in her hands as Kaede rounds the corner towards her. “Ah, Tenko!” she says, rushing up to her. “Did you and Tsumugi find anything?”

“Tsumugi already left,” Tenko says. “And if she found anything, she did not tell Tenko, ah,” she looks back down at the paper in her hands. “Sorry, Kaede, Tenko was kind of distracted with this when Tsumugi logged out.”

Tenko holds it out slightly to her, and Kaede leans closer to get a better look. She scans it briefly, noting the paper seems to be a list of names with a time and location written after each one. She randomly reads one aloud, choosing, “Maki Harukawa—5:56, entrance hall to salon.” She looks to Tenko. “Is this… a list of when we used the card readers?”

“Tenko thinks so,” Tenko says. “She asked the bear, and it said this information was apparently being recorded and sent somewhere within the program world. Tenko doesn’t think it would lie, so this is probably trustworthy.”

“I can look it over to see if everything roughly matches up with how I remembered it, too,” Kaede says. “And I guess we really don’t have a choice in trusting if the information was being sent somewhere else since we can’t really prove or disprove it… especially since the investigation is over.”

“Ah, right,” Tenko says. “Um, Kaede, we can talk on the way, and you’d probably know more about what happened in the program, but Tenko thinks she found one thing that was sort of strange when she was reading it over earlier.”

Kaede nods as they start walking together. “Really? What is it?”

She points to part of the list as they go, saying, “Tenko wasn’t really sure what to look for, so she just tried looking for things about Kiibo since… he’s the victim, but—”

“Oh!” Kaede says suddenly. “Tenko, I forgot to say, but Kiibo’s okay—Miu saved him.”

Tenko gasps. “She did!? Ah,” she smiles, pressing her hands with the list still in them to her heart. “Tenko is so happy Kiibo’s alright… Does this mean no one has to die now, too? No one has to be punished?”

Kaede feels her throat tighten. “Uh, no…” she looks at the ground as she walks. “When Miu told me, Monokuma appeared and announced we still had to do the trial, so,” she sighs. “Our lives are still on the line, and, if everything goes right, someone’s still going to be executed.”

“Oh…” Tenko shakes her head. “Tenko supposes Monokuma would do something like that… and one of us still at least tried to murder Kiibo.”

“They did,” Kaede says, “but,” she looks back up to Tenko, trying to halt the sheer misery creeping over her. “Anyway, what did you say you found when you were reading the list?”

“Ah,” Tenko looks to it again, eyes quickly scanning over the rows and rows of text before she points to a specific section. “Tenko doesn’t really know what everyone was doing, so this could be nothing, but she noticed that after a certain point, it looks like Kiibo stopped using his card.”

Kaede blinks. “What?”

“See, here,” Tenko says, finger underlining a Kiibo’s name in one section. “This is the last time it seemed that Kiibo used his card anywhere except for the time Tenko used it in front of Ryoma and Tsumugi.”

Kaede reads line Tenko’s pointing to aloud, “Kiibo—2:48, mansion front doors to outside… almost everyone else’s names are listed right before and after him, so I think that’s when we all left together to go to the church, but,” she frowns. “I definitely saw him using his ID later—he was with me and Miu after we split up, and I remember watching him use it to enter and exit the church.”

Tenko frowns, and shifts the list to find a different part. “Um, no,” she says as she points to a different section. “Tenko obviously wasn’t there, but you, Miu, and Kokichi went to the church.”

That catches Kaede off guard enough that she physically stops in her tracks for a moment. “What?” 

“Uh,” Tenko walks over to her, showing off part of the list. “From what Tenko read, everyone else, not including Kiibo, went back to the mansion. Um,” she shifts nervously. “Does that help things make sense?”

Kaede shakes her head. “No—if anything this just creates another mystery.” She starts walking again. “Tenko, let’s also just be quiet about this until it seems right to bring it up. I have a pretty strong feeling the culprit probably knew about this.”

Tenko nods. “Tenko will not mention it until you do Kaede.”

“Thank you,” she says. “Honestly, after talking to everyone, I think you might be the only person I can trust right now. So,” Kaede tries to give her best supportive smile. “We’ll just have to be a team—we’ll back each other up no matter what happens.”

Tenko smiles. “Tenko will do everything she can, and no matter what, Tenko will believe in you.”

And Kaede feels her smile grow more genuine. “I believe in you, too. And,” she pumps her fists, “I believe we can get through this.”

They finish the walk towards the trial grounds, exchanging words of encouragement and further going over the log for information. Tenko’s observations can only do so much, though as Kaede takes it in, she notes plainly that according to its data, she was supposedly with Miu and Kokichi for most of her time in the virtual world. And again she thinks, why does it always come back to him? 

Everyone else is already gathered by the elevator, and Miu seems to be engaged in a rather heated argument with the others. As they approach, Kaede starts to ask, “What’s going—”

“Kaede! Tenko!” Kaito shouts. “Did you hear? Kiibo’s fucking alive!”

“As alive as a robot can be!” Kokichi adds pleasantly. “Looks like Kiiboy lives to beep and boop another day—and that Miu isn’t a total waste of space!”

Miu scowls. “Shut your fucking whore mouth,” she says, jabbing a finger at him as he grins up at her. “You spent the whole investigation sucking flowerbrain’s dick, and you’re giving me shit for being useful!? I’ll have you know the great Miu Iruma—”

“Can we get this started already?” Maki says. “Miu’s given me enough of a headache already. The sooner I can stop having to hear her voice the better.”

Miu wilts, stuttering, “I-I was j-just defending myself…”

Ryoma ignores her, saying, “Have to agree—the sooner we get this over with the better.”

“Yeah,” Tsumugi says. “Our lives are still on the line, after all, so we probably shouldn’t dawdle, especially we can’t just save and reload if we need a break. Oh,” she hugs her arm, “this would be so much easier if we could just make a contract with Monokuma and rewind time, though that might only lead to more despair…”

“As I was saying,” Maki says. “My patience with listening to idiotic nonsense is already wearing dangerously thin.”

“And you’ll threaten to kill us a bunch?” Kokichi asks. “Man, I wonder what it would be like if I tried using the same terrible answer for every problem I ever had.” He grins, folding his hands behind his head. “I bet I would be as interesting and unpredictable as you, Harumaki-chan.”

She glares. “Do you want to be killed?”

And Kokichi just smiles back, her answer speaking to his victory more than anything he could say would. Kaito steps between them, saying, “Maki—calm down—I get thinking Kokichi’s a fucking brat, but now’s really not the time.”

“Right,” Kaede says. “Our personal problems with each other aren’t important right now.”

“Oh?” asks Kokichi. “Is that so? Personally, I think that’s the only thing that’s important.”

Kaede regards him warily as Ryoma asks, “And just what is that supposed to mean?”

Tenko steps forward. “Kokichi, Tenko will not tolerate anyone—especially a terrible boy like yourself—withholding information.”

“Guys,” Kaito says with a sigh. “Just ignore him for now—I’m sure he’ll say whatever cryptic bullshit’s important at the trial.”

“Aww,” Kokichi says practically beaming up at him. “I can always count on my beloved Kaito to protect me.”

Kaito rolls his eyes in response. “Shut up—I’m not—”

“No,” Maki suddenly snaps. “Why do you always take his side?”

He throws his hands in the air. “I’m not fucking taking sides—”

“You are,” Maki insists, taking a step towards him. “And for some reason you always end up supporting him, even after all he’s done, and—”

“That’s not true!” Kaito shouts. His sudden spike in volume casts a brief silence over them as everyone turns to stare with mixed looks of confusion and concern. And he falters, words catching up to his thoughts. “I mean—fuck,” he shakes his head. “Look I just… I just made a fucking mistake, and I’m dealing with it, and that’s really all anyone needs to know.” He turns to Maki and speaks only to her. “Okay, Harumaki?”

Her glare doesn’t falter as her eyes flicker over him, and her pigtails snap violently as she jerks her head away from him saying, “Fine—be a hypocrite,” as she stomps towards the elevator.

He just sighs and looks at the ground, cursing under his breath. Kokichi hums, “Trouble in paradise?”

“I think this is a little more than just that,” Tsumugi adds. “Usually conflicts in shoujo romance manga—”

“Tsumugi,” Kaede says gently. “I really don’t think now is the time.”

Miu snorts. “As if anyone gives a shit about dumb and fucking idiot’s sex life anyway.”

“Talking about this is a waste of time,” Ryoma says, pointedly walking past her to the elevator. “If anyone has anything important to say, they can do it at the trial.”

“Yep, yep!” Kokichi says cheerily, skipping after him. “I have a feeling this will be an extra fun one, too.”

Tsumugi says, “How can anyone say something like that? But, ugh,” she starts to warily follow after him, “we really should get going…”

“Right,” Kaede says with a nod before glancing back over to Kaito, still looking down. She thinks almost absently that she would reach out in reassurance if she trusted him more. But as it stands, she says, “Hey, we have to go now—if you want to talk something over with Maki, you can do it later, okay?”

He swears again as he nods. “Yeah—yeah, I fucking know.” With another sigh, he looks up finally and walks past Kaede without a glance her way. 

Alone with Tenko and Miu, the latter voices Kaede’s thoughts on their situation aloud, “What the fuck is wrong with everyone?” 

“There’s been another murder,” Tenko says. “That is what is wrong with everyone, Miu.”

“Yeah,” Kaede says, leading the way to the elevator with as much confidence as she can muster, even as she thinks is that it?


 

The ride down is quiet, and Kaede notes that with only half of the people she promised she would save remaining, the tiny room feels so, so empty.

In the trial room, Monokuma dutifully gives his explanation, his children butting in every so often to voice their surprise that their father is alive again. It all means very little to Kaede as she moves to her all too familiar podium. The entire thing feels so routine—so normal, and she sees Monokuma decorated Angie’s portrait with tiny angel wings and Kiibo’s with a perfectly uniform typeset X. 

It’s not her, and she’s decided to put faith in Tenko, and that’s where her belief ends. Before a word has even been said, Kaede rationalizes that at the very least, it’s a one in six shot of getting it right. Earlier she had realized it was a one in five guess of picking the mastermind, and as their numbers dwindle further and further, they have less people to hide behind. The more they play the game, the harder keeping their secret becomes. Of course, blindly murdering each other until they get it right is a lesson Kaede learned a long time ago.

But thinking of Rantaro makes her think of Kokichi’s warning, and she turns to him as he gets the first word in, “So first thing’s first,” he says, “the first person to find the body is always the most suspicious—so, Tenko—”

“Tenko has found almost every body so far,” Tenko says, voice firm. “She discovered Rantaro in the library, and Kirumi in the pool, and Gonta on the fourth floor.” She squeezes her eyes shut for a moment. “And now Kiibo in the computer room. The only thing that means is that Tenko has seen her friends’ corpses too many times.”

“Hey, also,” Kaito says. “Me and Harumaki were right outside the door—I mean we were talking, but we probably would’ve heard if Tenko was doing any weird crap. Plus, when we came in, she was just kinda standing around confused before the body announcement went off.”

“Doing anything when someone’s getting it on right outside doesn’t seem possible, then, huh?” Miu adds.

Kaede clears her throat and Miu’s words away with a cough. “And, Tenko was also outside the program world the whole time—if she had wanted to do anything to any of us—which she didn’t—she could have done it at a much more convenient time.”

“Oh, yeah,” Tsumugi says. “It would seem weird for the culprit to wait until witnesses are literally right outside the door to try anything, unless they had a magic notebook that could—”

“Also,” Maki says. “The Monokuma File said Kiibo suffered no external injuries, which we can probably take to mean that no one broke into his circuits from the outside.”

Kaede nods. “That sounds right, Miu,” she turns to the other girl. “You know the computer room pretty well—there aren’t any tools up there someone could use to dismantle Kiibo or remove any parts of him, right?”

“Yeah, it was fucking shit!” Miu says. “I had to get no-tits to carry him down to my lab since there was fuck all to repair him with up there.”

“And when you were examining him, were there any signs that someone had tampered with him or injured him from the outside?” Kaede asks.

Miu rolls her eyes. “If there was, I would’ve already fucking said something, whale tits.” 

Kaede sighs. “Alright—basically all that means, that whatever happened to Kiibo had nothing to do with Tenko.”

“And that means it is impossible that Tenko is the culprit,” Tenko says. “And all of that is ignoring that Tenko would never harm Kiibo in the first place.”

“Well, duh,” Kokichi says easily. “I knew that.”

Ryoma sighs. “And then you accused her because…? Did you think it would be funny to waste our time?”

Kokichi clicks his tongue. “Not a waste of time—I just think it’s really important we established that Tenko is innocent. After all,” he places a finger to his lips, “I think we need to know whose word we can trust before we move any further.”

Kaede furrows her brow. “And what is that supposed to—”

“Simple,” he says, folding his hands behind his head. “Tenko is telling the truth—so any testimonies that conflict with hers must be lies.”

Maki sighs. “Would you like to provide more logic a four year old could figure out or can we actually move on with our lives?”

“I think,” Kaede says. “That Kokichi has a point—we were all really split up during the incident, so establishing a baseline for what has to be true might be a good idea.”

“‘What has to be…’” Kaito begins to say before frowning. “Kaede, are you saying that you think some of us—other than fucking Kokichi—are lying?”

“Anyone who lies who isn’t the killer is only hurting themselves,” Tenko adds. “However… Tenko believes that might very well be the case—after what happened to Himiko—”

“Blah, blah, blah,” Kokichi says. “As if we haven’t heard that story a million times. Point is,” he beams, “I just think we need to accept the fact that maybe more than just the killer has something to hide.”

Kaito clenches his jaw. “What the fuck are you doing?” 

Kokichi smiles back at him. “Nothing, but, oh,” his smile darkens. “Did you assume I was talking about you, Kaito? Please, you know I would never betray my beloved—”

“Leave him alone,” Maki says sharply. “Kaito was with me when the murder happened—he has nothing to do with this. Questioning him would just be a waste of time.”

Kaede’s eyes dart between the three of them, not believing Maki’s declaration for a second. “Right… in that case,” she’s very aware how false her cheerfulness sounds when she asks, “Maki, would you mind telling everyone what you were doing before Kiibo’s death? I already asked Tsumugi, but she said she might remember wrong.”

Maki glares. “I was with Kaito. Tenko can confirm, and we all agreed to blindly trust her apparently.” 

“It’s not blind,” Kaede says. “We already went over all the reasons why it makes no sense for Tenko to be the culprit.”

“But she could always be hiding something else,” Ryoma says. “Isn’t that what Kokichi just said? Someone other than the killer might be keeping secrets.”

“Keeping secrets when my ass is on the line,” Miu says. “Also,” her voice raises, “whoever the fuck you are thinking about yourself when Kiibs is the one we’re here for has a lot of fucking nerve.”

“Oh,” Tsumugi presses her hands to her heart. “Miu…”

Kaede turns to her, squaring her shoulders. “That’s right. No matter what problems we have with each other, this is about Kiibo… and making sure we all live to another day.”

Ryoma fiddles with his cigarette. “So it is,” he says dully. 

Kaede frowns at him, as Tenko haltingly adds, “S-So where would be a good place to start? Tenko only waited outside, so she doesn’t know what happened in the program world…”

“Far as I get it,” Kaito says, “whatever killed Kiibo happened to him in the program—if Tenko was watching his body the whole time, it seems pretty fucking unlikely anything happened to him on the outside.”

“And that means we can rule out Kaito, myself, and Tenko as suspects,” Maki says. “Obviously none of us had anything to do with this.”

“Y-You can’t just make up a fucking alibi like that!” Miu shouts. 

“Why not?” Maki says. “It’s true—we already confirmed as much.”

“W-Well, fine!” Miu’s eyes dart around the room before landing on Kaede. “I was with boob-job the whole time—that means we have alibis, too, right Bakamatsu?”

Kaede pinches the bridge of her nose. “I guess, I mean,” she shakes her head. “Miu and I were together for basically the entire time once we entered the program.”

“Basically?” Ryoma says. “Which means…”

“When we’d go through doors,” Kaede answers simply. “There would always be a brief moment we were apart, but that’s true for everyone in the program world because of how it was built.”

“That’s true, isn’t it,” Kokichi says. “And Kiiboy’s murder would take more than a few seconds to complete.” He glances to Kaede out of the corner of his eye. “Speaking of which, just how was he killed? Doing in a robot has to be a bit trickier than slicing up a meatbag.”

“Wait,” Tenko says, frowning down at him. “You spent the entire investigation alone with Kaito, and you didn’t read the Monokuma File?”

Kaito quickly says, “No—we did, he’s just,” he coughs. “Just being an asshole or something, I guess.”

“Oooookay,” Kokichi says, turning to him. “Soooo, Kaito, how do you think Kiiboy died?”

“Haven’t we already talked about this?” he asks. “Someone fucked with him in the program world?”

“That’s kind of vague…” Tsumugi says. 

Maki rolls her eyes. “Why are we bothering questioning him? Miu did an autopsy—ask her.”

Kaede says, “Miu mostly just said that he suffered a shut down. I think the Monokuma File said it was sort of like if a person went into shock.”

“Yeah,” Miu says. “I already explained this to you, assholes—if you throw yourself off a fucking building in the program, your brain’s gonna think you just did that and freak the fuck out when you hit the ground.”

“Ah,” says Tsumugi. “So if you die in the game, you die in real life! Just like in that MMORPG that uses nerve gear! Although, that show’s really entry level…”

Kaito ignores her. “Yeah, and didn’t Miu say we could feel pain and shit, even if our avatars were indestructible?”

“And she also said we could die in the program,” Maki says. “It seems like someone decided to take advantage of that.”

Kaede bites her lip as her she glances towards Kiibo’s portrait. Above almost everything else, she still wonders why someone would possibly go after him, of all people. But her chain of thought is cut short as Ryoma says, “doesn’t all this mean that we don’t know the cause of death?”

“What?” Kaede asks.

“He was killed in the program, sure,” he says. “But how his killer went about doing that…”

Kokichi cheers. “Is a mystery!” 

“The details are,” Kaede says. “But, from what Miu’s told us, we can assume that he was probably killed… pretty normally.”

“Oh,” says Kokichi with absolute wonder. “So, so, so—was he stabbed, beaten, drowned, strangled, electro—”

“Shut up,” Ryoma snaps. 

Kokichi sniffles. “I… I was just trying to offer suggestions…”

“But,” Tenko says. “How would Kiibo’s killer even do any of those things? Didn’t Miu say she removed everything dangerous?”

“Maybe that was a lie,” Maki says.

Miu suddenly pales. “Wha—fuck—no!” she shouts. “I-I did remove everything!”

Kokichi smiles. “Did you?”

“Yes!” she yells. 

Kokichi continues to torment Miu, leveling a rapid fire volley of accusations at her, his list of possible weapons getting increasingly ridiculous as Kaede thinks. She hadn’t explored the entirety of the virtual world, and she knows Miu kept her secrets about many parts of it, but… was there anything dangerous?

(Present your Argument) 

“So, Miu!” Kokichi starts. “What did you leave in the program?”

“Nothing!” Miu shouts back. “It was emptier than your pea sized skull!”

“Were there knives, or hammers, or saws?” Kokichi lists.

Maki adds, “no one knew the virtual world better than you—you could have easily hidden something.”

“Or swords, or attack dogs, or wild bears?”

“Kiibo’s body was in the library,” Tsumugi says. “So if there was a weapon, it was probably in there…”

“Or spears, or tasers, or poison?”

“When me and Kokichi were looking around the library,” Kaito adds. “I don’t remember seeing anything dangerous in there.”

“Or maybe they just used a pillow and smothered him!”

Miu shouts, “For the last fucking time—there was nothing that could be used as a weapon! Do you think I’m an idiot!?”

Ryoma sighs. “You’re really going to ask Kokichi that question?”

(BREAK) 

“Wait,” Kaede says. “Kaito, that’s right! I remember during the investigation, it was really strange that there wasn’t anything that looked like it could have been a murder weapon in the library.”

“There wasn’t because I fucking took out all that shit!” Miu says. “Do you all get off on hearing me repeat myself?”

“Nothing in the library that could be a murder weapon,” Kokichi muses. “Is that right…”

“Of course not,” Maki says. “It doesn’t matter how many times Miu says there were no weapons—Kiibo was obviously killed using something.”

Ryoma stares at the ground, an odd expression on his face. “What if… we’re looking at this wrong? What if Kiibo wasn’t murdered?”

Kaito frowns. “What are you talking about? He was killed—”

“He could have committed suicide,” Ryoma says suddenly. 

Kaede’s mouth forms a thin, tight line. “We did talk about that possibility earlier.”

“I remember that, but,” Tsumugi says, shaking her head. “I still don’t believe that possible. The laws of robotics wouldn’t allow it.”

Kaito frowns. “The fuck are the laws of robotics?”

“Uh, well,” Kaede says, wary of Tsumugi rattling off another speech. “Basically they boil down to the idea that a robot wouldn’t purposefully harm itself.”

“And if Kiibo follows the laws of robotics then him committing suicide is plainly impossible!” Tsumugi asserts.

“No,” Miu suddenly asserts, jabbing a finger at Tsumugi. “Kiibs committing suicide is impossible because he—” she cuts her self off, and her hand curls into a fist. “He just… fucking promised me we’d do shit when we got out of here…”

Kaede turns to her, “That’s right,” she says. “I remember him saying that, and it would be odd for him to do such a thing if he was intending to die.”

“What if he discovered something?” Maki says plainly. “Something that made him want to die?”

“Huh?” Kaede says.

“Maki,” Ryoma says lowly. “What are you trying to say?”

“What…” Tenko breathes out. “What could Kiibo—what could anyone have found that would have made them want to die?”

Maki pauses before turning away from them. “The reason we went into the virtual world in the first place was to find clues about the outside world, right? So maybe Kiibo found something…”

“The clue to the outside world would make Kiibo kill himself?” Tenko asks, near horrified.

“N-No,” Miu says, voice shaking. “That’s bullshit—that has to be bullshit! H-Hey! Titless, why the fuck are you lying to me about Kiibo!?”

“Actually, Miu,” Kaede says. “I think the real question is why does Maki sound so sure about that.”

Kaito looks at her, expression unreadable. “Hey, Harumaki, if you know something you can tell us, okay? We know you’re not the culprit.”

“Do we know that?” Kokichi asks darkly. “Because Maki was acting very strangely in the program world before Kiiboy’s murder, right, Tsumugi?”

“Ah,” Tsumugi shoots a nervous look towards Maki. “That is true… Maki and I were supposed to investigate together, and then she suddenly left.”

“And that’s why you and Kiibo came down to the basement later,” Ryoma says. “It was just the two of you, and you were trying to meet up with everyone.”

Tenko says, “Tenko doesn’t know what Maki was doing in the program, but she just logged out though, right?”

“She left Tsumugi alone without a word to suddenly leave the program for no reason,” says Kokichi. “When you put it like that, Maki seems super-duper innocent, huh?”

“But she didn’t do anything,” Kaito says. “She logged out, and we spent the whole time talking—she has a fucking alibi, end of story.”

Tenko nods, though seems rather unsure of herself as she says, “Kiibo was killed inside the virtual world, and Maki was definitely outside of it when that happened, so she has to be innocent…”

“No,” Kokichi says. “Not necessarily.”

“What are you talking about?” Maki asks darkly. “I was outside the pro—”

“And Kiiboy was in, but,” his smile twists into something cruel. “If you set a trap inside the program, you could kill him while you were on the outside?”

“Trap?” Kaede echoes.

Kaito shakes his head. “No—no that’s not possible. Harumaki was with us the whole—”

“She wasn’t,” Ryoma says. “She stayed back when we went to the roof, and Kokichi went outside.” 

Tenko blinks, and parrots perhaps the oddest part of that statement to Kaede. “Kokichi went outside?”

“I did!” he responds happily. “I went to go explore!”

Again Tenko says, “Kokichi went outside when everyone else went to the roof…” she furrows her brow. “Uh—um, K-Kaede told Tenko this happened pretty early on when everyone entered the program…”

Kaede raises an eyebrow, all too aware she’s lying, as she backs up her story, “That’s right—is there something wrong with that, though?”

Tenko frowns again, looking down in confusion as she says, “Did Kokichi actually go outside?”

Kokichi looks up at her, mild curiosity on his face before he says, “You’re making an interesting point, Tenko, but we should talk about that later—now’s not the time.”

“What the fuck is that supposed to mean?” Miu asks.

“It means, now’s the time to grill Maki until she confesses!” he says. “Duh!”

“I didn’t kill Kiibo,” Maki says dully. “Being alone for five seconds doesn’t change that.”

“That’s right,” Kaito says. “And I’ll say it a hundred times if I have to—the fact that she was outside of the program has nothing to do with Kiibo! I believe in Harumaki, and I believe she would never just try to kill someone to escape.”

Maki gives him an odd look. “That’s right,” she says, even as her tone holds almost no confidence in her words. “I wouldn’t do something like that.”

“Then what were you doing outside of the program?” Miu asks. “Did you log out just to get freaky with spacecase?”

Maki jerks her head towards her. “Do you want me to kill you?”

Miu retreats, as Kaede bites her lip, going over the possibilities before her. 

(Present your Argument) 

“Tenko can confirm that Maki was logged out of the program when Kiibo died,” Tenko says. “However, she did not tell Tenko why…”

“She did it on purpose,” Kokichi adds. “So it wasn’t a weird, freak thing like what happened with Kaito.” His face darkens. “It was a premeditated act to carry out her evil plan.”

Maki rolls her eyes. “I didn’t have an ‘evil plan.’”

“Then you can tell us what you were doing,” Kokichi insists. “If you have nothing to hide, you’ll tell us, right Harumaki-chan?”

“Kokichi,” Kaito says. “Leave her alone—she told me what she was doing, and it’s nothing strange.”

“Then you tell us what it was, dickhead!” Miu says.

Tenko adds in a softer voice, “Kaito didn’t tell Tenko what he was doing outside the program either…”

(BREAK) 

“Kaito,” Kaede says. “You just said Maki told you why she logged out, right?”

He frowns. “Yeah… it’s what we were talking about, but it’s really not a prob—”

“Then you knew she was trying to kill Kokichi,” Kaede says.

A harsh silence falls over the room, and Kaito just stares at her, struck dumb. 

His speechlessness is enough to confirm her suspicious, and Kaede presses forward. “Tenko told me that she sensed a killing intent coming from Maki when she logged out, and that it was directed towards Kokichi.”

“Tenko doesn’t know anything,” Maki snaps. “There’s no reason to believe—”

“She’s the only person I can believe,” Kaede says. “And we agreed we’d trust in her word.”

Maki says, “She’s an overly emotional idiot who—”

“Tenko knows what she felt,” she says coldly. “Maybe her emotions haven’t been as clear lately, but she knows what happened, and—and,” her voice twists into something angry, “and how dare you tell Tenko that she doesn’t know her own feelings.”

“I’d put faith in Tenko’s ability to read emotions before almost anything else,” Kaede says. “And if she says that she sensed you were attempting to kill Kokichi, then I believe her.”

“And that is what Tenko felt,” Tenko says. “There is no doubt.”

“Well, obviously I didn’t kill Kokichi,” Maki spits back. “So you can stop with your meaningless deductions. If you think you’re cornering me into anything, you’re delusional.”

“Ah, wait,” Tsumugi says, shooting increasingly fearful glances towards Maki. “I have a question—if Maki left the program world because she intended to… to kill Kokichi, does that mean she was planning to fight Tenko?”

Kokichi hums, seemingly undisturbed by the revelations floating around him as he rocks on his heels. “Oooh, that would be something—a duel between Maki and Tenko, especially since Maki herself said it would be silly to try such a thing.”

“She did,” Ryoma says. “Which I suppose is just more evidence that she was thinking about it from the get-go. If it matters,” he fiddles with his cigarette, staring intently at it rather than anyone hanging on his words, “Tenko’s been skipping meals lately, meaning she’s been undernourished and low on energy—if Maki was planning to fight her, now would be the best time.”

Kaito throws his hands on the air. “What kind of bullshit deduction is that!? There’s no way Harumaki was tracking something like that! And,” he slams his hands down on the front of his podium. “In case you’ve all fucking forgotten, the victim is Kiibo—maybe Harumaki was thinking about doing something for, like, five seconds, but that doesn’t mean she’s the killer.”

Kaede looks at him and finds herself feeling frustrated over everything else. “So you don’t deny that she was planning to kill. Is that what you two were talking about?”

“That would explain why they did not want Tenko to hear,” Tenko adds. “And also… it is a possible explanation for why Kaito agreed to protect Kokichi.”

Kokichi’s smile isn’t bright or childish like the one Kaede has seen him wear in the face of horror so many times before. Instead, if Kaede didn’t know better, she’d almost label it as melancholy or, perhaps, remorseful. He says, “That certainly is one possibility. Kaito protected me to protect Maki. It’s almost funny how much Maki needs to be saved from herself. I wonder what would happen if she didn’t have Kaito around to tell her what to do.”

Maki gives him a look of pure death. “I can still kill you, you know.”

He shrugs. “But you won’t as long as Kaito’s around. Because what happened,” he smiles, “is that Maki logged out of the program to come after me, but stopped when she saw Kaito who scolded her and hit her on the nose with a newspaper until she calmed down. The end!”

“Ha!” Miu suddenly blurts out. “Guess Whore-ukawa really is spacecase’s bitch!”

“And I can kill you, too,” Maki says darkly.

“Eeeeey!” Miu shrieks. “I-I w-was just—”

“Shutting up,” Maki says. “If you want to keep all of your limbs, that is.”

“And that’s the end of this!” Kaito shouts. “Harumaki almost did something, but she didn’t, and she’s not fucking responsible for what happened!” 

Kaede stares hard at him, and she asks as evenly as she can, “Why did she try to kill Kokichi? You know the answer to that, too, don’t you?”

Kaito looks at her, clenching his jaw. He pauses too long, before finally saying, “reason doesn’t matter. And…” his eyes dart to Maki and then pointedly away again. “And she promised not to try anything again, so none of this matters.”

“There’s one problem I have with just dismissing Maki as suspicious,” Ryoma says. 

Kaito shakes his head, muttering under his breath. “Fucking hell… She didn’t do it…”

“Maki had the keycard to access the motive,” Ryoma says plainly. “Far as we know, she’s the only one who could have seen it. Even if she wasn’t acting sketchy, that alone should be enough to make her a suspect.”

“That is true,” Kaede says. “Maki did—”

“No,” Maki answers. “The motive doesn’t matter.”

“Someone’s a liar,” Kokichi says in a sing-song voice. “So, real question: when did you look at the motive? Ooh, ooh! And how super cool was it that it caused you to murder Kiiboy in cold blood?”

She scowls. “The motive is stupid, and I never even saw Kiibo in the simulation after we split up.” She crosses her arms. “My brief intentions to end your miserable existence and stop this game had nothing to do with Kiibo’s murder.”

Kaede frowns. “‘Stop this game?’ Maki… do you think Kokichi is—”

Kaito cuts in, “He’s not, and it doesn’t matter. So let’s just fucking talk about something else.”

Kaede turns to him as she fiddles with her hat. Attempting to convince him to stop protecting Maki is likely a lost cause, especially since the girl in question being a generally suspicious person and Kaede’s own distaste for her are rather removed from being concrete evidence. And, of course, how Kiibo factors into anything described is far, far out of reach of any logic Kaede finds herself able to throw together at the moment.

Kaito’s still staring at her, eyes silently pleading, as Kaede finally says, “Fine—there’s more to discuss anyway. So,” she sighs and turns back to face the group as a whole. “Does anyone else have a question—it might jumpstart a new conversation.” 

“Yeah, I’ve fucking got a question,” Miu says. “The hell does flat-chest mcstabby get off on saying Kiibs found something that would have made him commit suicide?”

“Ah, that’s right!” Tsumugi says. “Earlier, Maki was really confident when she brought up that possibility.”

Maki shakes her head. “It was simply a theory—don’t put too much stock into it.”

“We should still think about it,” Ryoma says with a sigh. “And another thing to consider: the whole damn reason we went into the virtual world.”

“The clues about the outside world, and something that would cause Kiibo to take his own life,” Kaede says. “Do you think there’s a connection between those two things, too, Ryoma?”

To the ground he says, “Just saying no one here’s spoken up about finding what we were looking for, and also no one else ended up dead while everyone had an alibi.” He shrugs. “Maybe my logic’s out of order, but it just makes sense to me.”

Though Ryoma isn’t fighting particularly hard for his argument, Kaede finds herself furrowing her brow as she thinks over his words and all the testimonies she had heard before. 

(Present your Argument) 

“In the program,” Tsumugi says hesitantly. “Did Kiibo find the secret of the outside world? And then… did he decide he didn’t want to live anymore…”

“Bullshit!” Miu shouts. “Kiibs’s a team player—he woulda fucking said something if he found it!”

“Would anyone here keep something that important secret?” Kaito asks. “It’s the whole fucking reason we went into Miu’s shitty world in the first place.”

Kokichi chirps, “I dunno—would anyone here possibly do something that devious?”

“Question fucking retracted,” Kaito says completely deadpan.

“But even if someone did find it,” Tsumugi says. “What were we even looking for? Do we have any idea what the clue to the outside world even is?”

“We should ask Maki!” Kokichi says. “She found it, after all! Right before she killed Kiiboy, too!”

“Is there a rule against committing murder at a class trial?” Maki asks.

Kaito sounds almost tired as he says, “No one’s fucking killing anyone…”

(BREAK) 

“No, Tsumugi,” Kaede says. “I think we did find the clue to the outside world earlier. Do you remember? There was a Flashback Light in the basement, though it seemed like it had already been used when we tried to turn it on.”

“Ah, that’s right,” Tsumugi says. “But I guess that means that someone did really just find it and keep it a secret, though I don’t know why anyone would do that…”

“Could be what Maki was talking about earlier,” Ryoma says. “Maybe it’s a truth we’re better off not knowing.”

Kaede fiddles with the brim of her hat, choosing her words carefully before saying, “Even if that is the case—which I hope it’s not—this might be a pretty important clue to discover what happened to Kiibo, especially since it’s clear someone used it but is keeping quiet.”

Miu snaps her fingers. “So all we need to do is figure out who used the Fleshback Light, and then vote for their ass!”

Ryoma shrugs. “Makes sense to me.”

“Uh—hey, wait,” Kaito says suddenly. “I’m not gonna try and say that the Flashback Light or whatever isn’t related, but couldn’t this be some of that shit Kokichi was talking about earlier? Like people just lying or hiding crap for different reasons?”

Tenko voices aloud the accusation rolling through Kaede’s head. “Kaito… that sounds very suspicious. Did you—”

“No,” he says. “I’m just thinking about it—can’t a guy fucking throw out theories without being accused of murder?”

“Not at a class trial, my dear Kaito,” Kokichi answers. “Here, everything you say can and should be used against you because one of us isn’t trying to find the culprit, or perhaps,” his smile stretches to almost split his face in half, “in this case, more than one of us.”

“More than one of us?” Kaede echoes. “Kokichi, you’re saying there’s someone else here besides the killer who wants us to get it wrong?”

He presses a finger to his lips. “Of course,” he answers. “Would I lie to you guys?”

“You always say that right before lying,” Maki says. “And,” like a light switch, her face flickers from banal to something predatory. “Why don’t you tell us exactly what your alibi is since you seem so intent on talking down to us?”

Kokichi taps a finger to his chin. “Me? Why do I need an alibi? I’m as innocent as can be.”

“That’s not an answer…” Tsumugi mumbles.

“As far as Tenko understands it from what Kaede told her,” she says. “After Kaito’s strange log out, Kokichi was left alone in the program world.”

“So I was!” he answers cheerily before suddenly descending into sniffles. “Seeing my beloved Kaito just vanish before my eyes… whoever made him disappear is so mean!”

Ryoma says, “Can’t say when Kaito left, but Kokichi did come back out of the library alone.” He lowers his hat. “That also means he was at the scene of the crime by himself—and we don’t know how long for.”

“Oh, I get it,” Miu snarls, jabbing a finger in Kokichi’s direction. “After closet case fucked off, that little abortion sabotaged the library to kill Kiibo!”

“Wait, hey,” Kaito cuts in. “Just saying Kokichi sabotaged some crap is pretty fucking vague, right?”

Maki glares. “Why are you defending him?”

“That’s a good question, Maki!” Kokichi cheers. “Why is Kaito helping me out? Could it be that he believes in—”

“Yes,” Kaito says suddenly. 

His answer manages to catch both of them off guard, and Kokichi and Maki ask, “What?” at the same time.

Kaede says, “Kaito, what do you mean? Do you trust Kokichi?”

“I thought you two wanted to rip each other’s heads off?” Miu says. “D-Did one night of passion really turn things around that much!?”

Kaito lets out a sigh as he runs a hand through his hair. Before anything else, he breathes out, “Shut up, Miu.”

“H-Hey! I only—”

“Miu,” Kokichi says sweetly. “Kaito asked you to keep your filthy mouth shut, okay?”

She falters again and begins to mumble more excuses to herself as Maki says, “Kaito—you’re going to explain yourself to me right now.”

Kaito pauses again before shaking his head. “Don’t get me wrong—Kokichi’s still a fucking asshole, but… I’ve decided he’s not our enemy, and I’m gonna believe in him. And, if that screws us over, then it’s no one’s fault but my own, but right now it’s the only thing I can do. So,” he looks up with something close to renewed determination. “For now, I’m gonna believe.”

And perhaps the strangest thing is how unsurprised Kokichi suddenly seems. “Can’t say I ever remember a time when someone decided to say something like that to a liar like me, but,” he grins. “I guess it makes sense given Kaito’s position. And,” he flickers back to his cheery, sing-song voice, “It looks like my Kaito really is a standup kinda guy! At least, when he’s able to stand up that is.”

Maki’s hands tighten into fists. “If you’re blackmailing him, I will kill you right now.”

“Harumaki, it’s fine,” Kaito says trying to smile at her. “I wouldn’t be much of a man if I couldn’t handle my own mistakes.”

Nothing about his words seem console her, and Maki responds in the same tight voice. “Why are you acting this way?”

“Well, Harumaki-chan,” Kokichi says. “You and Kaito are pretty good friends, and not even the best of friends tell each other every—”

“This is a class trial,” Ryoma intones coldly. “If we need to interrogate Kaito, we will.”

“And we don’t,” Maki says. “So this conversation is over.”

Kaede straightens her shoulders as she prepares to cut in. “Actually, it’s not because Kaito and Kokichi are both still really suspicious.”

Kaito frowns. “Kaede, if you’re saying that because I disappeared or whatever, I already told you I have no idea why the fuck that happened.”

“And I believe that,” she says. “Tenko basically confirmed as much for me during the investigation.”

“That is true,” Tenko says. “When Tenko went to help Kaito, he seemed to almost be in a panic about getting back into the program. Tenko does not think he was just acting.”

“Because I had no idea what the fuck was going on!” he announces. “If anything that just makes me less suspicious, doesn’t it?”

Tsumugi quietly adds, “I… don’t think that makes sense…”

“But that’s not my point,” Kaede says. “My point is that you and Kokichi were the only people in the library before Kiibo arrived and was killed.”

“That’s just a coincidence,” Kaito says. “And Kaede—what the hell is with this?” There’s something almost hurt in his expression that makes Kaede’s throat tighten even as she refuses to back down. “Do you… do you really think I did it?”

“You don’t have to answer any of her questions,” Maki says. “You don’t need to tell anyone anything.”

“No,” he says. “If Kaede doubts me she should clear her doubts, but, fuck…” 

Kaede does let her gaze falter to stare at a place slightly to the side of his face then. “There’s really just one thing that’s been bothering me, but… as soon as I get an answer to that, I can decide for sure whether or not to suspect you. I,” she hugs her arm. “I am sorry for this, Kaito, I do want to believe in you, but…” and Kaede stops herself from saying just how little she trusts perhaps the first person to have faith in her since Shuichi died. 

But for as nice and supportive as Kaito has been since the very beginning, Kaede can’t look at him without doubt. 

Then Kokichi suddenly cuts through her thoughts, saying, “Kaito’s not a killer, but let’s hear what Kaede has to say. I have a feeling it will be important as we move forward towards a real suspect.”

Miu snorts. “Sticking up for your fuck buddy?”

Kokichi practically twirls around. “Of course! If Kaito believes in me, then I’ll believe in him—I’m all about paying people back, you know. Soooo,” he turns to Kaede. “Give me your best shot, Kaede!”

Ryoma says, “Isn’t Kaito the one who should be arguing?” as the room then devolves into chatter, and Kaede knows that now is the time to finally catch someone in their lie.

(Present your Argument) 

“I’m a suspect,” Kaito says. “Because I was in the library with Kokichi before the murder, right?”

“That means Kokichi’s a suspect, too,” Maki adds. 

Miu shouts, “You fucking tried to kill the shota—sit your ass down!”

“We’re suspect buddies because no one else was in the library before Kiiboy,” Kokichi says. “Buuut, neither of us were there when he actually died, soooo…”

“Tenko thinks maybe one of them could have set a trap or something,” she says. “But it’s hard to believe two people—even if it’s two boys—would work together to kill someone.”

“The two of them were alone for a while,” Ryoma says. “So if that is what happened, they had the time and opportunity to do it.”

“Yeah, well,” Kaito says. “We didn’t do anything in the library besides talk and look for clues or whatever.”

Tsumugi adds, “I did find the Flashback Light in the room next to the library, so… I actually don’t know if that supports if they’re innocent or not.”

Kokichi gasps. “The Flashback Light was right in the next room!? Aw, boo! And we spent so long looking for it, too!”

Tenko scoffs. “Boys might be terrible at paying attention, but were you even listening? We already discussed that!”

“Ooh,” he says. “So we did!”

(BREAK) 

Kaede takes a deep breath. “Kaito—you said you and Kokichi didn’t do anything in the library besides talk, right?”

“Yeah,” he answers. “I told you that during the investigation, too, didn’t I?”

“You did,” she says. “And it bothered me then because… it just doesn’t match with the scene of the crime.”

Kaito frowns, and Kaede swears she sees him start to sweat. “Okay, so maybe the room was a little messed up—that’s just what you do when you’re looking for shit, right?”

Ryoma says, “It looked like there had been a fight.”

“Then Kiibo fought with his killer,” Maki snaps. “That’s the most obvious—”

“Kiibo was alone in the library for seconds at most,” Kaede says. “Ryoma, Kokichi, and Tsumugi can all confirm that.”

“That’s right,” Tsumugi says. “Ryoma followed after him, but he came back very shortly afterwards… it probably wouldn’t have been enough time to have a fight, especially in a place so far away from the body.”

Maki spits, “Kiibo wasn’t even there.” She turns her glare on Kaede. “Even if there was a fight, it has nothing to do with the murder—all of this is irrelevant.”

“That is true…” Tenko says. “If Kiibo was not there, then what would they have been doing to make the crime scene look like there had been a fight?”

Miu cackles, “Well I can tell you what they weren’t doing.”

Kokichi just stares blankly for a moment before folding his arms behind his head. “You know, I actually think Maki is right. None of this is really important.”

“I would like to believe that,” Kaede says. “But the fact that it happened in the room where Kiibo was attacked just can’t be a coincidence.”

“Bzzt!” Kokichi says. “Wrong! It is just a coincidence—now back to Kiiboy—”

“I know you’re just going to lie,” Kaede says. “But there’s obviously a secret here, and if you want me to drop it, I’m going to have to hear it from Kaito. So,” she turns to Kaito to see him gripping the front of his podium and looking at the ground. “I don’t want to think you’d hurt Kiibo, but you have to tell me now why you’ve been acting the way you have. What happened in the library and why did—”

And Kaito’s head snaps up as he says, “I tried to kill Kokichi,” so fast Kaede thinks she dreamed the words for a second.

Absolute silence falls over the room, and Kaede can only stare at him in shock.

Kaito lets out a shaky breath as everyone collectively fails to take in his confession. Kaede barely hears Kokichi say very softly, and mostly to himself, “you didn’t need to tell them.”

But he keeps going, showing Kaede the truth she had been pushing so hard for. “It was fucking stupid, and I barely did anything, and I regretted it immediately, and it ended with Kokichi fucking feeling sorry for me,” he says, voice labored with deep a self-hatred Kaede never could have imagined him possessing. “The only thing that happened is I knocked some books off the shelf like an idiot and shoved Kokichi against a different shelf before he talked me down…”

Kaede shakes her head, trying to possibly process what she’s hearing. “Is—is that tru—”

“Why?” Maki suddenly asks. “Why are you telling them anything?”

Kaito blinks at her. “Harumaki, wha—”

“Just shut up,” she says. “Just shut up and stop making things worse for yourself.”

“Harumaki,” Kaito lets out a humorless laugh. “The hell are you trying to protect a hypocrite like me for? After all the crap I said to you, you should be more pissed off at me than anyone else.”

Maki stares hard at him for a moment, before turning away sharply. Kaede watches her then turns to Kokichi only a trial stand away to see him just staring forward almost vacantly. 

Kaede swallows before she decides to ask her own question, “But why? Why would you do something like that?”

He goes silent again, and Kaede thinks he isn’t going to answer at all when he finally says, “I thought… I thought he was the mastermind. After everything Harumaki said, and everything we talked about I felt I had to, but… I still couldn’t go through with it.” 

Their conversations that had stretched on and on about saving everyone run through Kaede’s head as she just stares at him, and the question did I talk someone into murder? burns bright and painfully in her mind.

Then Kokichi says coldly, “Kaito’s not a killer. And none of this,” he looks directly at Kaede. “Has anything to do with Kiiboy’s death.”

Beside him, Tenko hesitantly asks, “H-How can you be so certain?”

“Because Kiiboy barely has anything to do with Kiiboy’s death,” Kokichi answers plainly. “Because the real truth behind this case is that almost everyone here is capable of murder.”

Chapter End Notes

And chapter 4 trial has begun! I want to take a moment also here to give a huge thanks to everyone who has been commenting and say that even if I don't reply to every comment (especially lately since I've been kinda pressed for time between school work and writing this fic, haha) know that I read and adore every single one! You guys are the greatest!

Trial VIII

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

Kokichi’s words seem to almost cast a spell over them. Or perhaps it’s Kaito’s confession or Maki’s seething rage ready to bite the head off of anyone who says another word against them.

No matter the cause, however, Kaede finds herself gripping the edges of her podium as the implications of everything she strove to unveil comes rushing up to her. Before his death, Shuichi had told her why he was so afraid of the truth—why he had allowed himself to die rather than facing it again. Kaede had understood his fears only from a distance, but now they surround her, asking if she’s proud of herself and everything she’s accomplished by dragging out someone’s secrets into the light.

She’s too caught up in thinking how all of this, everything about this entire case, about the entire game, is her fault to say anything.

Then Miu shouts, “As if you fucking know anything!”

Kaede snaps her head up to see Miu practically trembling with anger on the other side of the room. “Miu?”

“Hmm?” Kokichi says, sparing Miu a glance. “Did you say something?”

“I said shut the fuck up!” she screams. “I said—” she leans forward over her podium, thrusting a finger in his direction, absolute fury in her eyes, “That you don’t fucking know anything about Kiibo, you miserable little prick!”

“Ah, Miu,” Tsumugi says. “Do you know something about Kiibo’s death?”

She scowls and casts a pointed glare over Kokichi, Maki, and Kaito in turn before huffing and crossing her arms. “I know the three stooges apparently all have egos bigger than my tits if they’re trying to make Kiibs fucking dying about themselves.”

“You’re saying their testimonies aren’t important?” Ryoma questions.

“I’m saying,” Miu begins. “I don’t fucking feel like taking the time to throw the twunk-wannabe a pity party when someone here tried to kill Kiibo.” She tosses her hair over her shoulder. “I get that you’re all brainless enough to buy into the crap horseshit says about Kiibs not counting as a person, but if you think he didn’t matter at all, then, then—” she gestures wildly, obviously trying to think of an appropriate threat, “Then I’ll fucking lick you until you cry!”

“Um,” Tsumugi says. “That would be… pretty gross…”

Tenko says, “Tenko does not know what Kokichi truly meant, but… Tenko also believes that acting like Kiibo did not matter to fight amongst each other…” she shakes her head. “Tenko is tired of people saying her friends’ deaths don’t matter, and she refuses to let it happen to anyone else!”

Kokichi raises an eyebrow at her, contemplating the situation rather distantly as he says, “Your platitude are nice and all, and, well,” he grins, folding his arms behind his head. “If you want to ignore my help and go off on the wrong track, who am I to stop you? Soooo,” he beams, “have lots of fun!”

“I thought I told you to shut your fucking mouth!” Miu shouts. “The next time you even think about saying Kiibs was just a useless robot, and everything’s just about your threesome fuckbuddies, I’m gonna stomp over there and kick your fucking teeth in!”

Kokichi starts sniffling. “Why are you being so mean to me? I already said you could just do whatever you want… and I’ve already been through so much today with people trying to kill me, a-and, and,” his sniffling escalates into ear shatteringly loud sobs, “Waahhhh! Miu’s a bully!!!”

“Shut up,” Maki snaps.

Yet at her words, Kaito sighs and returns to staring at the ground, seemingly too ashamed of himself to argue. To the floor he says, “But… Miu’s got a fucking point—I did a lot of stupid shit, but this isn’t about me or Harumaki or Kokichi—”

“Kokichi could still be the culprit,” Maki says sharply.

“Oooh,” Kokichi says, suddenly cheerful again. “Could I?”

“Um,” Tsumugi says. “Why do you sound excited about that?”

Kaito says, “Kokichi’s not the culprit.” He runs a hand over his face. “Haven’t we already been over this?”

“No,” Ryoma says. “If anything, someone’s been steering us away from it.” He shakes his head. “Guess it makes sense why Kaito’s been protecting him now though.”

Miu points an accusatory finger at him. “You were gonna try and guilt us into the wrong vote just so your fucking boytoy could get away with murdering Kiibs!?”

Kaito rolls his eyes. “I take it back—Miu doesn’t know what the fuck she’s talking about.”

“Then allow me to clarify,” Maki says. “Kaito’s not the culprit—that much is obvious, but Kokichi’s still suspicious since he was in the library by himself after Kaito got logged out.”

“Harumaki,” Kaito says, sounding almost completely exhausted. “I get why you’re accusing him, but just trust me, okay?” he sighs again. “It’s not Kokichi—he talks a lot of shit, but he’d never actually do anything.”

“You have any proof of that?” Ryoma asks. “Or is this just a hunch?”

“Neither,” he says. “Maybe I didn’t investigate so I don’t have evidence, but I already said I believe in Kokichi, and after the shit I pulled, I’m not going to just fucking go back on that.”

“So it is out of guilt,” Tenko says softly, eyes not so subtly darting down to Kokichi standing vacantly beside her. “Kaito—”

“Don’t call me an idiot and don’t fucking tell me I’m wrong,” Kaito snaps. “I get it if you guys can’t trust me, but I’m not backing down on this.”

Kaede frowns. Kokichi and Maki are both silent, and she knows that if they possibly want to move the conversation forward, it has to be her. “Then let’s stop just accusing each other,” Kaede says, “and actually try and figure out one of the puzzles surrounding Kiibo’s death.”

Her suggestion is briefly meant with silence—though not a hostile one—before Ryoma says, “and which puzzle do you suggest we start with?”

“Um, Kaede,” Tenko says. “If you do not mind, Tenko has a question that’s been bothering her for a while.”

Kaede nods, fairly certain Tenko is one of the few people who will not immediately turn the conversation back to finger pointing. “Alright, what is it?”

“Well,” she says, “We’ve talked a lot about how Kaito was strangely logged out of the program world, but Tenko doesn’t think we’ve actually established how that happened.” She bites her lip. “Tenko just thinks it’s very strange because she didn’t see anything physically happen to him on the outside beforehand.”

“That’s right,” Tsumugi says. “I’d actually like to know the answer to that as well. Maybe his synchronization score was so low that the program wouldn’t respond to him at all.”

“I don’t know about that,” Kaede says. “But this does seem like a good place to start.”

Kaito rubs the back of his head. “Yeah—hate to say this, ‘cause I wanna know what the fuck happened, but there’s not much I can tell you that we haven’t gone over already in… detail, I guess.”

Kokichi finally speaks up saying, “Me and Kaito were chatting, and then a shiny circle appeared around his feet like when you log out at the phone.”

“But can we really trust either of you?” Ryoma says. “After everything we’ve talked about, it’s pretty safe to say they could just be lying for each other—maybe Kaito did it on purpose.”

Tenko frowns. “Tenko doubts it—Kaito was pretty panicked, and also Tenko doesn’t think he would even know enough about computers to do something like that.”

“Hey!” Kaito shouts. “I know shit about technology and crap! Just not Miu’s stupid program!”

“I’m pretty sure it was someone else that caused Kaito to get logged out,” Kaede says. “And I think I have a theory about what happened, too, and if I’m right about this, it should hopefully clear him of all suspicion.”

“Then get on with it,” Maki says. “Are you trying to impress us by dragging everything out?”

Kaito says, “Harumaki—let her talk. After all,” he laughs humorlessly. “I’ve got nothing left to hide.”

Maki pauses before saying to Kaede, “Fine—just don’t screw it up, Kaede.”

Kaede frowns as she fiddles with the brim of Shuichi’s hat. “I don’t intend to, Maki—all I want is to find the truth behind this case and end things as soon as possible.”

“Then hurry up already if you’re so sure you have the answer,” Maki says.

Kaede barely resists rolling her eyes as she takes a breath instead to center herself and listen to the others talking around her.

(Present your Argument) 

“Tenko still isn’t sure,” Tenko says, “why Kaito was logged out of the program world.”

“Maybe there was a glitch,” Maki says. “It was just a coincidence.”

“But the timing was strange,” Ryoma says. “Kaito logged out right before Maki, right? There’s a chance they were planning something together.”

“Nope!” Kokichi says. “No chance!”

Tsumugi adds, “I was in the entrance hall after Maki logged out, and I didn’t see anyone go past. Ryoma and Kokichi were also down in the basement, so I plainly doubt that Kaito could have just walked to the phone.”

“And also the fact that I keep saying that I never fucking went to the salon,” Kaito says.

“W-Well,” Miu says. “The phone’s the only fucking way out of the program, so obviously dickless had to have used it to get out! A-And that is the only possibility!”

Kokichi stage whispers, “Kaede, someone’s lying!”

“M-Maybe he hacked the system from the inside!” Miu says quickly. “O-Obviously it had to be something like that!”

“Geeze,” Kokichi says. “I wonder what it could be…”

(BREAK) 

Miu’s already sweating when Kaede pinches the bridge of her nose and says, “Miu, you already told me yourself that you can veto people logging out of the program world from inside of it. You’re going to have to give me a very good explanation if you want me to believe you really have no idea what happened.”

“W-Well,” Miu stutters. “S-See—sh-shit’s fucking complicated, y’know?”

Kaito glares at her. “So it was you! What the fuck, Miu?!”

Maki sighs. “Of course—it’s so obvious.”

“Huh?” Kokichi says. “If it was so obvious, why didn’t you say so earlier, Harumaki-chan?”

She scowls, her eyes practically glowing. “I see—you and Miu want to die, is that it?”

Tenko speaks up, “Tenko thinks we should let Miu explain herself before we move on to discuss anything else.”

“I’d like to hear her reasons, too,” Ryoma says. “And also how she even did something like that.”

Miu’s eyes dart between her accusers, her earlier, angry, confidence, fading fast. “W-What are you virgins talking about? I-I never said any of that crap! Whatever shit Bakamatsu’s saying is obviously as fake as her tits!”

“That’s the argument you’re going with?” Tsumugi asks. “But why would Kaede lie?”

“I don’t fucking know!” Miu shouts, throwing her hands in the air. “Maybe she’s the killer!”

Kaede glares. “Miu, we were together literally the entire time—it’s impossible for me to be the killer.”

“A-And that means it’s also impossible for me to have done any of the crap you’re accusing me of!” she shouts back.

“I’ve had enough of this nonsense,” Maki says. “I think it’s safe to say Miu is somehow responsible for logging Kaito out of the program, but I also doubt she’s the killer—does anyone here actually think Miu, of all people, could convincingly lie long enough to last in a trial without breaking down?”

Tenko adds, “Tenko also does not believe that Miu would harm Kiibo—perhaps it is naïve, but Tenko believes that alone is enough to dismiss her of suspicion.”

Kaito sighs. “Gotta agree with that. I mean, I think Miu’d try shit, but she’d probably fuck it up—”

“Hey!” Miu shouts. “Fuck you! I could totally kill a bitch if I wanted to! N-Not that I did!”

“—and I doubt she’d do anything to Kiibo,” he finishes. “‘Specially after her whole speech earlier about how special he is.”

Kaede furrows her brow. “Alright, but even if Miu’s not the culprit, she’s still suspicious if she purposefully logged someone out. I noticed that when we were together it seemed like Miu kept fiddling with something in her pocket—if she had the ability to log someone out remotely, I think she probably did it one of those times.”

“Hmm,” Kokichi says. “That sounds pretty right to me. Soooo, what do you think Miu? Your lies are usually pretty funny, so you can tell a few more of them if you want.”

“Or she could just cut to the point,” Maki says. “Miu,” she turns to her, “Answer. Now.”

Under Maki’s icy stare, Miu squirms and then practically bursts as she shouts, “O-Okay fine! Fucking fine! M-Maybe I logged the purple dildo out of the program! B-But that’s the only thing I did, right Bakamatsu? Never left your fucking side the whole time!”

Kaede frowns. “I mean, that is true, but why would you do something like logging someone out in the first place?”

“Seriously!” Kaito shouts. “And why the fuck did you do it to me?”

She throws her hands in the air. “I just fucking picked someone at random, okay!?”

“But,” Tsumugi presses. “Why did you plainly pick someone at all?”

“Maybe,” Kokichi says. “Even if she didn’t go after Kiiboy, Miu was planning to kill, too, weren’t you?”

Miu clenches her jaw, the sweat beading down her forehead only growing in intensity. Kaede says, “Miu… were you?”

Tenko fidgets, looking down as she says, “Now that Tenko thinks about it, Miu did not seem happy that Tenko stayed behind when everyone went into the virtual world.”

“That’s right,” Kaede says. “And… Miu seemed annoyed when we pointed out something that would have forced all of us to go, as if it was an idea that hadn’t occurred to her before.”

“Oh, holy shit,” Kaito says. “Miu fucking botched her own murder attempt.”

“Sh-Shut up, dickweed!” Miu snaps. “I-I did not!”

Maki sighs. “So Miu tried to murder someone but was too incompetent. I suppose that is the most logical outcome.”

“Oh,” Tsumugi says. “Would that also maybe explain the poison we found at the crime scene? I mean, if I remember right, Miu was sitting in the chair next to mine, and we found the puddle between our chairs…”

Miu frantically waves her hands. “That has nothing to do with anything, you rat bitch!”

“‘Rat bitch?’” Tsumugi echoes. “Hey, I’m not some member of a cursed family!”

Ryoma says, “I take it that means we can assume she was planning to poison someone.” He sighs, “Suppose having a murderer who’s terrible at lying has some upsides.”

“Sh-Shut up!” she shouts again. “I-I don’t know anything about a-any poison, a-and I definitely didn’t get it from Shithara’s lab!”

Kaede sighs as she presses a hand to her forehead. “Alright, so, that answers that.”

Tenko adds, “Tenko remembers that she found the bottle for the poison broken behind Tsumugi’s chair, and she does not remember it being there while she was in the computer room.”

“Ah, that’s right,” Tsumugi says. “I remember only finding it after I logged out, so did Miu try to kill someone after she logged out?”

“When she logged out of the program,” Maki says. “She ran straight to Kiibo in a panic.”

“Also, I think Tenko or I would have noticed if Miu logged out before that,” Kaede says.

Ryoma says, “Remember seeing the poison, and I really don’t think this is much of a mystery.”

“Ooh,” says Kokichi. “Ryoma is stepping up to the plate to rat out Miu!”

Ryoma sighs, saying, “It’s not ratting out if it you’re proving someone innocent. But my point is mostly just that Tenko probably ruined Miu’s plans, and Miu’s really clumsy.”

“Hey!” Miu barks. “I’m graceful as fuck!”

Kaede simply raises an eyebrow at her defense before saying, “Ah, okay, but, Ryoma,” she turns to him, “you have a theory about what happened.”

“I do,” he says. “And Maki or Kaito could probably back this up since they were there.”

“Okay!” Kaito says, slamming his fists together. “Let’s figure this shit out!”

Ryoma frowns. “Don’t think it’s worth getting that excited about…”

Miu mumbles, “I fucking hate all of you…” as the conversation continues.

(Present your Argument) 

“The bottle was only broken,” Tenko says, “After Tenko logged out of the program world—she saw no signs of it before that.”
