“Kiibo talked to Kokichi and me a few times that day,” Kaede says. “But he was still angry with Kokichi and told me pointblank that he would prefer not to talk to him.”

“Kaede,” Kiibo says. “Please, give me a little credit. I may have been upset with Kokichi at the time, but I would not let my personal feelings conflict with my mission in assisting all of you escape.”

“Is…” Tenko says. “Is that true? Kiibo, you refused to speak with Tenko or anyone else for days after Miu’s death.”

Kaito clenches his jaw. “Kiibo, are you lying to us?”

“A-Absolutely not!” Kiibo stammers, appalled at the accusation. “Yes, I would have preferred to speak to Kaede at the time, but when I turned on, I noticed the state Kokichi was in and decided that communicating with him was more important than holding out for someone more… favorable to talk to.”

“You were able to tell how Kokichi was doing from just when you turned on?” Ryoma asks. “And you didn’t think it was a trick or a lie or anything?”

“No,” Kiibo says. “Please understand at the time I felt I had very important information to deliver.”

Tsumugi blinks up at him. “Really? What kind of information?”

Kiibo pauses. “I’m afraid… I believe it would be unwise to reveal that right now.”

“Because one of us is the mastermind, right?” Ryoma asks.

“Correct,” Kiibo says. “I am sorry to admit that I doubt my friends, but—”

“Kiibo,” Tenko says. “Did—did you believe that Kaede and Kokichi both couldn’t be the mastermind? Tenko knows she, um,” her eyes dart nervously around the room, “asked you to tell them about the Flashback Light, but… you never told her what you thought about it.”

“Kokichi shared rather compelling proof regarding his and Kaede’s innocence,” Kiibo says. “After that, even with his rather… dubious track record, I felt inclined to believe him.”

Kaede furrows her brow. “When did he tell you that?”

“When Tenko first brought me to the hanger,” he replies. “Kokichi demanded I talk to him first while you spoke to Tenko. He explained his reasons then.”

Kaede frowns. “Why did he—”

“Kaede,” Kiibo says. “If you do not mind me speaking over you, I feel the need to repeat that I dropped my disguise in order to more directly express what I was trying to say earlier. Solving the mysteries around this case is playing right into the mastermind’s hands.”

“You keep saying that,” Kaito says. “But… then you say crap that sounds suspicious and you still haven’t told us where the hell Maki is.”

“I know, and I apologize again, but it cannot be helped,” Kiibo says. “Also understand that right now, your choices are either to trust me or to trust Monokuma. Even if I may seem suspicious, I would hope that choosing between the two of us would not be too difficult.”

“That’s,” Tsumugi says. “Not really an answer. Actually, you kind of just admitted you were plainly acting suspicious and lying to us.”

“I know,” he says. “And I’m afraid that still can’t be helped.”

Kaede pulls at the brim of her hat, thinking over his words and all of the slight problems with them when Kaito speaks up. “Kiibo, even if you’re hiding a bunch of shit from us, can I still ask you one thing? You said Kokichi… that he—you told us what happened to him. But what about Maki? Were you the one who told her about Miu’s lab and wanted me to go get your fucking head for some reason?”

“Know he had a grudge against Kokichi,” Ryoma says. “But would Kiibo really just answer Maki’s questions after watching her kill someone?”

“You’re right,” Tsumugi says. “That’d be heartless even for someone made out of tin.”

“I can assure you I did no such thing,” Kiibo says. “And also that is robophobic… and inaccurate. My metal composition was primarily—”

“So Kokichi told her?” Kaito presses. “Did she—” he cuts himself off briefly, his own words making him grimace. “Did Maki really torture him?”

Tsumugi hugs herself. “I found an arrow covered with blood while I was investigating the hanger. From what Kaede told me, I assumed it was the one Kokichi was shot with. And… I was wondering why Maki would have gone to the trouble to remove it.”

“That must have been…” Tenko shakes her head. “Tenko can’t even imagine how painful that must have been. Poor Kokichi, no one deserves something like that.”

“I,” Kiibo sighs. “I was hoping not to have to go into details, but… that is all correct.”

“Our theory was right?” Kaede says. “Kokichi was dying of the poison and Maki tortured him for information before letting him die—that’s what happened.”

“Yes,” Kiibo says. “Due to my position, I was only able to see parts of what took place, but from my understanding… yes.”

Kaede takes a deep breath. “I see. Then, Kiibo, can you answer one more question for me?”

“Of course, Kaede,” he replies solemnly.

“Will you stop lying to us?” she says.

“I—what?”

“Kaede,” Kaito says. “You—it’s a lie? That’s not what…” he jerks to look at the Exisal. “Why the hell would you lie about something like that!?”

“I-I am telling the truth!” Kiibo protests. “I promise I would not try to deceive you about something so serious.”

“I,” Tsumugi says. “I believe in Kaede. If she says Kiibo is lying to us, then I believe her.”

“That’s a nice sentiment… I think,” Ryoma says. “But I’m not even sure what Kaede thinks is a lie.”

Kaede nods. “Don’t worry. I plan to make the contradiction in Kiibo’s testimony clear. Then maybe we can get some actual answers.”

“Kaede, everyone,” Kiibo pleads in vain. “Please, trust me. I promise I’m on your side.”

“Kiibo,” Tsumugi says, voice stern. “To speak plainly: that remains to be seen.”

“I do not understand this hostility…” Kiibo mutters softly as Kaede prepares herself to interrogate him again.

(Present your Argument) 

“Kaede said Kiibo lied to us,” Tenko says. “Tenko thinks it had to be something he just said… right?”

“I did not tell any lies!” Kiibo says. “I only gave my account of what happened to Kokichi.”

“He said he died from the poison,” Ryoma says. “Or that Maki tortured him to death for information.”

“Tenko isn’t sure,” she says. “But Tenko thinks we already talked about that. That Maki shouldn’t have even known Kokichi knew…”

Kaito clenches his jaw. “You’ve got a lot of fucking nerve trying to lie to us about Kokichi. You said he was in so much pain, he couldn’t even talk. Why the hell would you make something like that up?”

“I would never do such a thing!” Kiibo protests. “Why won’t you believe me?”

“Do you have any evidence?” Tsumugi asks. “If you could prove it, then we’d believe you but since you’ve already lied to us once…”

“We can’t trust him, can we?” Ryoma says.

“Everyone,” Kiibo says near hopeless. “Please…”

(BREAK) 

“That’s it,” Kaede says. “Kiibo, you said the poison was affecting Kokichi badly enough that he couldn’t speak. If that’s true, then Maki couldn’t get information out of him no matter what she did.”

“Wait!” Kiibo shouts. “Please listen—”

“So you were fucking lying about that!” Kaito shouts.

Tsumugi gasps. “If Kiibo is lying does that mean he really is the killer somehow?”

“At the very least,” Ryoma says. “He’s hiding something.”

“It’s the way that Kokichi died, right?” Tenko asks. “When he was pretending to be Maki, Kiibo kept trying to hide that fact, too, so… what did happen to Kokichi?”

“Well,” Tsumugi says. “What can we deduce from Kiibo’s lie? Does this mean he told Maki everything?”

Kiibo’s voice barely rises above the chatter in his defense of himself. “I can explain! Everything is not what you think it is! I promise I am on your side!”

“I don’t care what shitty excuse you have,” Kaito says. “Pretending to be Maki and then making up all this crap about how she hurt Kokichi—you really expect us to believe that this is all for our own good?”

“I… it’s…” Kiibo falters. “Everything I’ve done since this all began was for you. I know it might be painful, but please believe that I mean it when I say my number one priority is to keep you safe.”

“But,” Tsumugi says. “Didn’t you propose earlier that we not vote? How is that keeping us safe?”

Kiibo doesn’t answer, and Kaede takes the opportunity to regain control of the conversation. “I think our best choice is to just ignore him for now and try to solve the mystery in front of us. If we can do that, then maybe we can figure out exactly why Kiibo would lie in the first place.”

“That… sounds reasonable,” Tenko says. “Okay, Kaede, where do you think we should begin?”

“Our new information seems like the best place,” she replies. “According to Kiibo, both he and Kokichi didn’t tell Maki the information she needed in order to get Kaito to search for the key to Miu’s lab. Right now, there’s no reason why she should have suspected that Kokichi had it in his room.”

“Would Kiibo have even known that?” Ryoma asks. “That Kokichi stole the key?”

Kaede mulls over his words for a moment, answering slowly as she thinks. “No… Kiibo was mostly just with Tenko after Miu’s execution, and I don’t think there’s any reason why Kokichi would have mentioned it to him.”

“So the only person who knew,” Tsumugi says. “Was Kokichi?”

“Kaito,” Ryoma says. “Did Maki say anything suspicious when she was asking you to get her stuff?”

Kaito frowns. “No, I don’t think so. She kept,” he lets out a shuddering sigh. “She kept apologizing to me and telling me to trust her and shit, but I thought that was just due to… her killing Kokichi.”

“If it matters,” Kiibo says. “I do believe Maki felt genuinely sorry for hurting you.”

Kaito scowls. “Go to hell.”

“Um, a-anyway,” Tsumugi says. “Kaede, did you say you had an idea?”

Kaede pulls at the brim of her hat. “I’m not quite sure yet,” she says. “But from everything we know, I think the only possible solution is… I think Kokichi just told Maki voluntarily.”

“Why would he do something like that?” Ryoma says. “You know that implies she just told him what she wanted and he helped her out, right?”

“I know,” Kaede says. “But what other possibility is there?”

“If it is the only possibility,” Tenko says. “Then Tenko thinks it has to be true, but… Tenko saw the scene of the murder. Tenko,” she cradles her head in her hands, “Tenko saw how everything was destroyed. She saw all the blood…”

Tsumugi nods solemnly. “I saw it, too. But from what we talked about earlier, maybe some of the blood was Maki’s, too. I mean, assassins like her could probably just shrug off injuries for a while, so maybe it wasn’t all Kokichi’s. At least,” she hugs herself, “I hope it wasn’t.”

“No,” Kaito sighs. “It was.”

“How do you—” Kaede starts to ask.

“Because I lied earlier when I thought it was Maki,” he says. “Kiibo made up something about me hurting her, and I just went along with it because… fuck.”

“Kaito…” Tenko says sympathetically.

Tsumugi, however, presses ahead. “Then wait—if Maki didn’t get injured, why did I find a used bandage in the bathroom?”

Kaede’s eyes widen. “That’s… that’s right. And that means…”

(Present your Argument) 

“Kaito said Maki was not hurt,” Tenko says. “But there was a used bandage at the scene of the murder…”

“Maki didn’t happen to patch you up, Kaito?” Ryoma asks.

“No,” Kaito says. “Nothing like that happened.”

“Kaede already said it wasn’t hers from earlier,” Tsumugi says. “But the only other person who was in the hanger was Kokichi, right?”

“But—Tenko’s confused,” Tenko says. “Wasn’t Maki the one who brought the gauze?”

“She was…” Kaito says. “But Kokichi was the only other person there after I left with Kaede. And I doubt… he wouldn’t do anything like that.”

“Maki was an assassin and Kokichi was shot with a poisoned arrow,” Ryoma says. “Whether or not he ‘would’ doesn’t matter. At that point it’s just impossible.”

Tsumugi frowns. “Are we just plainly missing something?”

“I suppose I am not allowed to answer that question,” Kiibo says.

(BREAK) 

“Kokichi,” Kaede says. “That’s the only possibility.”

“What the hell are you talking about?” Kaito says.

Kaede straightens her shoulders. “From what we know, the only person who would have needed something like a bandage is Kokichi. And since Tsumugi found only a scrap left, then we can only assume that his injuries got taken care of somehow.”

“Tsumugi mentioned she found the arrow Kokichi was shot with, too,” Tenko says. “Would that mean that the arrow was removed not to hurt Kokichi but… to help him?”

“But Maki was still the one who brought the supplies to do that,” Ryoma says. “And it seems unlikely that Kokichi would have managed to steal them, remove the arrow and treat his wounds without her noticing.”

“But wait,” Tsumugi says. “That means Maki had to know, and,” she frowns. “Didn’t Kiibo tell us earlier that she brought the gauze as a ‘just in case’ sort of thing. Was that a lie, too?”

Kaede furrows her brow. “I—I’m not sure.”

“At the very least,” Ryoma says. “Doesn’t this all mean that Maki was fine with Kokichi taking care of a wound she inflicted, and she was still planning to kill him later?”

“That… doesn’t sound right,” Tenko says. “But why would Maki help Kokichi? She shot him and poisoned him a-and brought a knife to torture him and even crushed his dead body under the hydraulic press.”

“Maybe,” Tsumugi says. “Maybe this is too plain an answer, but from what we know… maybe all of that stuff somehow… isn’t true?”

“You mean,” Kaito says. “Maki—she didn’t kill Kokichi?”

“No,” Kiibo says. “She did. However, you are right. The situation is… more complicated than I made it out to be.”

Kaede frowns, unsure how to address him. “I’m starting to realize that, but I don’t understand. I don’t think any of us do.”

That seems to take Kiibo off guard, and he asks, “What do you mean?”

“I mean,” she says. “We know why Maki went to the hanger, and, well, we know Maki. She was trying to kill me—the fact that there’s anything more to this case than a murder weapon and a corpse is just weird.”

“Maki said she wanted to prevent a trial,” Tenko says quietly. “That’s why she… cleaned up Kokichi’s body.”

“But even that doesn’t really make sense anymore,” Kaede says. “Because Maki only ever had two goals, didn’t she? Kill the mastermind and protect Kaito. Why would she even go to all this trouble?”

Kaito glares at her. “You know she was more complicated than that—killing people and shit wasn’t that simple to her. If you knew about her past—”

“Then maybe I’d cry for her and not the person she murdered?” Kaede snaps. “When you kill someone here that means you’re ready to put everyone else in danger, and you want to just give her a free pass because her orphanage or whatever was mean to her?”

“You are such a fucking hypocrite,” Kaito snarls. “Maki’s the only person you’ve ever treated this way. You only ever saw her as this mindless killer, and that’s exactly why she hid her talent. Yeah, she fucked up a lot, but you refused to even give her a chance.”

Kaede scoffs. “So it’s suddenly my fault that she literally killed someone because I didn’t play nice with her?”

“How many goddamn times do we have to have this fight?” Kaito runs a hand through his hair. “And you know what, Kaede, you killed someone, too, and you forced us all to have a trial, so what does that—”

“I was ready to die during that trial!” Kaede yells. “I never ran away from what I did to Rantaro. I never hid behind robots or mechas or whatever other stupid traps Maki used to try and distract us.”

“Kaede—” Kiibo begins to say.

Ryoma cuts in, quietly advising, “if you’re gonna say something about robophobia, I’d save it for later.”

Kaede doesn’t notice the exchange as all her focus remains locked on Kaito staring her down. “Maybe back then I intended to kill someone, but that does not make me the same as Maki.”

“‘Intended to kill…’” Tenko mumbles to herself.

“Why are you so obsessed with being better than her!?” Kaito shouts. “We have no fucking idea if she’s dead or alive or where the hell she even is and you’re still going on about how she’s so much worse than everyone else.”

“She’s a killer!”

“Um,” Tenko says. “Tenko thinks she thought of something.”

“We’re all killers!” Kaito yells back. “Don’t you get it—we’re all capable of ‘just’ trying to save ourselves or doing ‘the right thing’ or whatever other shitty excuse we use to kill someone. And you know as well as I do that we can’t keep fucking holding that against each other.”

“No,” Kaede says. “Just because ‘everyone’s doing it’ doesn’t mean she shouldn’t be held accountable for murdering someone.”

“‘Held accountable?’” Kaito says. “What the hell do you think the class trial is? But you started this trial, so of course you must just be so fucking happy that—”

“Tenko has something she wants to say!”

“Wanting justice for my friends who have literally died isn’t—”

“Knock it off with your justice bullshit! Nothing about this game is ‘just’—”

“Tenko would really like to—”

“You’re literally arguing for letting a murderer just get away with killing one of your friends!”

“Yeah, because you’re trying to fucking kill her right now!”

Kaede sees red and opens her mouth to say anything to shut Kaito up when Ryoma’s voice cuts through the room. “Both of you—stop.”

Kaito says, “I’ll stop if she—”

“Tenko has something she wants to tell us about the case,” Ryoma says, eyeing both Kaede and Kaito carefully. “I think we should listen to her.”

“I—” Kaede glances over to see Tenko and feels the fight suddenly drain out of her. “Yeah, we… we should.”

“I think we should, too,” Tsumugi says. “What is it, Tenko?”

Tenko seems uncomfortable under the sudden shift in attention, and she eyes Kaito as he sighs and shakes his head before she speaks. “Tenko was just… she was thinking about what Kaede said earlier. And about what Maki—or, Kiibo—said earlier about ‘intent to kill.’”

Kaede can’t help herself from jumping in. “What about it? I thought it was pretty clear that’s what Maki’s motive was—she wanted to kill the mastermind, right?”

“But…” Tenko says. “She didn’t. And when Kiibo was pretending to be her, he just said Kokichi’s death was collateral, and that she’d kill whoever was in her way, but she didn’t hurt Tenko that night.”

“There was no logical reason to kill you, Tenko,” Kiibo says. “Maki wanted to prevent a trial—a death within the school of someone she did not suspect would have been counterproductive to her goal.”

Ryoma stares up at the Exisal. “But that’s true for Kokichi’s death, too.”

“I… suppose it is,” Kiibo says. “However, the circumstances there were different.”

“Were they?” Tsumugi says. “I mean, I know I wasn’t there, but I feel like someone like Maki wouldn’t just let her target go.”

“She gave me a choice on who to save,” Kaito says, gaze trained on the ground. “She let Kaede leave so she could get me out of there.”

Kaede huffs but nods in agreement. “That’s why she shot me in the first place. Both arrows were poisoned and Kaito was forced to help one of us leave to get the antidote.”

“I see,” Tsumugi says. “And I think… that plainly doesn’t make sense.”

“How so?” Kiibo says. “Kaede and Kaito explained the situation in full.”

“They did…” Tsumugi says slowly. “But I think Kaito might be right. I think what we’re missing is… we really don’t understand Maki, do we?”

“What?” Kaede balks. “What are you—of course we understand her.”

Ryoma murmurs, “some of us do better than others…”

Kaede whips her head to look at his strangely accusing words when Kaito speaks up. “Tsumugi, what are you trying to say?”

“Well,” she says. “Tenko was saying it earlier that Maki’s actions and what we know about her seem weird together. So… I think we should talk more about that.”

Kaede can’t help but defensively cross her arms as the others begin to talk, Tsumugi guiding them along the way.

(Present your Argument) 

“Maki’s motivation,” Tsumugi begins. “Was it really just to kill the mastermind?”

“Is there another reason why she would have gone to the hanger?” Ryoma asks.

“There’s no chance Maki just wanted to talk is there…” Tenko says. “Kaede said she showed up armed with a crossbow, and Tsumugi found a knife in her bag.”

“That doesn’t sound like someone who just wants to talk to me,” Tsumugi says. “But she also brought bandages and asked Kaito for strange things.”

“And those things just seem weird,” Ryoma says. “Kaito, do you remember her doing anything else weird?”

“I don’t think so,” Kaito says.

“Well,” Tsumugi prods. “Did Kaede or anyone else notice anything suspicious?”

“I did not make note of any strange behavior,” Kiibo volunteers.

“Um, well,” Tsumugi says. “I wasn’t really asking you.”

(BREAK) 

“I think,” Kaede says slowly. “That I might remember something.”

Tsumugi perks up at her words. “Really? What is it?”

“I didn’t really think anything of it at the time,” Kaede says. “But when Kokichi and I were hiding from Maki… he kept saying how weird it was that we were both going to die or that it was ‘funny’ that she gave Kaito a choice in who to take with him.”

Kaito scowls. “I didn’t think anything about that was funny.”

“No, it probably wasn’t,” Tsumugi says. “But I think Kaede is right. If Maki wanted to kill the mastermind why would she just let you take whichever of them you wanted with you?”

“Because Maki wanted Kaito to leave the hanger,” Kiibo says. “I believe we went over this before.”

“We did,” Kaede says. “But now that I’m thinking about what Kokichi and Tsumugi said… Maki’s motive and her actions don’t match up. And,” she furrows her brow. “I think Kokichi figured that out when we were still in the hanger.”

“Is that why,” Kaito says suddenly, “why he volunteered to stay behind?”

Kaede bites her lip. “Maybe. And if Maki did help him with his injuries, I guess they might have talked to each other so…”

She stops, fiddling with the brim of her hat as she keeps thinking. Tenko says, “Tenko doesn’t know if she understands. Did Maki really come to the hanger to talk then? Tenko thinks—oh!”

Tenko cuts herself off as something unseen catches her attention and she begins to rifle through her pockets. As she does so, Kiibo says, “That is still highly illogical. As we know, both Kokichi and Kaede were attacked, so the possibility that Maki wanted to communicate with them is—”

“Tenko?” Another Kiibo says, his voice coming from Tenko’s podium. “Hello! I apologize for my absence if you have been trying to contact me, but—”

“Kiibo!?” Tsumugi shouts in alarm.

Kaede darts to look at Tenko holding Miu’s old monopad in her hands. The familiar sight of Kiibo’s face on it makes her jaw drop. “Tenko, is that…?”

Softly from the Exisal, Kaede hears Kiibo’s voice mutter, “shit.”

“What the fuck is going on?” Kaito says.

“Um, T-Tenko doesn’t know,” she says. “Kiibo, did you just turn yourself on?”

“I did,” he says. The two words alone are enough to make everyone else quickly exchange hurried and confused glances. “For some reason I was having difficulty functioning earlier, however, whatever was disabling me seems to have passed and I can find no lasting effects.”

Tenko briefly glances up to the others for some indication of how to continue the conversation. Kiibo prompts, “Tenko? Is something wrong? You appear distracted.”

“N-No, Tenko’s fine, but Kiibo,” she says. “You’re only here, right?”

The projection of Kiibo’s face draws its animated features into a frown. “I am unsure what you mean.”

“Miu mentioned she could make copies of you,” Kaede improvises. “I know it was a long time ago, but that… hasn’t happened by any chance, right?”

“No, I do not believe it has to my knowledge,” Kiibo says. “Is that Kaede? Who else is here?”

“Everyone,” Ryoma says. “We’re in a class trial.”

There’s a pause before Kiibo says, “I see,” from the monopad.

“Okay, fuck subtlety,” Kaito says turning to face the Exisal. “Who the hell are you?”

The Exisal remains silent.

“If it’s not Kiibo,” Tsumugi says. “Then were they just using the voice changer to try and pretend to be him?”

“Someone pretended to be me?” Kiibo asks.

“Currently is pretending,” Ryoma says. “Though I think they just gave it up.”

“Kiibo,” Tenko says. “You were in the hanger last night. Do you know anything about what happened to Maki and Kokichi?”

Kaede keeps eyeing the Exisal suspiciously as Kiibo says, “I do not. I spent most of the night attempting to finish running my programming, particularly since I suffered an unexpected setback while trying to do so.”

“What kind of setback?” Kaede asks.

“A power malfunction,” he says. “It was similar to the one I just recovered from. I am beginning to worry that running additional programs is too much for Miu’s monopad.”

“Okay, okay, whatever,” Kaito says still staring at the Exisal. “I asked you a damn question. Who the hell—” he brings a hand to his mouth and lets out a wet cough as he finishes his question, “—a-are you?”

The Exisal stays quiet as Kaito coughs.

Kaede says, “Why are you trying to hide your ident—”

“Well that was rather unfortunate timing,” the Exisal says, still using Kiibo’s voice. “This is exactly why I wanted to end the trial early.”

“You—just,” Kaito snaps even as he continues to wipe the blood off of his mouth. “Just tell us the truth. Who the hell are you!?”

“Someone who hasn’t given up yet,” the Exisal says.

Tsumugi points a shaky finger at it. “So you are just trying to get away with murder and beat us, aren’t you? We already know, so just admit it.”

“You misunderstand,” the Exisal says. “I’m going to lose the trial—but there’s still a chance one of you will figure it out. That’s what I haven’t given up on.”

Kaede watches it carefully as if some movement of its mechanical arms would betray its true intentions. “Figure what out?”

The Exisal doesn’t respond to her, and instead Kiibo speaks up, asking, “Excuse me, but is whoever is in the Exisal the person you mentioned who was pretending to be me?”

“That’s right,” Tenko says. “We thought they were you—well first, Tenko thought it was Maki, but now we’re just kind of confused.”

“Still has to be Maki,” Ryoma says. “Not sure why she’s going to all this trouble though.”

“Maki is inside the Exisal?” Kiibo asks. “Why is she—”

“She killed Kokichi,” Kaito says. “And she’s hiding in there to stop Monokuma from executing her.”

“I,” Kiibo says. “Am confused. You seem unsure on whether you’re sure it’s Maki or not.”

Tsumugi clears her throat. “Ah, well, it kind of has to be Maki because we’re all here, and… Kokichi is dead.”

“He is?” Kiibo asks. “When did this happen?”

“Last night,” Tenko says softly. “The Monokuma File said he died at some point between midnight and two in the morning.”

To Kaede’s surprise, Kiibo’s response is, “huh.”

Kaito scoffs. “Kiibo, I know you didn’t like him, but come on.”

“Oh no! I did not mean it in that way!” he clarifies. “I just thought it was rather strange since that was the time period where I suffered my power malfunction last—”

“Kiibo,” the Exisal says, however strangely the words sound coming out in Kiibo’s voice. “Don’t.”

Tsumugi’s the first to react to the interruption. “Why don’t you want him to say anything?” The Exisal stays quiet. Tsumugi sighs. “Well, now we know we have the culprit cornered like a rat. At this point we just really need to think like them—get in their head. Think like a rat—become the rat.”

“Um, Tsumugi?” Tenko asks. “Are you okay?”

Tsumugi doesn’t reply, still murmuring to herself. “Think, think. Why would the culprit not want Kiibo to talk?”

“He’s a witness,” Ryoma says, though seemingly unsure of himself. “Isn’t he?”

“No,” the Exisal says. “He said earlier he had no idea a murder had even taken place.”

“I still think we need to hear what he has to say,” Tsumugi says. “And then we can vanquish this culprit once and for all!”

Kaito mutters darkly under his breath, “the hell are you so excited for?”

Kaede spares him a quick glance, before turning her attention to Tsumugi’s conversation.

(Present your Argument) 

“Kiibo,” Tsumugi says. “Please present your witness account of the night of the murder.”

“Last night…” Kiibo says. “I was not aware of what was happening for most of the night I believe, however, I encountered a power failure a bit after midnight.”

“Can you please clarify the time,” Tsumugi presses.

“My internal clock states it began at twelve-forty,” Kiibo says.

“That’s the time of Kokichi’s death,” Tenko says softly.

Kaito shakes his head. “We don’t know exactly when he died. There’s a two hour window in the Monokuma File for some goddamn reason.”

“Two hours…” Kiibo repeats.

“Witness,” Tsumugi says. “Does that mean anything to you?”

“No,” the Exisal says. “He just said he was dysfunctional at that time.”

“I-It’s not time for your cross-examination yet,” Tsumugi protests.

(BREAK) 

“Power failure…” Kaede says. “Hey, Kiibo, you said you thought you just overloaded yourself or something, right, but… is there any chance something else forced you to turn off?”

Kiibo pauses. “I suppose that is a possibility. I admit I only assumed the cause because I could find no internal defects.”

“And you were also out of commission for this entire weird two hour window we have for Kokichi’s death?” Kaede asks.

“That is also true,” he concedes.

“Okay, then,” Kaede says. “Tenko, Tsumugi, when you were investigating the hanger, you saw used electrohammers, right?”

Tenko nods. “Yes. Do you think someone used one on Kiibo?”

“Maybe but… Kiibo, you were forcibly turned off for exactly two hours last night?” Kaede asks.

“Correct.”

Kaede sends a weighing look towards the Exisal, but it remains silent. “Then I think I know what happened. Assuming… Tenko, you didn’t happen to see anything that looked sort of like a bright pink grenade in the hanger this morning did you?”

“No,” she says. “Tenko didn’t. What about you, Tsumugi?”

“I didn’t notice anything like that either,” Tsumugi says. “And a pink grenade? I think that probably would have caught my attention.”

“Grenades…” Ryoma says. “Kaede, you mentioned something like that a while ago when we were talking about fighting Monokuma, right?”

Kaede nods. “I did. And those grenades were EMPs that last exactly two hours.”

“Two hours?” Kaito asks. “Wait. Was one of those used and—”

“And it took Kiibo offline!” Tsumugi exclaims in her excitement. “A-And that’s also why—” then she pales, cutting herself off abruptly.

“Tsumugi?” Tenko asks. “Are you okay?”

“I-I,” she stammers. “I’m fine. I was just… thinking about something…”

Kaede frowns. “Thinking about—”

“Hang on,” Kaito says. “These grenade things or whatever that turns stuff off—Ryoma, you mentioned all the cameras and crap are little robot bugs—”

“Robot bears,” Monokuma interrupts.

“Shut up,” Kaito says. “Robot bugs that are watching us all the time. Would one of those EMPs affect them?”

Ryoma pauses for a moment, thinking. “If it did…” he says slowly. “Then Monokuma couldn’t monitor what was happening in the hanger for two hours.”

“During which Kokichi died. Wait,” Kaede says, the sudden realization hitting her. “Does that mean we don’t have an exact time of death because—does the mastermind not know?”

“W-What?” Monokuma says, sweating profusely. “O-Of course I know when the little brat died! It’s my job as—”

“Then tell us,” the Exisal says. “Knowing the time of death is necessary for a fair trial.”

Kaede looks up at the Exisal, lost for a moment before it dawns on her. This is a challenge. She whips her head to look at Monokuma, pausing on his throne. “You know,” he says finally. “I think it’s time we move on to a different subject, kids. So how about we talk about the—”

“Hey!” Kaito barks. “Tell us the truth—do you know what happened to Kokichi or not!?”

“Know? Of course I know!” Monokuma exclaims. “Last night he was smashed to bits! Dead, done, gone forever and ever and ever! What more do you need to know?”

“Um,” Tenko says. “Tenko doesn’t want to agree with him, but… does the exact time of death matter? It says Kokichi died that night, and Tenko—she thinks that means the cameras turned back on after two hours and saw him dead…”

Ryoma sighs. “And we saw Maki this morning. Guess we found Monokuma covering his ass, but not sure if it changes anything.”

“Ah, I guess that’s true,” Tsumugi says, though still seeming unsettled.

Kaede keeps her gaze trained on the Exisal as the pieces start to come together before her again. It would be stupid to put her trust in them. She tears her eyes away. It would be stupid to trust someone like Maki. “Guys,” she says. “Think about it—wasn’t that weird?”

“What was weird?” Kiibo asks.

“Oh,” Tenko says, quickly looking down at him still in her hands. “Early this morning when we were all still in the dorms, we heard an Exisal outside and Maki was inside it. We talked to her and then she went back down to the hanger then we…” she glances up to the others for any guidance on how to continue. “We… talked for a while about what to do before following her.”

“I see,” Kiibo says. Then, “what about that is strange?”

“When we talked to Maki in the Exisal,” Kaede says. “She opened the hatch the pilot’s seat for some reason.”

“Well, yeah,” Kaito says. “We had to talk to her and shit.”

“But she can talk to us through the mic,” Tsumugi gasps. “So did she just open it to prove it was her or something?”

Kaede nods. “That’s what I’m beginning to suspect.”

“Why would Maki need to do something like that?” Tenko asks.

“Because of what Kiibo said,” Kaede says. “He says he suffered one blackout last night and he recovered just now from another one, and since you and Tsumugi didn’t see any of the EMPs when you were in the hanger—”

“But they also didn’t see Kiibo’s head,” the Exisal says. “Things have gone missing.”

Kiibo softly murmurs in confusion, “my head?”

Kaede frowns. “No, I know I’m right. Kiibo, how long did your blackout before the trial last?”

“I believe I suffered my second malfunction approximately… a little over two hours ago,” Kiibo says. “It was,” he pauses, the same connection Kaede made coming to him. “The same as the first one.”

“How many EMPs were there?” Ryoma asks.

“Just two, right?” Tsumugi says. “So does that mean one was used last night and another was used this morning to disable Kiibo?”

Kaito rubs the back of his head. “Okay, yeah, I guess. But what does any of that mean? Maki wanted us to know she was in the Exisal so she could shut off Kiibo?”

“No,” Kaede says. “I think Kiibo being there was a complete coincidence.”

“Kaede?” Tsumugi says. “Did you figure something out?”

Kaede turns to look at her hanging on to her every word. “Yeah… yeah I did.”

(Present your Argument) 

“We’re so close to figuring out this mystery,” Tsumugi says. “Kaede, you can do it!”

“Um,” Kaede says. “Thank you?”

“Can we focus?” Kaito asks. “You said it was weird Maki talked to us—what do you mean by that?”

“Tenko does think it was a little strange she would stop to speak to us,” Tenko says. “And that she opened the hatch to the cockpit then but not now…”

“If she opened it in the trial, she couldn’t have pulled her Kiibo trick,” Ryoma says. “Why… did she pull her Kiibo trick anyway?”

“Is that why she disabled me this morning?” Kiibo asks. “In order to impersonate me at the trial?”

“But if that was Maki’s goal,” Tenko says. “Why did she wait to start pretending to be Kiibo?”

“Maybe there was another reason for using the EMP,” Ryoma says. “Maybe she wanted to trip Monokuma up on something again.”

Kaito mumbles, “she wanted to hide something from Monokuma…”

“And if that’s the case,” the Exisal said. “Then maybe it should remain hidden.”

(BREAK) 

“We never saw Maki after we went to the hanger that morning,” Kaede says. “And this entire trial whoever is inside that Exisal has been trying to hide their identity this entire time.”

“Kaede,” Kaito says. “What are you—”

“I have a question,” the Exisal says.

“You,” Tsumugi points an unsteady finger at it. “You’re just trying to stop us! Nothing good can come from answering your question!”

“Maybe,” the Exisal says. “But I think I’ll still ask it. Last night in the hanger, Kokichi and Kaede were together and Kaito and Maki were together. Then the alarm turned off.”

Kaede blinks. “Yes…”

Kaito scowls. “What does that have to do with anything?”

“Who turned off the alarm?” it asks.

The room goes quiet. Kaede finds herself at a loss. “I,” she begins. “Don’t know. I was with Kokichi the whole time, and I just… never thought about it.”

“Are you trying to imply there was someone else in the hanger that night?” Kaito asks. “‘Cause it wasn’t me or Maki.”

“Ryoma and I were together when… all of that was happening, I think,” Tsumugi says. “And Tenko was unconscious in the school.”

“And Kiibo’s a thumb drive,” Kaito says. “That’s literally everyone so what the fuck are you talking about?”

The Exisal pauses for a moment, then, “who would have the ability to turn off the alarm?”

“Will you just tell us what the hell you mean already?” Kaito snaps.

“Kokichi had the remote to the hanger, but Kaede said he had nothing to do with it,” the Exisal continues. “So who else could have done it?”

Kaede fiddles with the brim of her hat as she thinks. “Just… Monokuma’s the only one who knows the password.”

“Exactly,” the Exisal says.

Kaede turns slightly to look at the now sweating robot bear. “Did you?”

“W-Well,” Monokuma says. “It was just sooo loud and I was just trying to get my beauty sleep, and it is my responsibility to shut off the alarm so it doesn’t blare forever. And let me tell you just what a pain my b—”

“You interfered with a murder,” the Exisal says. “And that breaks one of your rules.”

“Is that true…” Tenko murmurs softly. “What happens then?”

“Ahem, well, excuse me for wanting a little peace and quiet!” Monokuma says. “And as you know, a murder had not yet occurred at that point—just some riffraff and spats that were far too loud for my delicate ears.”

“For your ears,” the Exisal says. “Or your audiences’?”

Kaede snaps to look at the Exisal as any doubts in her mind evaporate into nothing.

“Audience?” Monokuma asks, tilting his head. “Are you by any chance referring to my tragically deceased kubs? To mock a grieving father! Oh the humanity! The bear-manity!”

“Knock it off,” Ryoma says. “Tell us what they’re talking about.”

“I would if I could, but my head is only full of fluff,” Monokuma replies. “Poor little old me, surrounded by such wild and imaginative children. Whatever is a bear to do besides kill them all?”

“Anything besides that,” the Exisal says. “You won’t end your game that way.”

Monokuma raises a paw, his red eye glowing. “Phuhuhu—feel like testing me on that?”

“No,” the Exisal says. “I’ve done what I needed to do. Kaede, you had something to say.”

Kaede blinks up at it, completely caught off guard. “I—you want me to keep going?”

“I want you to think.”

Kaede keeps staring at it. Distantly, Kaito asks her if she knows something, the emotional strain clear in his voice. Tsumugi asks if she’s figured something out and if she’ll please tell everyone else. The Exisal doesn’t say anything.

Her thoughts come racing faster. Maki wouldn’t do what Kaede knows she has to have done. She isn’t to be trusted. Neither of them are to be trusted. Kaede keeps thinking, the implications twisting themselves over and into knots.

Then Tsumugi speaks. “Wait a minute—I think I get it.”

“You…” Kaede says. “You do?”

“It’s plainly just a theory, but,” she says. “Is there any chance that Maki and Kokichi switched places this morning?”

Kaede feels her jaw drop as Tsumugi makes the decision to press onwards for her.

“But wouldn’t that mean the Monokuma File was wrong?” Tenko asks.

Tsumugi sighs. “I know it’s hard to believe, especially because we’ve relied on it so much in the past. But Kaede is right. Why else would the culprit of the trial try so hard to pretend to be so many different people? Why would Maki make sure we knew it was her when we first saw her this morning? Why would she wait before killing Kokichi that night?” She turns to Kaede. “Kaede, you see what I’m getting at, don’t you?”

And then Kaede feels herself freeze. “I…” she stares at Tsumugi looking so earnestly at her to continue. She doesn’t turn to see what the Exisal is doing, but she swears she can feel its cold stare on her, too. “I think—”

“I have something to say,” the Exisal says.

“No,” Tsumugi says. “You’re just going to try to confuse us.”

“I’m not just saying it for me,” Kokichi’s voice says, suddenly emanating from the Exisal. Then it switches to Rantaro. “If I can be dramatic for a moment, I need to say something for everyone who has died.” Then, Maki. “And I’m not going to take no for an answer.”

 


(THEORY ARMAMENT) 

“This killing game,” Maki says. “Has always been us against the mastermind—the killings are only distractions.”

“Solving mysteries here,” Shuichi says. “That’s not really finding the truth. It’s just what the mastermind wants us to do. 

“It is a show to them,” Kirumi says. “They give us a puzzle and we solve it to entertain their audience.”

“And all that does,” Gonta says. “Is create more murders, and then more mysteries and more entertainment. And all of us…”

“We die for it,” Korekiyo says. “The trials are not held in order for us to survive but in order to perpetuate our suffering.” 

“There is no justice, there is no ‘hope’ in doing what Monokuma asks,” Kiibo says. “There is no beating him at him own game either. The only way to truly succeed…”

“Is to not play at all!” Angie says. “But it’s too hard to just stop the murders so the only other thing to do is to stop the mysteries!”

“If that happens,” Himiko says. “Then Monokuma’s audience won’t be happy, and if they’re not watching, why would we keep playing?” 

“And you better take this advice seriously,” Miu says. “People have died over it, you know? Two people are dying over it right now.” 

“The only way to make sure their sacrifices aren’t in vain,” Kokichi says. “Is to stop here—not every truth needs to be revealed.” 

“And the truth I’m giving you, and the one you need to believe,” Rantaro says. “Is that Kokichi died that night and Maki killed him.”

“And there is no other possibility,” Maki says.

(BREAK) 

Kaede pauses for a moment, still staring up at the Exisal, taking it all in.

Tsumugi, says, “Well, is that everything? Are you done?”

No one answers her question immediately and Tsumugi sighs. “I guess in that case—”

“Tsumugi,” Kaede says. “I think I understand what you were trying to say earlier about Maki and Kokichi potentially switching places.”

Tsumugi looks delighted, and Kaede doesn’t miss the semi-triumphant look she sends the Exisal. “Good. So I guess I wasn’t too far off, the—”

“But I think your theory isn’t right,” Kaede says.

Tsumugi blinks at her. “Huh?”

“What you’re getting at is that Maki and Kokichi made some sort of weird plan or something and Maki just agreed to let herself be killed, right?” Kaede says.

“Maki,” Kaito says. “She’s the victim!?”

“No,” Kaede shakes her head. “She can’t be. I get why Tsumugi thinks it’s a possibility, but, well,” she shrugs, “Kokichi was poisoned that night and we all know the antidote ended up broken in pieces on the floor. It’s impossible that he survived.”

“I…” Tsumugi looks at a complete loss. “I guess that is true…”

“There was only the one antidote that Kaito brought,” Tenko says. “And if Kokichi was shot with poison…”

Kaito clenches his jaw. “There’s no way he would have lived.”

“Ah, but…” Tsumugi starts to say. “Um…”

“Kaito did give me part of the antidote,” Kaede says. “So you didn’t need to drink all of it, but from what you described earlier, I doubt Kokichi ever got any of it.”

Tsumugi hugs one of her arms to herself but doesn’t say anything further. Ryoma says, “So is that everything then?”

“Tenko thinks so,” Tenko says. “We argued for so long, but… the answer is still the same isn’t it?”

“Then did Maki impersonate me merely to throw suspicion off of herself?” Kiibo asks.

“Maybe,” Kaede says. “She could have tried to just make us have enough doubt to think up some weird theories instead of just looking at the problem in front of us.”

“I see,” Kiibo says. “So she was simply trying to get away to avoid execution.”

Kaito shakes his head. “That can’t be it. Maki—she wouldn’t do that.”

“But,” Tenko says softly. “She just did.”

Kaito just sighs. “I know. But it doesn’t seem right to me. Maki knew what she was doing—she wouldn’t just kill someone and let us take the fall. She wasn’t like that.”

“Kaito,” Kaede says sternly. “Kokichi is dead because Maki killed him. Even if you want to believe in her, that’s just the facts of the situation. There’s no way Kokichi could have survived that poison.”

“‘That poison…’” Tsumugi mutters to herself, suddenly creasing her brow in thought.

Kaito doesn’t meet her gaze. “I know. I found the antidote, put it in Maki’s hand and watched her break it from the bathroom window—you don’t have to keep telling me over and over again.”

“Kaito,” Tsumugi says. “Actually, um, would you mind telling me a bit more about the antidote? I mean, I remember you reading part of the label aloud when you found it but… I-I think it could be useful to go over what it was.”

Ryoma frowns. “Does the poison used matter?”

“I’m not sure,” Tsumugi says. “But I think it might.”

Kaede watches Tsumugi carefully, not quite sure what she’s trying to get at. “Tsumugi, I don’t think there were the same ingredients that were in the antidote just lying around in the hanger or anything like that. And even if there were, I doubt Kaito remembers exactly what they were.”

“No, no!” she says. “It’s nothing like that.”

“Then what is it?” Tenko asks politely.

“Well,” Tsumugi says. “I was just thinking it might be useful to know what kind of poison it was since… there might be a second antidote that someone secured way before the murder. Actually, Kaede, I think you might know what I’m talking about.”

“I don’t think I do,” Kaede says. “How could there have been…” and she feels the words die in her throat as the memory that only she and Tsumugi should know comes back to her. Kaede shakes her head, hoping she didn’t pause for long enough to alert Tsumugi of her discovery. “I’m sorry, Tsumugi, but I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Oh,” she says. “That’s too bad. Anyway, Kaito, what did the antidote label say?”

Kaede sends him a look she hopes conveys the complex intricacies of the situation. Kaito only seems slightly off put by her pained expression but understands enough to give the vague answer, “a bunch of stuff about how to use it and how much to take mostly.”

Tsumugi, for her part, doesn’t seem frustrated by his useless response. “Okay, but did the label say anything about what kind of poisons it commonly treats?”

“I’m not su—”

“Anything about poisons commonly slipped in food?”

The color drains from Kaito’s face and the stutter in his answer does enough damage alone. “I—did I say something like that when I found it?”

“No,” Tsumugi says. “But Maki did when she took the antidote Kokichi had taken from Shuichi’s lab at dinner a few days ago.”

Kaede can’t help but wince at the damning words. Ryoma asks, “don’t remember anything like that. When did this happen?”

“Well, a while back when Kaede and I discovered Shuichi’s lab for the first time, Kokichi showed up and took an antidote and a poison with him,” Tsumugi says. “I don’t plainly have no idea what he was planning to do with it, but at dinner the night we finished exploring the new parts of the school, he started talking about it again, and Maki took the antidote from him.”

“That night,” Tenko says. “Tenko was with Ryoma in the dorms…”

“And Kaito was in his room,” Tsumugi adds. “Kaede and I were the only people who saw it happen, but from Kaito’s reaction, I think I guessed right.”

Kaito grips the front of his podium with one hand, and Kaede notices the other darts to hold his side. “Okay,” Kaede says. “But just because Maki had an antidote doesn’t mean Kokichi ever took it.”

“Th-That’s right,” Kaito agrees, his voice breaking as he tries to hold back a cough. “Maybe that’s all true or whatever, but we don’t know if she had it with her when she went to the hanger. Besides, Maki destroyed the antidote I brought so she obviously didn’t—”

“No,” Tsumugi says. “She did that because she wanted to trick you into thinking Kokichi died that night, and we almost fell for it. But we know that before Maki went to the hanger, she specifically picked to use a poison that she knew there were two antidotes for—one that Monokuma had restocked on the shelf in Shuichi’s lab and the one she had taken from Kokichi previously.”

Kaede’s mouth presses into a thin line as Tsumugi talks. “But,” she says. “We can’t know that for sure.”

“I think we can,” Tsumugi insists. “I mean, why else would Maki go out of her way to choose that poison? She must have gone to the hanger with the goal in mind to try and pull some sort of trick like this.”

“No,” Kaito says. “That can’t be right. ‘Cause that would mean… would mean she was planning to let herself be killed, and,” he grimaces, “M-Maki wouldn’t do that.”

“But,” Tenko says. “Would Maki kill someone? Tenko knows that seems like a strange question, but, Kaito kept talking about how she promised him she wouldn’t…”

Kaito stares at her in horror for a brief moment before turning away to cough into his hand. “N-No,” he still manages to get out. “I-I refuse to believe that.”

“If all of this is true,” Ryoma says mostly to himself. “Then… Kokichi’s alive?”

“K-Kokichi?” Kaito stammers. “He—no that’s not possible. He wouldn’t hurt anyone either.”

The Exisal remains silent.

“I think maybe I should clear up everything,” Tsumugi says. “Because we’ve solved this case.”

“I really don’t think that’s necessary, Tsumugi,” Kaede says quickly.

“If it’s the only way to convince everyone,” she says. “Then it is. So first, a few days before the murder, the culprit of the case and Maki—”

“But we can’t know!” Kaede shouts. “All of this is just speculation! Maybe Maki decided to just let Kokichi kill her for some reason, or maybe it’s what we thought before and Maki still killed him with the knife or the poison or whatever else. We can’t know.”

“And,” the Exisal finally says, Kokichi’s voice emanating from it this time. “Monokuma doesn’t know either.”

Tsumugi’s eyes widen. “What?”

“The EMPs,” Maki says. “You were right. They disabled the mastermind’s cameras in the hanger. No one knows what happened—not even Monokuma.”

“Is… is that really true?” Kaito asks.

“If it is,” Ryoma says. “Then what happens with the trial?”

Kaede turns to stare down Monokuma. “We can’t vote if you don’t know the answer.”

But strangely enough, unlike the times before, Monokuma doesn’t seem nervous. “Is that so? Because after your wonderful discussion, I think I have a pretty good idea how things went down.”

“But Kaede was right,” Tenko says. “We can’t know for sure, can we? So… how do we vote?”

Monokuma brings his paws to his mouth. “Like you always do. Vote for who you think is the blackened!”

“Fuck you,” Kaito says. “You’re just trying to get us to sell out Maki or Kokichi.”

“Aw, that’s such a nasty way of putting it,” Monokuma says. “Especially since aren’t they the ones who betrayed you first when they set up an impossible mystery? After all, who’s going to suffer from a wrong vote? Who’s going to suffer from a resisted execution? Oh, and believe me, this trial isn’t ending without an execution.”

Kaede feels her throat tighten even as she forces herself to speak. “You’re—you’re bluffing. As long as you don’t know what happened, you can’t rule if our vote is right or wrong.”

“Maybe we could try and tie the vote?” Tsumugi asks. “L-Like three of us vote for Kokichi and then three for Maki.”

“Not gonna happen,” Ryoma says. “Whichever of them is in the Exisal would have to leave in order to vote at all.”

“But doesn’t that mean that if we even hold a vote, they’ll be punished anyway even if we are wrong?” Tenko asks.

“Ah, a clever plan, certainly had me sweating a few times,” Monokuma says. “But all’s well that ends well, and this situation is just so utterly, deliciously hopeless once again. Because like I said—this trial only ends with an execution for somebody.”

“That,” Kiibo says suddenly. “Might be alright…”

Kaito looks appalled. “Wha—What the hell are you saying!? How is that ‘alright!?”

“I, ahem,” Kiibo says. “May or may not have a potential plan in place in the event of—”

“Puhuhuhu,” Monokuma laughs. “Oh, don’t worry your pretty little decapitated head about all that. Maybe the situation isn’t quite as taken care of as it should be thanks to a few good for nothing tech monkeys not doing their jobs, but accommodations have been made far in advance!”

Kaede blinks. “What are you talking about? It sounds like you have employ—”

“Which means whoever our culprit is will receive a lovely, unhackable, low-tech execution!” Monokuma announces. “Honestly, they knew what they were doing in the old days—some times you just gotta strip off the bells and whistles to find real despair, you know?”

“What… does that mean?” Tenko asks cautiously.

Monokuma brandishes a claw. “I’m glad you asked. It means there’s no escape for our culprit who thinks they’re just so clever. Let this be a lesson for all you kids: never try to outsmart a bear.”

“But,” Kaede says, feeling the desperation involuntarily creep into her voice. “You still don’t know who the culprit is. None of us do. You can’t punish us if you don’t know, and if they stay in the Exisal, they’re safe aren’t they?”

“Aw, you kids are so cute, thinking I won’t smash one of my own Exisals to bits,” Monokuma says. “And also now might be a wonderful time to introduce the Monokuma tank! Or the Monokuma clone army! Or maybe the Monokuma fighter jet! Go online for more details about how you, too, can purchase one of these limited offer—”

“You’re just going to kill us then?” Tsumugi gasps. “O-Or destroy the trial room until the culprit comes out?”

“Welp, it’s not the nicest solution, but a bear has to do what a bear needs to do!” Monokuma says. “And I’m not giving up until someone here gets executed. Because after all, maybe the vote will be wrong or right, but our mysterious culprit will have to make an appearance either way if they want to prove, oh, what was it? My game is a sham and I’m a failure or something?”

Kaede feels herself start to sweat. She looks to the Exisal, hoping it will have some possible solution. But it remains as silent as the others, all starting to look panicked as the reality of their situation sets in.

Then, “hey,” Kaito says. “Monokuma, I have a question for you. At Shuichi’s trial… Kaede was the culprit, but he took the execution for her. Can that happen again?”

The Exisal speaks then, hissing in Kokichi’s voice, “Kaito, quit it.”

“Hmm?” Monokuma says. “Are you trying to make a deal with little old me?”

“No,” it says again, this time as Maki. “He’s not.”

Kaito turns to the Exisal. “Hey, I—I honestly have no idea who you are, but just let me protect you, okay? I don’t have a lot of time left, and if I have to die, doing it this way, well,” even with the blood on his face, he does his best to give the Exisal his most confident smile. “I think I’d be okay with that.”

“Kaito,” Tenko gasps. “You can’t—you can’t just do something like that!”

“I will if Monokuma lets me,” he says. “Besides, like I said… I don’t know who the hell died, but either answer…” he shakes his head. “I don’t want to hear it. I don’t know and I don’t want to know. I know Maki or Kokichi… one of them is already dead, but if I can save the other,” he presses his fists together. “Then I’m going to. And dying not knowing who I failed—I think I’d prefer that.”

Kaede finds herself at a loss to do anything that repeat his name. “Kaito…”

“Hmm, hmm,” Monokuma hums. “Interesting, very interesting…”

“So,” Kaito says. “What do you think Monokuma? Everyone votes for me, I get executed, and you let the others go. You get your execution and the trial ends.”

“Kaito,” Maki says. “I can’t let you do that.”

He shakes his head. “It’s too late. I’ve already made up my mind.”

“You don’t understand,” she says. Then she pauses for just a moment before saying, “if I let you die, Harumaki-chan will kill me.”

Kaito’s previously calm demeanor vanishes. “Ko—”

Then the Exisal starts to lower itself to the ground, Maki’s voice still coming out of it all the way. “I had a feeling things would end like this. And I didn’t have too much of a choice anyway once you guys started piecing everything together even after my super dramatic speech and all.” The hatch rises, and Kaede can’t find it in herself to feel anything but defeat when she sees Kokichi inside. “Honestly, that should have given away that it was me. You think Harumaki-chan could pull something like that off?”

“So,” Tsumugi says. “The culprit was Kokichi after all.”

“You got it,” Kokichi grins, folding his hands behind his head. “I underestimated you guys. I thought you’d all be doomed for sure without me giving you hints. But looks like—”

“What the fuck are you doing!?” Kaito shouts in him. “Get the hell back in there right now! Monokuma’s gonna kill you!” Kokichi doesn’t move and Kaito shouts again. “What the hell are you waiting for!? Hurry up!”

Kokichi looks at him, and while his expression remains upbeat, Kaede can’t help but think she sees something slightly sad in his smile, or at least, she’d like to think she does. “Kaito,” he says. “You’re very dumb and very sweet, and you know it’s too late for that to work.”

“No!” he yells back. “No, it’s fucking not! There’s still time to—”

“Did someone say out of time?” Monokuma asks. “Because whoever did is right on the money! It’s now the wonderful and despair inducing voting time! Will you choose the right choice or the dreadfully—”

“Fuck you!” Kaito shouts. “I’m not voting for shit!”

“Nope,” Kokichi says. “I appreciate the sentiment, but no can do, Kaito. Like I said, Harumaki-chan would not be happy if anything happens to you. That was part of our deal, you know.”

Tsumugi says softly, “so you two were working together, after all. Did Maki force you to do the plan or she wouldn’t give you the antidote?”

“That’s… a possibility,” Ryoma says, though seemingly more stunned than anything.

Kokichi hums. “Could be. But anyway, your options are everyone votes for me or everyone decides not to vote, and, well,” he smiles wryly. “Option two isn’t going to happen. Not for me.”

Kaede feels her stomach twist. “Kokichi…”

“I don’t care,” Kaito says. “I’m not—I’m not sending you to your death. I don’t care if I’m the only one. I’m not voting for anyone.”

Kokichi sighs and finally jumps out of the Exisal’s cockpit to walk over to him. He places a comforting hand on Kaito’s arm and says, “Hey, Tenko,” he says. “Can you do me another favor?”

Tenko jolts slightly at the address but still answers, “Y-Yes?”

“My podium’s next to yours so can you go ahead and vote for me?” he says.

“Kokichi,” Kaito says. “You can’t be serious.”

“What? Why not? I’m always serious,” Kokichi says. “And I’m especially serious about Tenko voting for me since I need to vote for you.”

Kaito manages to gasp, “Wha—” before Kokichi bodily shoves the bulk of meager weight into Kaito’s chest.

He gasps again, staggering back with a choked cough, while Kokichi easily presses at the voting screen on his podium. “And there,” he says before looking up. Behind him, Kaito’s on his knees, trying to catch his breath as more coughs rack his body. “Anyone else still need to vote?”

Kaede forces herself to tear her eyes away just long enough to press his name on her own panel. Tenko seems to do the same and immediately takes off to hurry to Kaito’s side. “Kaito,” she says. “Try to calm down. Just focus on breathing, and—”

He looks up, blood still streaking down his chin, to glare at Kokichi. “F-Fuck you.”

Kokichi nonchalantly turns to face him as Monokuma announces all the votes are in. “It sounds like you're angry with me, Kaito. That's good,” he says. “And holding on to all that anger will make pressing the reset buttons on your feelings just a bit easier.”

Behind him, the tallies come in to show a unanimous vote. Despite Tenko’s protest, Kaito staggers to his feet, taking a shaky step towards Kokichi. “You—you killed Maki, and you faked your own death just so you could lie and manipulate us, and-and put me through hell,” he snarls. “And I’m never going to forgive you for any of this.”

“You shouldn’t,” Kokichi says. “In fact—”

He stops abruptly when Kaito surges forward to wrap his arms around his shoulders, pulling him into a tight hug. “And I’m so fucking happy you’re alive.”

Kokichi seems to recover from his initial surprise, though he doesn’t return the hug, his arms staying limply at his sides. But he doesn’t push Kaito away, either, and remains oddly quiet as the other slowly gather around. “Hey, Kaito,” he says finally. “I know you love me and all, but everyone’s kinda starting to stare.”

“Shut up,” Kaito mumbles half heartedly.

“But you know how hard that is for me,” Kokichi teases back.

“Um,” Tsumugi says. “Not to interrupt, but… Kokichi, can we ask you some questions?”

Without moving an inch, Kokichi replies casually, “well, you know how much I love talking about myself, but I’m afraid that’s kind of up to Kaito right now.”

Kaito pauses for a moment, letting a breath out through his nose before slowly backing off. “Ew,” Kokichi says, brushing at the top of his head. “Kaito got his gross blood on me.”

“Kokichi,” Kaede says. “You—you planned all of this with Maki.”

“Hmm?” he turns to look at her. “Did you say something?”

Kaede feels just a touch of her sympathy drain as part of her remembers just how difficult talking to Kokichi is. “You and Maki worked together,” she says. “To try and end the killing game.”

“That’s not a question, Kaede,” he says, cheerily folding his hands behind his head. “But it is true. Obviously didn’t work out though.”

“Well—but still,” Tsumugi says. “Maki she really did just… let herself be killed?”

“True,” Kokichi says. “I know I said you guys did a good job figuring me out, but you did slightly miss that part. Harumaki-chan went to the hanger with everything all set up, including a knife so she wouldn’t die by getting crushed to death or anything since that would be the worst—or at least, I think it’d be the worst.”

“That… does not sound pleasant,” Tenko says.

“But yep!” he says. “When Harumaki-chan showed up, I figured out she had a plan pretty quick, and I was kinda dying to know what it was. Also could you imagine if things worked out differently and it was Kaede trying to pull something like this off?”

Kaede blinks. “I hadn’t really thought about that.”

“But you just gave up,” Ryoma says. “So… all of this was for nothing.”

“Ryoma, who do you think you’re talking to?” Kokichi says. “Of course I haven’t given up—I just had to protect what was important. And besides ending a killing game by killing everyone is kind of a hollow victory, don’t you think?”

Kaede sees Kaito clench his hands into his fists while Tenko says, “You wanted to save us. You and Maki, both. You wanted to end the killing game and also save us from the time limit.”

“I’m just the nicest guy, aren’t I?” Kokichi says. “You know, for a while I was kicking around plans about pretending to be the mastermind, but those all kinda fell apart so I was just stuck being a goody-two-shoes. Still, though, I know I’m not that well liked, so you guys should stop lying and pretending to be all sad.”

“Kokichi,” Kaito says.

Kokichi ignores him. “Come on—you’re getting a pain like me out of your hair, but you’re all acting like someone ran over your cat or something. But then again, it was pretty fun to see how much everyone loved me after I was dead, so win some lose some.”

“How can you say that?” Tenko asks, near horrified.

“Yeah,” Tsumugi says. “And also why did you do so much other weird stuff like get Kaito to bring you Kiibo’s head?”

“Oh,” he says. “That’s a really good question, Tsumugi!”

“You’re not going to answer are you…” she says.

“Not unless you answer a question first!” Kokichi says before pouting and pointing towards his crossed out portrait across the courtroom. “Is that really the best picture Monokuma had of me? He didn’t even get my good side!”

“That’s what you’re concerned about?” Tsumugi mumbles to herself.

Kokichi huffs. “Image is very important for a supreme leader. Well, at least Monokuma looks pretty stupid for declaring me dead even if he used an ugly picture.”

Kaede hears the bear in question begin to grumble darkly to himself. “But still, Kokichi,” she says. “Why did you set everything up to be so… weird? I know some things were to make us think Maki was the culprit, but a lot of other things were just kinda…” she finds herself trailing off, caught between trying to ask about the oddities of the case and why other parts seemed so needlessly cruel.

“Well,” Kokichi says. “I’ll admit this was never my best lie, but then again I had to work with Harumaki-chan’s stupid plan. I’d like to think I managed to salvage something not completely terrible from it, though.” He beams as he folds his hands behind his head. “I did keep you guys guessing for a while after all, didn’t I? You should have seen the looks on your faces—man, I should really fake my death more often.”

“That’s…” Kaede says. “That’s it—that’s all you have to say?”

He hums. “I mean, you guys figured out most of the important stuff, and, well, I just wouldn’t be being true to myself unless I took a few secrets to my grave, right?”

“Kokichi,” Tenko says, shooting an anxious glance to Kaito. “Tenko thinks Kaede meant just… you’re going to die. Are you really not scared at all?”

Kokichi follows her gaze, and his voice lowers from his previous cheerful tone. “No,” he says. “Harumaki-chan and I both knew we were going to die as soon as we started our plan to end the killing game. She was super annoying about it, too, and kept asking me if I was sure I wanted to go through with it after she gave me the antidote.”

“So you weren’t coerced then?” Ryoma says.

“Yup! That’s one thing you guys got wrong, so I really can only give you a ‘C’ plus or something,” Kokichi says. “Especially since you guys haven’t figured out the real twist of the plan yet.”

“W-What?” Tsumugi stammers. “I thought you said it was just to have a mistrial? Was that just a lie, too?”

Kokichi presses a finger to his lips. “This is a mistrial,” he says. “Because Monokuma still has no idea who killed Harumaki-chan.”

Tsumugi pales. “B-But you confessed, didn’t you? Isn’t that why you left the Exisal?”

“Kokichi,” Kaede says. “You… you haven’t given up trying to trick Monokuma, have you?”

Kokichi grins. “I won’t give up even after my death—when I play a game, I play to win after all. And, well, I think it’s pretty safe to say that I won even if I did need stinky Harumaki-chan’s help.”

“Then,” Kaito speaks up, voice hoarse. “Are you not the killer?”

Something in Kokichi’s smile falters for just a moment, and Kaede notices he seems to look somewhere to the side of Kaito when he speaks. “Afraid I can’t say, Kaito. Mostly, I just want to let Monokuma know that, sure, maybe it was me, but Harumaki-chan also could have used that knife before I crushed her body.”

“And because of the EMP,” Ryoma says. “Monokuma has no way to know what actually happened. That’s the other part of your plan, isn’t it?”

“Exactly!” Kokichi says. “So, Monokuma, your thoughts?”

Kaede turns to Monokuma to see his robotic eyes narrowed and tiny fists curled in rage. “Man,” Monokuma says. “Even at the end you’re still a stubborn jerk.”

“That’s not an answer,” Kaede says. “Monokuma, do you know who killed Maki?”

He stares down at her, pausing for a moment. “The killer,” he says finally. “Is the killer, plain and simple, and if I say it’s Kokichi Oma, then it’s Kokichi Oma!”

“But you… don’t actually know, do you?” she persists.

Monokuma goes quiet.

Kokichi smiles. “And I think that means I win.”

“Win nothing!” Monokuma shouts. “All you’re winning is an execution!”

Kokichi sighs. “Man, two wrongful executions in one killing game? This game sucks…”

“Kokichi,” Kaito says.

“That’s my name!” Kokichi beams. “Funny hearing you use it. Absence really does make the heart grow fonder and all that, huh?”

Kaito ignores the teasing. “Maki—she… she really agreed to everything right? She…”

“She did,” Kokichi says, some of his cheer fading. “Me and her actually went back and forth a lot on who would do what, but she kept whining about this promise she made with you and how she wasn’t about to let you down and all that. So even if it was all pretend, she was pretty insistent on being the victim.”

Kaito lets out a shaky sigh. “Yeah?”

“Mhmm,” he says. “And trust me—I wouldn’t lie about this.”

To Kaede’s surprise, Kaito seems to accept that answer. “Right… right.”

“And she also wanted me to deliver a message to you, but I cut out a few parts since they were too mushy,” Kokichi says. “Basically Harumaki-chan told me to tell you not to blame yourself. Keeping Kaito safe was too important and she said a bunch of stuff about how she knows you hated that but she’s too stubborn to listen and you guys have that in common and blah blah blah.”

“Is that true?” Kaito asks. “Or are you… lying to make me feel better?”

“I,” Kokichi turns slightly to fish a piece of paper out of his pocket. “Have a note from assassin-chan right here! I also added some additions at the end, though you should read her part first to save the best for last.”

Kaito takes it, and something in his expression seems to crack as he breaths out, “you—”

“And that!” Monokuma announces. “Is enough of that! Sheesh, you kids can talk, but we got an execution to get to. And I’ve been really looking forward to this one.”

“Well,” Kokichi says. “Sounds like that’s my cue, and,” he gives a knowing grin to Monokuma, “I would hate to keep your audience waiting.”

“I’m sure I have no idea what you’re talking about,” Monokuma replies.

“That’s okay,” Kokichi says. “Because that was also a lie.”

“Kokichi,” Kaito says. “Quit messing around. You—you can still escape or…” he swallows. “You should have just let me—”

Kokichi huffs. “And I keep telling you, that’s not an option, Kaito. Geeze, I’m literally dying and you still can’t listen.”

“No,” Kaito says. “Because I’m not gonna let you die. We can still fight Monokuma, and—”

“No,” Kokichi says. “You can’t. If it wasn’t a possibility when everyone was here to fight or when Miu had her remote, then why would it suddenly work now?”

“Because I’m not giving up,” Kaito says. “I’m not just going to fail both you and Maki—I don’t care if I die, but I’m not just going to sit back and let my friend throw their life away.”

Kokichi pauses then. His recovery comes fast, but Kaede notices that same familiar sadness she thought she saw when Kaito had first hugged him. “Geeze, Kaito, you keep ruining my cool and mysterious image with all your lame speeches,” he says. “And also you still can’t listen.” He sighs. “Well, I did come prepared to Kaito proof my execution.”

Kaito’s eyes widen. “You what?”

Kokichi slips a familiar looking bottle out of his pocket, and before Kaede can even process what it is, he unscrews the lid and downs whatever liquid was inside. “Ugh, blechy,” he says, wiping his mouth on the back of his sleeve.

“Kokichi,” Tenko says cautiously. “What did you just do?”

“Drank lukewarm poison,” he says, sticking his tongue out. “That was so gross. I thought it was supposed to be flavorless.”

Tsumugi pales. “You—the poison you had been carrying around! You just—”

“Spit it out!” Kaito shouts. “Hurry, throw it up or—”

“Calm down,” Kokichi says. “And doing stuff like that would ruin the point. But, ugh,” he brings a hand to his forehead. “I’m already all dizzy. I guess at least it didn’t lie about being stronger in large doses.”

“How much time do you have?” Ryoma asks, obviously trying to keep his voice even.

“Not a lot,” Kokichi says. “Which means Monokuma-chan better hurry up if he wants to kill me.”

Kaito just stares in horror. “Kokichi, how could you—”

Kokichi suddenly jerks as he coughs into his hand, and the familiar image of blood on his hand and running from his mouth somehow makes him grin. “Hey, look, Kaito. We match.”

The sight is enough to make Monokuma scramble back to his chair to press his big red button to start the execution.

The last thing Kaede hears before it begins is Kaito calling, “Wait, Kokichi—!”

Then,


GAME OVER 

KOKICHI OMA HAS BEEN FOUND GUILTY 

TIME FOR THE PUNISHMENT 

King of Lies: The New Burning of the Versailles Witch 

Kokichi doesn’t resist as the stage starts to build itself around him, nor does he struggle as a sea of Monokuma like spectators emerge to separate him from the others. Up on his platform, Kaede realizes he’s leaning against a large wooden stake and the way back down has been replaced with piles and piles of branches. Even as Kokichi calmly keeps his hands folded in front of him, Kaede feels something sick rise up in her stomach.

Tsumugi voices her thoughts aloud, mumbling to herself, “he’s going to be burned alive…”

The words set something off in Kaito, and Kaede only hears him say under his breath, “like hell he is,” before he takes off towards the crowd of Monokumas.

Kaede only blinks as he runs past her, bodily pushing against each and every Monokuma slowing his progress. “Kaito!” Tenko calls out. “Kaito!”

Tenko keeps yelling for him to stop as she quickly follows through his roughly cleared trail towards Kokichi. The thought forces Kaede to tear her eyes away from Kaito—even as he shouts for Kokichi to hold on and that he’s coming—towards the pyre. Then she sees it: a masked Monokuma bearing a torch flickering bright red against the rather murky medieval inspired backdrop.

Kaede gasps, bringing her hands to cover her mouth in horror. Kaito starts shouting louder, pushing harder against the Monokumas daring to stand between him and Kokichi. And Kokichi seems oddly peaceful. At this distance, she can barely see a slight sheen of sweat beginning to manifest on his pale forehead, but what catches her attention more is the thin line of blood beginning to run from the corner of his mouth down his chin.

The flames keep rising closer and closer, and Kaede can barely force herself to look as Kaito finally reaches the base of Kokichi’s pyre now completely engulfed in fire.

To Kokichi, the world slowly blurs with the poison running brightly through his system, and he looks down through the haze of smoke and fire when Kaito calls his name.

“Kokichi!” he shouts. “Just hold on a little longer!”

The words mean little to Kokichi as the slight blood running from his mouth grows and begins to stain his uniform as it drips off of him. The fires around him are raging stronger and stronger, but Kaito still tries to move closer.

Kokichi hears him hiss once at drawing too near, but he keeps going even as Tenko screams that he’s hurting himself. She tries to pull him away, but he fights against her grip, and through the daze, Kokichi sees Kaito’s hand reaching out towards him even from so far away.

In his poison addled mind, all Kokichi can think is that’s a nice last thing to see.

The flames barely begins to graze against the soles of his shoes when Kokichi closes his eyes and his hands held clasped in front of him droop down to his sides.

Kaito keeps shouting, somehow becoming more desperate in his goal once Kokichi stops moving while Tenko tries her best to restrain him from attempting to climb through the fire. The crowds of Monokumas seem to dissipate all at once, and Kaede hears a few grumbled words of frustration about being deprived of a proper execution.

With them gone, any grandeur or showiness the execution had fades into nothing, and Kaede is left standing watching Kaito finally collapse, his chest heaving with coughs or sobs or a combination of both while Tenko frantically hovers over him. Kokichi’s still body goes up in flames, and the sick smell of burning flesh that Kaede remembers all to clearly from Shuichi’s execution rushes over her, making her stomach twist and her throat feel sour and rotten.

She takes her eyes off Kokichi’s body again to see Tenko trying to urgently get Kaito back onto his feet even as he refuses to cooperate with her, all the while chanting at him not to look. Kaede watches the miserable scene before her, sees the blood and the tears and the burns when Kaito finally lets Tenko act as his crutch. Tenko shouts to the others that they need to get back to the school so she can help him, and Kaede nods along numbly, allowing herself to be herded into the elevator with the others.

Kaede keeps watching Kaito even as he goes quiet—accepting his place to just hang off of Tenko. She remembers being so angry at him before the trial. Wanting to hurt him and show him he was wrong and rub it in his face.

Kaito shudders when Tenko shifts slightly, and Kaede can’t tell if it’s from pain or an attempt to disguise another sob. Kaede can’t tell if it’s possible for her to feel anger anymore. She at least knows she doesn’t feel it at him.

No one protests the walk to the dorms, and the only speech directed towards hers is when Kiibo springs to life again, and Tenko seems slightly frazzled as she hands him to Kaede. “Please, could you take this? Tenko really needs to—”

“Of course,” Kaede says.

Tenko gives her a grateful smile. Kaito doesn’t say anything.

The two disappear into Tenko’s room, and neither Ryoma nor Tsumugi seem inclined to start any conversation as Kaede heads back to her own room. Inside, she takes a deep breath before saying, “What is it, Kiibo?”

“I am sorry if I am interrupting anything, Kaede,” he says. “But I believe there is something I need to tell you.”

“Yeah?” she says, still distracted with the events of trial burning in her mind.

“Last night I was finally able to execute the code I was unsure about,” Kiibo says. “And I am finally comfortable saying this aloud as I believe there is no longer anything Monokuma can do about it.”

That catches Kaede’s attention a bit more as she stares down at him. “Really?”

“After the loss of my body, but before her death,” he says. “Miu went to what I have learned from my file gathering is something called the ‘Mother Monokuma.’ From there, she set up everything I would need to remotely access the network at a later date, helped by the fact that as a monopad, I am already semi-connected to the school’s system.”

Kaede nods. “That sounds… good, I think?”

“I believe it is,” Kiibo says. “And I also believe I am secured enough now that Monokuma cannot so easily remove me. With this, I think it could potentially be our key to ending the killing game. And…” he pauses. “From the data I have gathered, I also think I have discovered the identity of the mastermind.”

Kaede takes a deep breath.

“Would you like to hear it?” Kiibo asks.

“No, it’s okay,” Kaede says. “I think I already know.”

Chapter End Notes

I wanted this chapter out earlier but then it turned into the longest chapter in this fic by far, haha. Anyway, this has been a fun chapter that I've definitely seen a lot of theories for including some people who figured me out almost immediately! But whether you predicted it right away or weren't thinking too much about specifics, I hope you enjoyed the chapter! Also to anyone wondering, Celeste's execution has always been one of my favorites, haha.

Next chapter is also going to be bonus chapter featuring the scenes Kaede would have gotten if she had certain items, and I am also going to take that opportunity to link as much of the wonderful fan art I have gotten as I can! I have quite a few links collected already, but if I don't have yours, please just let me know in a comment on either this chapter or the next one since I would love to share it!

II

Chapter Notes
