“Well, there could be if you let slip who I am,” Tsumugi says. “But then someone will be executed and we’ll be down to three. Assuming Monokuma can get his act together and kill Maki.”

“I’m working on it!” The Mother Monokuma huffs. “There’s a process to these things, you know!”

Kaede keeps her glare locked firmly on Tsumugi. “So you agree then—there’s no reason for there to be another trial.”

“Well,” Tsumugi says. “Not a new trial, no. But the sixth trial is meant to be special, and there’s definitely precedent for retrials, so I figured why not?”

Many things about her cavalier statement strike Kaede, and her questions come out rapid fire. “Precedent? You mean the two killing games from forever ago? And how the hell can there be a retrial for anything? Isn’t that admitting that we got the culprit wrong?”

“Kaede,” Tsumugi says. “I’m not going to answer any of your questions now, but I want you to hold on to that shot put ball and just think it over, okay? There was… one thing I was considering doing to add in a red herring, but it just seems silly now.”

“What’s even the point in trying to trick me now?” Kaede asks. “I already know your plan.”

Tsumugi’s smile is sympathetic. “You definitely know more than you should, I’ll give you that. And this was going to be a last minute trick about the mastermind, so it wouldn’t do anything for you.” She laughs. “And it’s pretty ridiculous, too—more of an in joke than anything to take seriously.”

Kaede doesn’t share her humor. “What about you trying to trick us is so funny?”

Tsumugi waves her hand. “Oh, I think trying to convince you that you have a twin sister who somehow snuck into the game or faked her death or something and is the mastermind is pretty funny. You didn’t see the Hope’s Peak Flashback Light, though, so you probably just think it’s weird.”

“I do think that’s weird,” Kaede says. “And is something that stupid really supposed to be convincing to anyone?”

“Eh, kinda,” Tsumugi says. “If you meet up with Ryoma, ask him about Enoshima Junko’s twin sister. Maybe he can explain why it’s so funny—though I guess if it needs an explanation, it’s really not that great of a joke, huh?”

Kaede doesn’t even bother to voice her disapproval, and Tsumugi laughs at her glare. “Well,” Tsumugi continues, “I need to be heading back now anyway if I don’t want to seem completely suspicious.”

She moves to leave, and Kaede blocks her path. “No—you’re going to answer me right now.”

Tsumugi quirks an eyebrow. “Okay. And you’re going to bash me over the head if I don’t?”

Kaede suddenly becomes very aware of the intensity of her grip on the shot put. “I… could.”

“You really shouldn’t,” Tsumugi says, pouting. “If you did then you coming this far would be kind of meaningless. Escaping death for the entire game just to be executed right at the very end?”

“I,” Kaede says. “I’m not afraid to die. And I’m not afraid of your executions either.”

Tsumugi rolls her eyes. “It’s not about you—it’s about me. I can’t have you die right before the end.” She starts to leave the room again, and this time Kaede doesn’t stop her. “And the only person getting executed at the end is me, alright?”

Kaede watches her back until she disappears around the corner and back out into the library. The Mother Monokuma chuckles in the distance. “Well, this has certainly been an adventure. But I guess that was to be suspected with a mastermind who can barely hold things together. To be honest, I’m just happy the game got this far at all.” It lets out a sigh. “They just don’t make despair like they used to. Where’s Enoshima Junko when you need her?”

Something about its tone catches Kaede’s attention as odd. “Hey,” she says, addressing the giant robotic bear head. “By the way, who actually is this Enoshima Junko person? The others said she orchestrated the two previous killing games, but… does she actually have anything to do with us? If Tsumugi’s the mastermind then is she a Remnant of Despair or one of Enoshima Junko’s followers?”

It laughs in response. “You know, I think that’s just fun enough a question that I’ll answer—mostly because it has a really fun answer. Little miss mastermind is not a Remnant of Despair, but she definitely is a follower of Enoshima-san.”

Kaede raises an eyebrow. “Do you… know Enoshima Junko?”

“Of course I do,” the Mother Monokuma says. “Everyone in the world knows her. Everyone in the outside world, everyone in this world—Enoshima Junko practically is this world after all.”

“I meant do you know her personally?” Kaede asks, suspicions rising at the strange declaration. 

“You could say that,” it says. “Where there’s Monokuma there’s Enoshima Junko!”

“But she’s been dead for years,” Kaede says. “And you just said she’s not running this killing game.”

It laughs again. “And that’s true, too! I haven’t said a single lie in this conversation, but you’re even more baffled than before, right? I told you your question had a fun answer!”

Kaede hears another distant explosion punctuating her bringing a hand to her forehead. “Alright, this is going nowhere—I’m leaving.”

It keeps chuckling to itself as Kaede takes a moment to deposit the shot put ball in her bag. The motion makes her stomach turn, but she swallows her discomfort as she picks her way through the room, hesitating for a second in indecision before heading out through the secret passage. 

Kaede keeps a rough count of how long the journey takes her, noting the time amounts to very little when she reaches the girls’ bathroom. She exits the room, and the school seems to shake again. Down the hall, she hears a startled grunt and turns to see Ryoma slightly off kilter from the most recent explosion. 

“Ryoma,” she says, heading over to him. “Are you alright?”

“Yeah,” he says dazed. “‘m fine. I’m… fine.”

His response makes Kaede think he is decidedly not fine. “Are you sure? You seem…” she takes a second to really look him over and notices he seems far more disoriented than what the slight tremor running through the school would cause. “Kind of out of it.”

“Would say that sounds about right,” Ryoma says. “Found this Flashback Light a while ago, and it keeps messing with my head.”

“A Flashback Light?” Kaede asks. “What did you remember?”

“Nothing at first,” Ryoma says. “But ever since I used it, I keep getting these weird flashes of memories.”

“Oh, like a delayed reaction?” she says. “I’m sorry it’s messing with you though—now’s really not a great time to randomly be blacking out.”

He shakes his head. “It’s really not, but the memories aren’t unpleasant. There was one where some kid was talking about… how we’re all heroes or something. And another where… it was all of us—including everyone who died—together in some weird room, talking about how we were going to all be friends.”

“Oh…” Kaede says. “That does sound pretty nice. Kinda wish I saw it, too, actually.”

A grim expression stretches over Ryoma’s face at her words. “Not sure about that. But…” he pauses for a moment, seeing to debate something before pulling out what Kaede recognizes as another Flashback Light. “There is a second Flashback Light that I… found.”

“You sound unsure about that,” Kaede says. “Do you think it’s a fake like the one that said I was the mastermind?”

“Just,” he says. “Just try it.”

Ryoma flicks it on without waiting for a response, and suddenly Kaede’s world goes white, then bright gold, then black. Then she’s filled with memories of other Ultimates all also going off on their own spaceships on separate missions. There are other survivors out there like them, but it was classified information that only the participants of the Gopher Project knew.

Then the world fades back in. Ryoma’s still standing there, his mouth pressed into a thin line at the positive news. “We’re…” Kaede says. “We’re not the only survivors. Are the others the ones Monokuma is broadcasting the killing game to?”

“No,” Ryoma says. “Seriously doubt that.”

“Oh,” Kaede says. “Did you find more evidence?”

“Well,” he says. “Have the evidence that I made this Flashback Light.”

Kaede blinks at him and takes another look at the Flashback Light as if registering it for the first time. “You—how did you just…”

“The school’s pretty destroyed now,” Ryoma says. “And was wandering around when I found a room that had the door and part of the wall gone. Inside there was also this weird technology stuff.”

“Wait, which classroom was this?” Kaede asks. “I feel like we would have noticed stuff like that when we first explored the school.”

“Just one of the regular classrooms,” Ryoma says. “No idea how it all got there or we missed it or whatever. But it looked like a workstation or something to create Flashback Lights, and, well,” he gestures to the one in his hand, “I made this one.”

Kaede nods. “So they are just being made in the school by the mastermind.”

“Seems like it,” Ryoma says. “And the happy one I was talking about—found it when I finished making this one. My guess is the mastermind prepped it, but then never got around to using it for some reason.”

“So the mastermind wanted to give us weird, encouraging messages for some reason?” Kaede asks. “I mean, you did just happen to find it, right?”

He shakes his head. “No. When I made the Flashback Light I showed you, it appeared in a locker. That’s how I found the first one—it was already there.”

“So the one you saw was created the same way the one you made was?” Kaede asks. “That must be the place they’re produced then.”

“Think so,” Ryoma says before casting his gaze down to the Flashback Light. “And starting to think that all the Flashback Lights are fake. If I could make one to say whatever I wanted, the mastermind definitely has been.”

“I was afraid of something like that,” Kaede says. “So—I’m kinda even more afraid to ask this but—how far back do you think our fake memories go? If all of the Flashback Lights have been fake, then we don’t know anything about the outside world or why we’re here.”

Ryoma lets out a breath. “Saw the destroyed world for myself, but… if Monokuma’s able to bring in all these copies there has to be the manpower to manufacture Monokumas on the outside. And that’s not a good sign.”

“Yeah,” Kaede agrees. “Because wouldn’t that mean… the outside world is on Monokuma’s side? If no one’s rescued us, they’re actively supplying Monokuma, and just watching us…”

“Just what the hell is the world like?” Ryoma asks.

Kaede’s voice drops a few decibels, barely rising over the sounds of fighting from outside when she responds, “I don’t know.”

“And who the hell are we?” Ryoma asks. 

“I don’t know that either,” Kaede says. “I still have my memories from home, but there’s nothing I remember like Monokuma or the killing game.”

Ryoma takes a moment before asking the question Kaede didn’t know she had been dreading. “Think those are fake, too?”

“The first Flashback Light was the group funeral, right? Or was it us running from the Ultimate Hunt? I don’t remember, but,” Kaede says. “Those were the earliest Flashback Lights—so our memories from before those have to be right. Those are real.”

Ryoma doesn’t seem as convinced as Kaede hoped her false confidence would make him. His next words do nothing to quell her unease as he asks, “Kaede—one more thing. Was… there ever a moment when you tried to remember how you got here and just…”

He trails off, and Kaede feels a lump form in her throat as she knows exactly what he’s talking about. “Did your head start hurting really badly, too?”

Ryoma nods somberly. “Don’t know what the hell we got mixed up in, but I think it’s a lot worse than we thought.” He lets out a humorless laugh. “Never thought that a game where we’re forced to kill each other could somehow be even worse.”

“Yeah,” Kaede says. “But… there’s going to be no more murders. Not after today. So,” she summons her best smile, “I want you to remember that promise I made on the first day here. When we do get out of here, we’re all going to be friends, alright, Ryoma?”

And despite the darkness of the conversation, Ryoma smiles back. “Personally, I’d say we’re already friends, Kaede. Or at least friendly acquaintances.”

“I’m glad to hear that,” Kaede says. 

In the ruins of the school, their shared moment is interrupted by a click Kaede has come to recognize means Kiibo has taken over one of the monitors. “Kaede, Ryoma,” he says. “Tenko has almost finished her preparations, however, she could use more assistance for the final step.”

“Tsumugi not enough help?” Ryoma asks. 

Kaede bites her lip as Kiibo flatly replies. “No.”

Ryoma gives the monitor a dubious stare as Kiibo abruptly turns himself off. Kaede quickly finds her own explanation. “He’s probably just busy helping Maki and Kaito.”

“Right,” Ryoma says, suspicion lingering in his voice.

The walk back through the school requires a few stops for them to push the newly created rubble to clear a path. The entire outside of the school appears in ruins, though the commotion appears to be gone. Kaede still hears the distant noise of gunshots and guesses the fight has moved to the lower courtyard, closer to Kiibo’s lab. She bites her lip, wondering if she should have done something to stop Tsumugi from speaking to the Mother Monokuma when she had the chance.

Beside her, Ryoma says, “Think we’re clear until we reach the stairs. After that,” he shrugs. “It’ll probably be a lot worse.”

Kaede nods in agreement, and they begin their trek over the scorched ground of their former prison. She notes the destroyed remains of the gardens and sheds that she had once frequented lying in heaps next to a variety of destroyed Monokuma vehicles. She briefly searches for the remains of a purple Exisal and feels a rush of relief at finding no signs of it.

From the top of the stairs leading down, Kaede sees the full picture of the scene below. Monokuma’s original tank has taken a beating but appears to still be functional enough to continue engaging in its firefight with Kaito. The Exisal darts around Tenko’s lab, and Kaede gets a clear view of another one of Monokuma’s missiles ripping through the once beautiful dojo. 

She watches the building fall for a brief moment before Ryoma mumbles to himself, “Where’s Maki?”

His words alert Kaede that Maki is nowhere to be seen. “Maybe she’s already inside of Kiibo’s lab? He said Tenko needed extra help, so maybe Maki—”

“No,” Ryoma says, pointing out towards Kiibo’s lab, or more specifically, the roof of it. “There.”

Kaede had never thought someone could stand atop Kiibo’s lab from the spherical shape of the roof, but there Maki was kneeling next to a makeshift looking antenna behind her. The rather comically macabre image of Kiibo’s head on a spike is somehow overshadowed by the sheer rush of nerves Kaede suddenly feels. 

Ryoma says, “Looks like Tsumugi and Tenko got out of the building though…”

Kaede spares a glance away from Maki to see the two girls standing at the base of the lab, Tenko furiously checking her monopad for something. Kiibo decides to speak up from Kaede’s monopad as well at that moment, and after quickly retrieving him from her backpack, he says, “Kaede, Ryoma, you are currently standing in the open and might want to find cover.”

“Is there going to be more fighting?” Kaede asks.

“I have conferred with Maki and we are both unsure what Monokuma’s response is going to be once the message begins,” he explains. “In the event that it is violent, he will likely be targeting Maki, and it is necessary she exposes herself while the signal is being broadcast. Kaito will attempt to preoccupy Monokuma, but…”

“It’s dangerous for us to just stand here,” Ryoma says. “And you’re arguing with Tenko down there about it, too, huh?”

Kiibo sighs. “She is rather persistent, though I do not know how she is intending to do anything against Monokuma’s weaponry.”

“Hey, Kiibo,” Kaede says. “Just… don’t worry about us—we’re not gonna die. Focus on Maki.”

Ryoma doesn’t know the hidden meaning of her words, but he nods in agreement anyway. “Yeah, your first priority is the person being shot at.”

“I know,” Kiibo says. “And also Maki is informing me she is ready. We are going to reverse the signal and instead of receiving messages, send one ourselves. And… I have also taken the liberty to make a bit of a show of it. Just to make sure the message gets across.”

Kaede’s about to ask what he means when the walls of dome, previously projecting the day time sky are suddenly plastered with Maki’s face.

Kaede watches in awe—distantly hearing Monokuma shriek as Kaito’s Exisal all but tackles his tank. Maki fidgets slightly, also probably taking in the sight of herself across the sky. “Well,” she says. “I suppose that says everything I need to. But I am alive—Kokichi was innocent, and Monokuma, the mastermind, and everyone else running this game broke their rules to execute him. You’ve already seen his fate, and seeing me here is more than enough evidence to prove that this game is invalid.”

Monokuma’s tank gets a shot off, and a missile flies wildly, far over Maki’s head and careening into the dome. The resulting impact obviously shakes her, but Maki doesn’t move from her spot as she continues. “Monokuma is currently trying to kill me to cover up his mistake—this game is flawed and the mastermind has regularly been trying to cover up the truth since the very beginning. Even if you are enjoying this, everything you’re watching is a lie—if my death was a mistake, what other mysteries has Monokuma faked? How long has he been hiding the truth?”

Monokuma screams, “The truth doesn’t matter!” in between blows of Kaito’s Exisal. 

“I know now that you cannot destroy a game by working within its rules,” Maki says. “So there will be no more murders, no more victims, no more executions. Even if we all die, we refuse to play this game, and if you care about our lives in whatever twisted way, you care that we die fair. And that has not been happening.”

“Then there will be a retrial!” Monokuma shouts. “That’s it—a bear can fix his mistakes!”

Maki pays him no heed. “Maybe we are just race horses for you to bet on for who lives and who dies—but know that even that has been ruined for you. You cannot trust the killing game now, or as it was, or whatever happens in the future for it. This killing game and every killing game to come is now over.”

“And I’ll fix my mistake right—now!” Monokuma finishes, and another volley of missiles soar through the sky. The Exisal slams into the tank as it fires, sending the shots slightly off kilter but, Kaede realizes with absolute horror, not quite enough.

The shots tear through Kiibo’s lab and Miu’s below. Maki’s face flickers from the impassive expression she had been wearing for the entire broadcast to let out a brief gasp as the roof she had been standing on falls out from under her.

The walls of the dome buzz with a newly displayed static. Everything feels like it’s moving in slow motion from how Kaede’s legs seem to refuse to move fast enough to the collapsing building to another shot that causes the base of Miu’s lab to crumple in on itself even more so.

“Maki!” Kaito shouts, and the Exisal abandons its fight with Monokuma to race over to the remains of the two labs.

Kaede hears Tenko scream, too, and sees her speed towards the rubble. Tsumugi follows nervously behind her, also calling out in worry. Monokuma stops his assault to laugh, chanting provocations that everyone ignores.

Tenko and Tsumugi had been the closest and make it to Maki’s side first. Tenko shoves aside some of the wreckage with a bit of difficulty, Tsumugi hovering at her side. Then Kaito, hoping out of the Exisal in a panic, rushes over to try and assist her. It’s only when Kaede is at the edge of the remains of the building does she what they’re shoving at.

Maki sits up, cradling one of her arms so Kaede can’t see the full extent of the damage. But what Kaede can see is a rather nasty head wound trickling blood down her forehead and a huge slab of concrete completely burying one of her legs from the knee down. From the few grimaces she lets slip as Tenko and Kaito push fruitlessly to try and free her, Kaede gets the feeling that Maki isn’t in any condition to walk under her own power, let alone make the expert dodges she had before. 

And as Ryoma joins Kaede at her side, Maki voices her thoughts aloud. “Stop it,” she says. “You’re just wasting your own energy.”

“Shut up,” Kaito says. “We’re not just leaving you to die here.”

“It doesn’t matter if I live or die,” Maki says. “What matters is that you escape. If you stay here and let yourselves get killed, then everything I’ve done will have been for nothing.”

“Maki,” Kaito says, near breathless, and it’s then Kaede fully takes in the dried blood on his shirt and smeared around his mouth. “I already thought you died once. I’m not going through that again.”

Maki gives him a hard look, her mouth pressing into a tight line. 

Tenko stops her struggling then and moves to stand in front of Maki’s position, arms held stretched out on either side. She says, “Monokuma, Maki’s broadcast succeeded and whoever is watching us knows she is alive. There is no point or reason to kill her now.”

“No reason?” Monokuma calls out. “Why, she committed grievous acts of violence against the headmaster, and that, children, is against the rules!”

“She didn’t kill you though,” Kaede says. “You fought, but she never destroyed you. Kiibo told us that there is only one Monokuma now, so if you’re here then—”

“And I attacked you, too!” Kaito shouts. “So if you wanna kill Maki, you’re gonna have to kill me, too.”

Maki hisses in pain as she shifts to grab at Kaito’s pant leg. “Stop it. I’m telling you to—”

“Also,” Ryoma says. “Do you really want to be caught breaking your rules again right after that announcement?”

Monokuma pauses to grumble before says, “well, I also now feel the need to inform all of you that attendance at all class trials is mandatory! No ifs ands or buts!” 

“But no one else is dead!” Tenko says. “You can’t just—”

The all too familiar chime announcing the end of an investigation echoes around them. Monokuma says, “as the game master, I reserve to hold a retrial for a trial gone wrong.”

“You can’t redo Maki’s trial without her,” Kaito says. “I know what you’re trying to do and—”

“In a few short moments,” Monokuma says. “We will be holding a retrial for the murder of Rantaro Amami. All students are asked to report to the trial grounds in order to commence. And if your leg just happens to be stuck with no way of escape under a giant rock, well then that sucks for you!”

He vanishes at the end of his speech, leaving the others to stare at each other. Tsumugi says softly, “what are we supposed to do now?”

Kaito starts to stomp back towards his Exisal. “We’re getting that boulder off of her and taking her with us.”

“Kaito,” Maki says.

“This thing took a beating,” he says. “But it’s still pretty strong—I think I can lift it off of her.”

“Kaito.”

“And then she’ll just have to lean on me or maybe Tenko through the trial. We just figure it all out fast and then find help for—”

“Kaito, I can’t feel my leg anymore,” Maki says. “Even if you were able to use the Exisal, it wouldn’t matter. I…” She takes a deep breath. “I am going to die whether Monokuma decides to kill me or not.”

Kaede tears her eyes away from Kaito to really take in Maki’s appearance. She seems paler by the second, and though her voice remains steady, Kaede can see her shaking. “Maki… you’re…”

“I knew I was likely to die as soon as I agreed to this plan,” Maki says. “And I knew I would be used up and then killed at some point as soon as I became an assassin. I never expected to make it through this game, so don’t feel sorry for me. Just get through the trial and survive.”

Tenko kneels at her side. “Tenko treated the others before maybe she can…” she pauses for a second to wipe at the tears brimming in her eyes. “Tenko can do something, and then you’ll make it through with the rest of us. We’re not sacrificing anyone anymore.”

Ryoma takes a step closer. “No,” he lets out a deep breath. “Maki is right. Trying to do anything would just prolong her pain. Know you’re all trying to be nice, but anything you do now isn’t a mercy.”

“I-Is she going to bleed out?” Tsumugi asks. “Or is she in shock? Is there anything we can do if she’s in shock? H-How do we know if someone’s in shock?”

As Tsumugi panics, Tenko very gently reaches forward to take the arm Maki had been holding close to her chest. Maki winces as Tenko’s fingers graze her mangled limb, and Kaede squeezes her eyes shut, not bearing to look at the sight. “I… I don’t want to abandon her either, but I think Ryoma is right. We… what are we supposed to do?”

“Well we’re not just fucking leaving her!” Kaito shouts. “We’re not—we’re not making it this far, losing her once, and then just deciding she’s dead!”

“Kaito,” Maki says. “Calm down and think about this rationally.”

“No!” he says. “You—you were the one who told me that throwing my life away was stupid, but you want me to just sit here and let you die alone?”

Maki lets out a deep breath. “You know I barely even had a life. This doesn’t mean the same thing it meant for the others who died. And you know I don’t care if I die alone.”

“Well I do!” Kaito says. “You’re my friend, and I promised that I was gonna stay with you until the fucking end of this thing!”

“And I promised Kokichi that you would live,” Maki says, an air of finality in her words. “It was part of our deal. So you’re going to go to the trial and stop wasting time here.”

Kaito falters for a second, clenching his jaw and his hands balling up into fists. Then he marches back over to Maki, kneeling at her other side and taking her uninjured hand. “Then I’m sorry I’m disappointing Kokichi. I already said it and I’ll say it again—I lost you once and I am not going through that again as long I live.”

“Kaito,” Kaede says. “Are you really…”

“Maki,” he says, grinning fondly as he shakes his head. “You’re an idiot if you think you’re the only person here who knows they’re not making it out of this game.”

Maki struggles slightly at his words, grimacing as she jostles her own injured limbs. “Kaito, I won’t let you—”

“As soon as I got this cough, all I could think is that if I was gonna die, I wanted it to mean something,” Kaito says. “You said your death doesn’t matter because you’re not a person, but, hey,” he smiles down at her, “I think spending my last breath telling you that’s not true—that would mean something, right?”

Maki’s voice is choked when she speaks next, and Kaede finds herself taken aback at a sight she thought was impossible. Maki shakes her head, the tears streaming freely down her face. “No! I already told you—I don’t want you to die! I don’t care if I’m alone—I don’t care who leaves me as long as…”

Her voice becomes more and more garbled and Kaede hears her whisper, “I don’t want you to die,” again before Kaito gingerly wraps his arms around her shaking shoulders.

Tenko’s crying, too. “Maki, Kaito… you’re both…”

“Yeah,” Kaito says. “Yeah, we are.” Maki hammers his chest with her good hand, and he wheezes at the contact. “Hey now, let me get a few more goodbyes in, Harumaki. We’re gonna go out like heroes, you know? And heroes always say goodbye.”

Kaede sees Maki shake her head again as the nickname seems to make her cry harder. “Did you make that up just now?” she asks, trying to keep her tone light even as her voice falters.

“Sure did,” he says with a grin. “Oh, and by the way, Kaede—you’re still angry, right? You’re still gonna fight Monokuma?”

Kaede nods, swallowing the lump in her throat. “I am.”

“Good,” Kaito says. “Then give ‘em hell for me. And you, too, Tenko. And Ryoma—let them know what you’re fighting for. And, hell, Tsumugi, too.”

“I-I’ll try,” Tsumugi stammers, and the false sympathy in her voice makes Kaede’s stomach turn.

Maki slams her hand into Kaito again, finding her voice as she says, “You—letting yourself die—you know that only makes my pain worse? Knowing that you’re dying because of me—”

“Maki,” he says. “You know I don’t have a lot of time left—I’m kinda fighting to even hold it together right now. So, the way I see it, I could spend my last few moments yelling at Monokuma,” he squeezes her hand. “Or I could spend them with you.”

Maki just shakes her head, but doesn’t say anything more after that, seemingly torn between being pained and relieved by the turn of events.

Ryoma says, “so you’re decided then—no changing your mind?”

“Nah,” Kaito says. 

“Alright,” he says before taking a deep breath. “Then…” he pauses, and Kaede realizes she has no idea what anyone is supposed to say when faced with such a horrible situation before them. “Take care.”

“Will do,” Kaito grins back.

Tenko’s still wiping at her eyes as she slowly lifts herself back to a standing position. Kaede moves over to support her, gently placing a hand on her back. To Kaito and Maki, Kaede says, “what we did mattered, and we’re going to make the mastermind and Monokuma—and everyone—knows that.”

“You bett—” Kaito cuts himself off as a cough racks his body. Maki shifts as much as she can to attend to him, even though there’s nothing either of them can do at this point.

It becomes clear his coughing fit is going to take a while. Maki pauses, then all the emotion that had burst out of her suddenly drains away in favor of her usual guarded expression. She nods to them. “Go—Monokuma won’t wait forever.”

Kaede nods back and forces herself to look away from them and make those first few steps out of the rubble. Tenko’s walking with her, and she hears Ryoma and Tsumugi’s footsteps behind, crunching the remains of the labs underneath them.

Kaito’s coughing, however, is the noise that follows her as they finally reach the landing before the elevator.

When there, Tenko tugs at her sleeve. “Kaede,” she says, voice still hoarse from crying. “Are you going to be okay?”

“I…” she says. The gravity of losing one of her first friends and her first rival at the academy still hasn’t hit her yet, and her voice is hollow when she replies. “I don’t know. They were…”

Tenko fidgets at her answer. “Tenko doesn’t know either, but… about the trial—Monokuma said it was going to be a retrial for Rantaro’s murder. Are you,” Kaede sees the fright in her eyes as Tenko drops her voice to a whisper, “are you going to be executed, too?”

Kaede feels her chest seize up at the thought. “I,” she glances over her shoulder to Tsumugi standing placidly behind them. “No—I-I don’t think that’s going to happen.”

“You’re sure?” Tenko says, still obviously terrified.

“I think so,” Kaede says. “Because… I don’t think I killed Rantaro.”

Chapter End Notes

A story I meant to tell at the end of last chapter but forgot is kind of what inspired Maki's death fake out. When V3 was first released in Japan, there were a ton of fake spoilers floating around, and my personal favorite is that Rantaro faked his death and hid in the vents since it gets sillier the more you try to think through the details. So for this chapter, I tried to think out a way where something like that could plausibly happen, and hopefully I did an alright enough of a job!

Trial XIII

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

The elevator doors slide shut behind the four of them. Processing what is happening right now in the school grounds is beyond Kaede. She doesn’t want to think about what kind of punishment Monokuma has for breaking the rules—if it’s more or less brutal than an execution. But whatever it is, it doesn’t seem real in the moment. It feels wrong not to stare at Kaito’s back as the elevator descends, but that doesn’t equate to him being dead in Kaede’s mind. She knows that will come later.

The trial room feels so empty. Last time, the sheer presence of the Exisal had accounted for their decreased numbers. Now Kaede takes her podium, pointedly aware of the crosshair painted over Maki’s face and the X splattered over Kaito’s. 

She glances across the room. Tsumugi looks at peace with the proceedings she and Kaede both know are leading to her demise. The calmness in the face of death, here, isn’t reassuring like Kokichi’s, Angie’s or Korekiyo’s parting before their executions. Instead it sends a chill through Kaede that she only shakes off when Monokuma starts to talk.

“Well now, well now, well now,” he says. “Seems only four of my five naughty students made it down to the trial. How unfortunate…”

“There were six of us,” Ryoma says coldly. “Stop trying to deny it.”

“Oh, but you see, this is the world of Monokuma, which means it’s my world!” Monokuma says. “And in my world, I decide what happens—get it? I hand out the rewards and the punishments, the trials and tribulations, the rules and regulations—”

“You don’t though,” Kaede says. “Someone else decided the rules of the game. Trying to follow them has been actively hurting you this whole time. There has to be some reason for handcuffing yourself like this.”

Monokuma brings his paws to his mouth. “Oh, someone’s excited. You just wanna get right to the good stuff, huh? Skip the foreplay and get right to the climax, huh? But,” his giggling fades as he brandishes his claws. “I’ve had enough of your sequence breaking for one game. Anymore and the whole thing falls apart, so you’re just gonna have to be patient and take things one step at a time. Speed running is strictly forbidden!”

“So we can’t just vote for who we think the mastermind is,” Tenko says. “We have to… do another trial even after Kokichi and Maki, and Kaito, too, all died to—”

“As a bonus for making it this far, however!” Monokuma says. “I will give you all a little hint just to spice things up as we dive into the truly mysterious trial of who killed Rantaro Amami, the Ultimate Something-Something.”

“Ultimate Survivor,” Ryoma says. “That’s not a mystery.”

Monokuma bulldozes over his comment. “There are four of you remaining! One of you… is a dirty, no good, traitorous mastermind who has been working against you the whole time!”

“We… know that, too,” Tsumugi says. 

“And,” Monokuma says. “I just think it’s a rather interesting little fact that we have one mastermind and three participants, here, but this game is only designed to have two survivors… I wonder what that despair-ful detail could mean.” 

Kaede pauses briefly before she shakes her head. “When we find the mastermind, the game is over. You can’t turn us against each other anymore, and we know your rules don’t mean anything.”

Monokuma gasps, offended. “My rules mean a great deal! They mean so much that I will not allow any more conversation that’s not about the untimely death of Rantaro Amami. They mean so much that there’s currently a truly brutal murder taking place right now!”

Kaede flinches. “You can’t just—”

“So on that fateful day, just what did happen? I have to admit, I am one curious bear!”

Kaede clenches her jaw, staring him down as if enough eye contact will reveal his true motives. 

“Um,” Tenko says. “Tenko knows that Shuichi wasn’t Rantaro’s real killer, but…” she shoots a nervous look to Kaede. “Tenko also thinks maybe we should just… leave it at that.”

Ryoma follows her gaze. “Have to agree,” he says. “Kaede’s right—we’re not about to betray each other.”

“Yeah,” Tsumugi says. “You’re just trying to trick us into sacrificing Kaede, and we’re not going to fall for it.”

Tsumugi coming to her defense as earnestly as Ryoma and Tenko unsettles Kaede, and it’s all she can do to keep her attention on Monokuma. “Oh?” he says. “I’m trying to trick you? Is that what you all think?”

“Yeah, we do, but,” Kaede says. “This ‘trick’ isn’t about me, is it? Shuichi was innocent—there’s no doubt about that—but… you’re trying to get us to ask the wrong questions.”

“Huh?” Tsumugi says. “Really? I mean, I believe you, but what are the ‘right’ questions then?”

“Not whoever killed Rantaro,” Tenko says quickly. “We don’t need to talk about that.”

“Tenko,” Kaede says. “It’s okay—Monokuma’s not about to do anything to hurt me now. It wouldn’t fit with whatever he’s trying to accomplish.”

Ryoma gives her an odd look. “Alright then. Does that mean it’s fine to figure out what happened to Rantaro, or is that what Monokuma wants us to do?”

Kaede knows the answer is both, but she replies, “I’m not sure, but I do think it’s necessary that we confirm who killed Rantaro just… to clear up any remaining doubts.”

“Ah, yes,” Monokuma says. “Clearing the sullied name of your beloved—truly a task any love struck heroine would be up for.”

Kaede scowls at him. “Can you just shut up?”

“Um,” Tsumugi says. “I think Monokuma’s being pretty rude, too, but if we just keep arguing with him, we’re not really going to get anywhere are we?”

The real question, which Kaede hears Tenko softly mutter to herself, “what are we trying to get to?” isn’t the most pressing. 

(Present your Argument) 

“At the first trial,” Tsumugi begins. “We thought Shuichi was the culprit, but that wasn’t right, was it?”

“Kaede proved she did it,” Ryoma says. “There was a trap in the library or something.”

“The culprit doesn’t matter,” Tenko says. “No one should be punished.”

“Tenko, I said it’s fine,” Kaede says. “Because even though what happened is my fault, I… have new evidence now.”

“You found something else out about Rantaro’s murder?” Ryoma asks, clearly dubious of her claim. “How?”

Tsumugi comes to her defense, “I’d like to know that, too, but what even is the evidence you found? Does it tell us who really killed Rantaro?”

“If it does,” Tenko says. “Then Tenko would prefer not to talk about it. Tenko doesn’t think she can make herself vote for anyone to die again…”

“I’m,” Kaede says. “I’m sorry you feel that way, but I’m not sure if that’s a possibility.”

There’s a fleeting look of something conflicted in Tenko’s eyes, but she says nothing.

(BREAK) 

“What I found isn’t enough on its own to prove who Rantaro’s true killer is,” Kaede says. “But it’s enough to prove it isn’t me.”

“Still don’t understand how you just stumbled upon something like that,” Ryoma says. “A lot of time has passed since Rantaro’s case, and Monokuma cleans up evidence after we’re done investigating a murder. Not to mention that the school was being destroyed.”

“Oh,” Monokuma says. “Are you saying it almost sounds like the evidence had to be handed to Kaede?”

Kaede glares at him. “You’re not part of this debate. And to answer your question,” she turns back to Ryoma, “I found it somewhere we weren’t able to explore before. The school being destroyed actually helped in this case.”

“Some place we weren’t able to explore before…” Tsumugi says. “The only place I can think of is the secret door in the library. Is that it?”

Being helped by Tsumugi makes Kaede’s stomach churn, but she still pushes ahead. “That’s right. Like Ryoma said, the school was falling apart, and the door got damaged badly enough that I was able to get inside.”

“And there was evidence about what happened to Rantaro in there?” Tenko asks. “In the mastermind’s secret room? Is that also where Himiko…”

“Yeah,” Kaede says softly. “I think so…”

“Tenko sees…” she says. “The mastermind probably killed Rantaro, too, then.”

“I think they did,” Kaede says. “Because in a trashcan in that room, I found a shot put ball just like the one I thought I killed Rantaro with.” She shakes her head. “No, not just like the one I used—it was the one I used. It even had a fiber from one of my vests still stuck to it.”

Tsumugi nods. “So the weapon you used and the one we found at the scene of the crime were different? And someone able to get into the mastermind’s room took the shot put you had used?”

“That’s right,” Kaede says.

“Hold on,” Ryoma says. “Something’s… weird about this.”

“Huh?” Tsumugi says. “There is? I plainly haven’t noticed anything.”

“It’s what Kaede said,” he answers. “She said she got into the secret room where Himiko was killed, but, Kaede, you already knew about that room. During… Gonta’s trial, you said that you, Miu, and Kokichi were the only ones who knew. So this wasn’t the first time you went there.”

Kaede fiddles with the bill of her hat, shifting it to cover a bit more of her face. “No, it wasn’t.”

“So we could access the room before the school was destroyed?” Tenko asks. “Then wouldn’t Kaede have found the shot put before…” she trails off, and Kaede can tell it’s not out of confusion but a want to reach the conclusion.

“It’s… kind of complicated,” Kaede says. “I found a secret passage in the girls’ bathroom with Miu a while ago that led to the secret room. I just didn’t know at the time that it was the same room that was in the library.”

“Then are two ways to get to the mastermind’s secret room?” Tsumugi asks. “The one in the library and the one you and Miu found earlier?”

“But you didn’t find the shot put the first time you went there?” Ryoma asks. “Didn’t you say it was just in a trashcan?”

“That… does seem strange,” Tenko concedes. “Did Kaede just not check the trashcan the first time?”

Kaede squeezes her eyes shut. “No, I did. And it was empty the first time.”

“But you checked it again when you went the second time,” Tenko says. “And there was evidence about Rantaro’s case in it?”

“That is plainly strange, isn’t it?” Tsumugi says.

“Hmm, I wonder what that could mean,” Monokuma says.

Ryoma sighs at Monokuma’s response. “That’s not a good sign. Kaede, I don’t think you’re the mastermind—the fake Flashback Light that tried to make us think you were a Remnant of Despair wouldn’t make any sense if you were. But you have to tell us why he keeps saying things like that.”

Kaede’s gaze briefly flickers to Monokuma, obviously enjoying himself, and the glee on his robotic face is more than enough for her to make up her mind. “You were right with you said earlier, Ryoma. Finding evidence for Rantaro’s case at this point when Monokuma was planning to hold a retrial for him is too weird to be a coincidence. When I went to the secret room the second time, I was directed basically handed new evidence that the mastermind put out for us to find for this trial.”

Tenko’s eyes widen. “So discovering Rantaro’s killer is all part of the mastermind’s plan. Th-Then Tenko thinks we should stop this trial right now. We promised Maki and Kaito we weren’t going to play the mastermind’s game anymore, and Tenko—”

“But wait,” Tsumugi interrupts. “I don’t get it—are you saying the mastermind wants us to reveal them? But doesn’t that stop the game?”

“I don’t know anymore,” Kaede says. 

Ryoma scowls. “There’s something wrong with this trial. We’re stuck in some trap, aren’t we?”

“Monokuma wants to trick us into executing someone,” Tenko says. “Kaede has proof that she’s innocent, so Monokuma is trying to force her into killing one of us.”

Kaede says softly, “Monokuma isn’t forcing me to do anything…”

Tsumugi either doesn’t hear her or pretends not to. “Oh, I think I understand what’s happening. Monokuma is using Rantaro and Shuichi’s deaths to blackmail Kaede.”

“That,” Ryoma says. “Could be true. Kaede, you’ve had the weight of their deaths over you this whole time, haven’t you? Wouldn’t blame you if you wanted to set things right.”

Kaede bites her lip. “I don’t know about that.”

“Kaede and Shuichi were close,” Tenko says. “Tenko wants to find Himiko’s true killer… so she understands. The only person here to blame is the mastermind.”

“That’s true,” Tsumugi says. “If what Kaede said was true about there being two murder weapons, and one of them was found in a place only the mastermind could access, then the mastermind has to be the one who really killed Rantaro.” She hugs her arm. “And they covered up their crime and executed poor Shuichi for it.”

“Tenko understands, then,” Tenko says. “This is for Shuichi’s sake—and Rantaro’s, too.”

Kaede pauses for a moment, then, she reaches up to take off her hat. 

It feels a bit odd coming off, her hair clinging to it and rising up to give her what Kaede knows is particularly bad hat hair. Tenko stares at her wide eyed, but Tsumugi is the one to say, “Kaede? What are you—”

“Shuichi didn’t kill Rantaro,” Kaede says. “You all already know that he lied at the trial because he wanted to save me. I was stupid and reckless… and I got him and Rantaro killed—no matter what Monokuma says about the true culprit of this case or whatever, what happened to them is still my fault.” Her grip on the hat tightens just a little, and Kaede knows her words are meant mostly for herself even as she feels compelled to say them aloud. “Kaito gave this to me to be nice, but…”

“Kaede,” Tenko says. “Tenko said this before, but you can wear it for whatever reason you want.”

Kaede gives her a sympathetic smile. “I know, and I think I have. I think I’ve been doing it to punish myself. Shuichi—and Rantaro, too—aren’t… real to me. I don’t think any of us knew them long enough to actually know them as people.”

“Oh,” Tsumugi says. “That’s kinda sad.”

“It’s true, though,” Ryoma says. “Sometimes people can come to mean something to you fast, but also when you’re just surrounded by death, it’s hard to know what you’re really missing.”

“I don’t think I could have said it better,” Kaede says. “They didn’t deserve to die, and it’s wrong that they died so I could live, but to the mastermind, to whoever is watching us, they’re not people to them either, are they? No one who died is. They’re all just punishments. That’s why we have these stupid trials and these horrible executions because someone wants to see us suffer and they’re—they’re,” Kaede’s fists clench and it takes all of her self control not to just throw the hat in her hand at Monokuma, “they’re getting off on making us miserable—on seeing us make friends so it’ll hurt more when they’re ripped away, and I refuse to be part of that anymore!”

Monokuma sighs. “Blah, blah, blah, ‘you won’t betray each other anymore.’ You said that already. You’re boring m—”

“You can’t control me anymore,” Kaede says. “You’re making us go over Rantaro’s case again to torture me for your stupid audience, and I’m not putting up with it anymore.”

“Kaede?” Tsumugi says. “Are you… not participating then? I mean, I get what you’re saying, but our lives are still on the line. This trial decides if we live or die, and I don’t know if I can bear to throw it all after everything we’ve been through.”

Kaede glares at her. “I know, and I am going to tell you exactly what happened to Rantaro, but I’m not doing it for Shuichi, or ‘justice,’ or even to survive.”

“Oh?” Monokuma says. “But those all certainly seem like mankind’s most common motives! What else left is there? I can bear-ly wait to find out! Right after this commercial break!”

“You’re not serious,” Ryoma deadpans. 

Monokuma continues to ramble, but Kaede pays him little attention as she says her next words directly to Tsumugi. “The only reason I’ve let this go this far is so I can kill you.”

Tenko must have overheard her over Monokuma’s non sequitur. Her voice is tinged with worry as she says, “Kaede? You really want to—” Tenko shakes her head, cutting herself off. “Tenko knows what they’ve done, but what Maki said about how killing the mastermind doesn’t end the game—”

“I know,” Kaede says. “And that’s fine. I can do both.”

“So,” Ryoma says, adding his voice to the conversation. “One more of us really is going to die then.”

“Well,” Tsumugi says. “That’s kind of horrible to think about, but it’s not like they don’t deserve it.”

Tenko’s expression remains conflicted, and she seems to be on the verge of saying but ultimately remains silent as Kaede moves the debate forward. “I don’t know why the mastermind would hold a retrial for a murder they’re responsible for, but there can be no doubt that Rantaro’s killer and the mastermind are one and the same.”

“The trial plainly is the best way forward, then, isn’t it?” Tsumugi asks. “I guess in that case, we should go over the incident with Rantaro one more time.”

“Probably,” Ryoma says. “But this seems weird. Like, Kaede said, why would the mastermind set themselves up to get executed?”

“I guess we’ll have to ask them when we find out who they are,” Kaede says. “And I think the best way to do that is for everyone to give their alibis for Rantaro’s death. One of them isn’t going to hold up, and that’s how we’ll know who it is.”

(Present your Argument) 

“I was in the classroom connected to the library by the vent with Shuichi,” Kaede says. “I did roll the shot put through the vents to try and kill whoever opened the secret door, but…”

“Maybe you missed?” Tsumugi says. “Or were stopped somehow?”

“Which means I thought I was Rantaro’s killer,” Kaede says. “But I know now for a fact that I’m not, and I am not the mastermind.”

“Also not the mastermind,” Ryoma says. “But I was in my room the whole time. Not gonna pretend I have an alibi, but I didn’t do it.”

“I was in the dining hall with Kirumi, Miu, and Korekiyo,” Tsumugi says. “I left to go to the bathroom once, but I think I was only gone for about five minutes. And there’s also just no way someone as plain as me could be the mastermind.”

Tenko says softly, “Tenko was with Kaito the whole time. We left the strategy meeting together to look for Rantaro when he didn’t come back.” She looks at the ground. “Tenko is also not the mastermind…”

(BREAK) 

Hearing Tsumugi hold onto her normal persona even as she purposefully gives herself away makes Kaede clench her fists involuntarily. “Tsumugi, I said the secret passage I found leading to the room in the library was in the girls’ bathroom. Are really you not even trying anymore?”

“Wha—?” Tsumugi gasps. “Me? You think I’m the mastermind? That’s—that’s crazy! That’s just—” she looks around the room wildly to see both Ryoma and Tenko have taken the news rather impassively. “Guys?”

“Kiibo told Tenko when she was setting up Maki’s broadcast,” Tenko confesses. “And… Tenko could also guess at this point.”

“Same here,” Ryoma says. “Think Kaede is still hiding something from us, but this is what makes the most sense. Sorry, Tsumugi.”

Tsumugi looks at the verge of tears. “You guys can’t be serious. You really think I could kill some—”

“Don’t apologize to her,” Kaede says. “She used the secret passage to kill Rantaro when my trap failed, she lured Gonta to his death, and she murdered Himiko in cold blood.”

Ryoma lets out a breath. “Right. I… wasn’t leaving the fourth floor during the blackout. Tsumugi left me alone, which I guess she did so she could go kill Himiko.”

“I was physically stuck with Kokichi the whole time, and Tenko went to search outside where there are no secret passages to the mastermind’s room,” Kaede says. “That also proves Tsumugi is the only one who could have committed a crime done by the mastermind.”

“Th-That’s all a coincidence!” Tsumugi says. 

“Tsumugi, please stop,” Tenko says. “We know you betrayed us, so just… tell us what happens next. Tenko doesn’t want to talk about this anymore.”

Tsumugi gives her a pleading look for a second longer before her expression shifts to something slightly annoyed. “Well, that was anticlimactic. Fine, I’ll admit it, you got it right. But you still don’t have all the details about who I really am, so it’s fine. This game’s not won until you solve that mystery first.”

Kaede frowns. “Are you saying you have a secret identity? We didn’t get any clues about that.”

“You mean I didn’t hand you any clues during the investigation like I did with the stuff about Rantaro’s murder,” Tsumugi says. “But you certainly have everything you need to figure it out anyway.”

“Kaede,” Ryoma says. “I’m not particularly inclined to believe Tsumugi right now, but when we split up at the school…”

He trails off, and Kaede sighs in response. “Yeah, I knew earlier. Tsumugi was actually how I got into the secret room in the first place.”

“And,” he says. “Why did you lie?”

“I figured it out earlier, and Tsumugi just came and confessed to me,” Kaede says. “She said that if I didn’t expose her immediately, we’d get the evidence for this trial and we could kill her. I think she thought I agreed because I wanted to exonerate Shuichi, but really… I just wanted her to pay without hurting anyone else.”

“You want her to die that badly?” Tenko asks softly.

“I do,” Kaede says. “I know you don’t like that, but… it’s not right if she just gets away with what she did to us.”

“Aw, Tenko still feels bad for me?” Tsumugi says. “Ha, I was half expecting you to throw me across the room when you found out. I guess sometimes characters grow more than you think they will.”

Tenko shoots her a glare before turning back to Kaede. “Tenko is… sorry for interrupting. She knows Kaede will do what she thinks is right.”

“Think I agree with that, too,” Ryoma says. “Speaking of, what did you mean ‘without hurting anyone else?’”

“Tsumugi told me that if she was killed before she revealed herself as the mastermind, she would count as another victim and her killer would be executed,” Kaede says. “This way, we can just get rid of her directly.”

“Did you think one of us would snap and kill her if you said anything?” Ryoma asks. 

“There was a chance,” Kaede says. “But mostly… if she’s going to die, it should be through execution. Just getting stabbed or poisoned or whatever isn’t enough for her.”

“Oh, wow,” Tsumugi says. “You’ve certainly gotten bloodthirsty. Or have you always been like this and are just showing your real colors now?”

“I’ve wanted to kill you since the first day we got here,” Kaede says. “Because I knew you would torture us and put us through hell—and you of all people have no right to call me ‘bloodthirsty’ after forcing us to kill each other.”

Tsumugi laughs. “You know I didn’t force you to do anything. So shouldn’t you really be mad at—”

“Shut up!” Kaede shouts. “Do you really expect any of us to buy that after what we’ve been through? You’re a monster, and you’re the one who did this to us—end of story.”

“It’s not, though,” Tsumugi says. “Because you haven’t figured out who I really am yet, and you’re not even close to solving the mystery of who really did this all to you.”

“It… wasn’t you?” Tenko asks. 

“If you’re about to try and say we did this to ourselves again,” Ryoma says, irritation clear in his voice.

Tsumugi shakes her head. “Nope. Not me, and not you, but someone else is absolutely the reason why you’re all here. Well, a few someones, but that’ll all fit together later. And,” she smiles at Kaede, “if you want that information, you will need me alive to tell it, so let’s hold off on the vote for now.”

Kaede pauses, looking Tsumugi over. She places the hat that had been in her hands to side, and Tsumugi’s eyes nervously dart to the movement for just a moment. “You know,” Kaede says. “You used information as leverage when we made our deal earlier, but I think I’m done with that now. I don’t care what the truth is anymore. Maybe we’ll never find out why we were here, but I don’t want to know at this point. I’m done being strung along by you.”

“Um, Kaede,” Tenko says. “Tenko understand how you feel, but… maybe all of us should decide together.” She tilts her head to direct Kaede’s attention to Ryoma, fiddling rather pointedly with his cigarette. “Ryoma,” Tenko says. “What do you think?”

He glances between Kaede and Tenko and sighs. “Kaede makes a good point, but also there’re some questions I think we really need answers to.”

“Like what?” Kaede asks.

“How much of our memories are real,” he says. “Or what the world is actually like, who did Maki broadcast her message to, what the hell happens to us when Tsumugi dies.”

Kaede frowns, choosing her words carefully as she says, “you know that solving mysteries is what Tsumugi and her audience want.”

“Yeah,” Ryoma says with a shrug. “But we’re also in the dark about too much. Mean, I don’t really care about who Tsumugi secretly is, but… who the hell are we?”

“What do you mean?” Tenko asks. “We’re… us, aren’t we?”

He shakes his head. “The Flashback Lights told us we were Hope’s Peak students, but we proved that was a lie, and… think we can assume at this point that all the Flashback Lights that have been telling us stuff about the outside world or how we got here are lies.”

“Ryoma discovered that the Flashback Lights are manufactured in the school,” Kaede says, filling in the information for Tenko. “Apparently you can make them say whatever you want. They weren’t giving us back our old memories—they just made us remember whatever the mastermind wanted.”

“Okay…” Tenko says hesitantly. “But what about the outside world?”

“Don’t know anymore,” Ryoma says. “I know what I saw with my own eyes, but the Flashback Light creation thing I found had all this stuff about implanting memories about the fate of the outside world, not to mention…” his gaze focuses on Tenko. “Tenko, you and Kiibo were able to contact something or someone on the outside, right? So… the world can’t be completely destroyed.”

Tenko nods. “That is correct. Tenko was confused about that, too, but Kiibo said his programming was already setup to deliver information to some outside network. Also,” she bites her lip, “he said it was specifically information from what he could hear and what the cameras in his eyes were picking up.”

“Does that mean Kiibo was monitoring us?” Kaede says. “He told me he thinks he was created specifically for the killing game, and if he was reporting what was happening to us…”

“But Kiibo helped us,” Tenko says. “And he helped get Maki’s message out and disable Monokuma, and—”

“I know,” Kaede says. “I know. I don’t think he was purposefully betraying us or anything… but it’s weird that he had a direct link to Tsumugi’s audience.”

“Tsumugi,” Ryoma says. “Answer the question: was Kiibo your mole?”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “That’s not how this works. I give hints not answers. But if you would like a hint,” she says, perking up. “I’m more than happy to remind you about Kiibo’s inner voice! Wasn’t that plainly suspicious?”

“His inner voice,” Ryoma says. “Been a long time since I heard that.”

“Yeah,” Kaede says. “And I don’t think Kiibo really knew what it was either. But… he really wanted to.”

“And now you get to figure it out,” Tsumugi says. “See, this trial is really just a great way to wrap up all the little mysteries.” 

“Tsumugi,” Tenko says softly. “Will figuring this out help us get out of here? If we solve these… mysteries, we can go home, right?”

Tsumugi nods. “Of course. There’s no need to stick around a crime scene once the case has been closed after all, you know.”

“Tenko, don’t bother asking her question,” Kaede says. “We can’t trust anything she says.”

“Ah, there’s no need to be so rude,” Tsumugi says. “I want you guys to finish and go home as soon as possible, too. And one of the first steps to doing that is to figure out the mystery behind Kiibo’s identity. And my identity, too, of course.”

Kaede glares at her for a moment before she says, “there’s no point in trying to figure out someone as horrible as you.”

“So Kiibo it is, then?” Ryoma says coolly. 

Tsumugi laughs softy as Kaede answers him affirmatively. “Yeah. This was something he wanted to figure out, too, so we’re doing this for him.”

“Are we?” Tenko says quietly to herself.

(Present your Argument) 

“I have to admit,” Tsumugi says. “I was just going to give you the answer to this one, but it’s plainly more exciting to watch you figure it out.”

“Shut up,” Kaede says.

Tsumugi ignores her. “For another hint, I will assure you Kiibo’s inner voice isn’t God or his conscience or anything silly like that. Kiibo was a robot after all.”

“Kiibo said that his inner voice told him not to give up hope a few times,” Tenko says. “So… something giving him advice?”

“It also stopped working when his body was destroyed,” Ryoma says. “So it wasn’t some program part of his A.I. or anything.”

“Kiibo told Tenko that his body was setup to receive signals from the outside,” Tenko says. “And he was also sending information to somewhere outside, too. That’s what he had Tenko connect him to for Maki’s broadcast.”

“You’ve very close,” Tsumugi says. “And when you put all of that information together, what do you get, Kaede?”

(BREAK) 

Kaede takes a moment to shoot Tsumugi a cold look before she answers. “The only people interested in getting information about the killing game are Tsumugi’s audience. And it’s not that much of a stretch to assume the people giving him advice were the same ones watching his camera feeds.”

“That makes sense,” Ryoma says. “But… where does that get us? We know it was Tsumugi’s audience, but we still don’t know who that audience is.”

“Which is why you need to figure out my identity, too,” Tsumugi says. “I know you don’t want to get to know me or anything, but if you want the truth about the killing game then you—”

“I don’t care about the truth,” Kaede says. “And I don’t think you do either. We know you’ve lied and manipulated us every trial—why would this be any different? Actually,” she throws her hands in the air, “why the hell was this a trial for Rantaro anyway? All that would do is out you!”

Tsumugi smiles. “I think you answered your own question, Kaede. I was willing to lie a little to keep the game moving, I’ll admit, but now that we’re at the end, I’ve turned over a new leaf.”

“Do you really think any of us believe that?” Ryoma asks.

“No,” she says. “But you can believe whatever you want. The truth is what you make it, after all. Kaede, what was it Monokuma said to you after Shuichi’s death?”

Kaede narrows her eyes. “What are you talking about?”

“If everyone thinks something is the truth,” Tsumugi says. “And the truth is a lie, who can really say which is which?”

“Which is why I refuse to believe to anything you say,” Kaede says. “You can say whatever stupid thing you think about what makes something true, but if none of us are listening, then it doesn’t matter. The only person who cares about your lies is you,” she sneers, “and you can keep your pathetic mind games to yourself.”

Tsumugi doesn’t seem disturbed in the slightest by Kaede’s response and simply presses a hand to her chin. “Ah, I see, I have been going about this wrong, haven’t I?” she says. “Truth and lies were really more Kokichi’s thing, weren’t they? Or maybe Shuichi’s—I’m sure a detective would be way more excited about showing me the cold, hard truth and all that. It’s a shame that I don’t really have anything a pianist would be interested in, isn’t it?”

Kaede rolls her eyes. Tenko asks, “does that mean you’re done asking questions?”

“Oh, no, no, not at all,” Tsumugi says. “I had just given up on one strategy since Kiibo isn’t here, but now I’m thinking of revisiting it.”

“You know if you tell us all of your plans to manipulate us, they’re not going to work,” Ryoma says.

“No, they still will,” Tsumugi says. “Despair is despair, no matter how it comes.”

“Okay, what the hell does ‘despair’ actually mean to you?” Kaede asks. “You just want to make us sad? Is that your goal?”

Tsumugi laughs. “No, despair is much more than just that. It’s hard to describe, but it’s a feeling of pure hopelessness for your past, present, and future. The ceiling falling in and the ground swallowing you up—feeling empty but also like you’re ready to burst.”

“Couldn’t have said it better my self!” Monokuma says. “Despair isn’t just a feeling. It’s a way of life!”

“That’s what the other killing games were about,” Tenko says. “But… the participants overcame it both times. And if Rantaro was in a third killing game and then came here, he also overcame despair, right?”

“Yeah,” Ryoma says. “Sounds like a pretty weak way of life to me. Not to mention all of the followers of despair are dead if they even existed.”

“I’ll admit that the Flashback Lights are fake, yes,” Tsumugi says. “But the participants of the past games are as real as you and me. Oh, and thank you Tenko for bringing up Rantaro’s game.”

Tenko fidgets under her stare. “Is Rantaro’s game important?”

“Well, this is Rantaro’s retrial,” Tsumugi says. “So it plainly makes sense to talk about him, don’t you think? I’d like to start the discussion with a question, too. Who do you all think was the mastermind of Rantaro’s previous killing game?”

Kaede pinches the bridge of her nose. “Someone you’re working with obviously.”

“Hmm,” Tsumugi says. “That’s pretty vague.”

“Kaede is right, though,” Ryoma says. “You have to be working with an organization of some kind. Kaede told me a while ago that someone has to be cleaning up the school when you and Monokuma are both at the trial.”

“Right,” Kaede says. “And all of this technology—the executions, a broadcast system, the ability to build and pilot multiple robots. There’s no way you’re the only person behind this.”

“Whoever put Rantaro in this game probably had a connection to his last game, too,” Tenko says. “Otherwise, he wouldn’t have been able to record a video for himself… But why was he in a different killing game in the first place?”

Ryoma nods. “Was thinking about that earlier, and came up with another question, too. Rantaro’s talent was Ultimate Survivor. Killing games are designed for Ultimates, so he had to have had a different talent before that.”

“And it got erased somehow or replaced by his survivor talent,” Kaede says. “We do already know that the mastermind can just play with our memories, so that’s not that hard to believe, I guess.”

“But if Rantaro was in a different killing game,” Tenko says, voice suddenly growing urgent. “Then that means there were other Ultimates with him, right? What happened to them? Were they all killed? And how do Ultimate students just keep getting rounded up for these horrible games?”

“All good questions,” Tsumugi says. “And to find out—”

“And what happens after us?” Tenko talks over her. “Are you just going to find sixteen other Ultimates and force them to kill each other? Are you going to erase our memories and throw us into another game? How do we even know we haven’t already been through this before if we can’t trust our own memories!?”

“Whoa, whoa, whoa,” Monokuma says. “Sloooow down! I mean the despair is good, but—”

“Tenko doesn’t know what’s going to happen, but there’s going to be more death, isn’t there?” she says. “Tenko almost hopes the world really is destroyed just so you won’t do this to anyone else!”

There’s a moment of silence after Tenko’s outburst. A gentle smile spreads over Tsumugi’s face. “And if you were still wondering what despair is… that’s a pretty good example.”

“Shut up,” Ryoma says. “Don’t talk about her that way.”

Tenko brushes at the beginnings of tears welling in her eyes with the back of her hand. She says, “Tenko can stand up for herself,” though her voice has little bite in it. “She just… she just doesn’t want anyone else to die. And Tenko knows that when this is done there’s going to be more Himikos and Gontas and Kaitos.”

Ryoma lets out a pained sigh. “You think that if it didn’t end with Rantaro, why would it end with us? He probably lost someone who was… kind to him for the first time in a long time, too, and then stood here and thought the same stupid things we are right now.”

“No,” Kaede says. “We’re not going to let that happen. With everything that’s happened, there’s no way Tsumugi’s audience will have faith in her to run another game. And that’s something she isn’t talking about for a reason—we all know the killing game is obsessed with following its own rules, and with how many times Tsumugi has had to—”

“Fine, I’ll admit it,” Tsumugi interrupts. “You’re right.”

That catches Kaede off guard, and she stammers, “H-Huh?”

“I did receive quite a few… strongly worded messages, however,” she says. “The mistake you’ve all been making—the mistake you bet Kokichi and Maki’s lives on—is that I care about that.”

“You…” Kaede falters for a second before shaking her head. “No, that’s definitely a lie. Everything you’ve done has been to try and keep the game going to put on a show for your audience. There’s no way you don’t care if they get angry.”

“Right, right,” Tsumugi says dismissively. “And if I didn’t care about the rules or whatever, I would have just haw the Exisals mow everyone down on day one. But I already told you what the real goal of this game is: bringing despair to all of you and everyone watching by extension.”

“Everyone watching?” Tenko asks. 

Tsumugi nods. “That’s right. Ryoma can tell you that the first two killing games were designed to bring despair to their audiences, right?”

Ryoma pauses, giving Tsumugi a measured look as he responds. “I guess…”

“Maybe all of you aren’t Hope’s Peak students, but you’re still symbols of hope,” Tsumugi says. “And what’s more despairing than seeing symbols of hope turn on each other over and over again, and every time they get close to stopping the game, the mastermind snatches it away from them? The fact that the game’s unfair just brings more despair, don’t you think?”

“So this really is all about despair, then?” Kaede asks. “You’re saying our suffering isn’t even about us—you’re just using us as examples for your stupid audience.”

“Does that mean Tsumugi’s audience… is on our side?” Tenko asks. “Whoever they are, they don’t want us to fall into despair, right?”

Ryoma tugs at his hat. “This is starting to sound a lot like the first killing game. Enoshima Junko wasn’t above cheating to try and stop people from ruining her game, either.”

“Exactly! You’re all correct!” Tsumugi says. “And with that in mind, who do you think I am? I promise the answer is plain to see.”

“Yup, yup, yup!” Monokuma says. “She’s plainly Enoshima Junko!”

Kaede blinks. “What.”

(Present your Argument) 

“I’m Enoshima Junko,” Tsumugi says. “You all thought she died, but you can’t ever really kill despair.”

“Where there’s Monokuma,” Monokuma says. “There’s Enoshima Junko—and where there’s Enoshima Junko, there’s Monokuma! We’re a two for one pair.”

“The real Remnant of Despair hiding amongst you all was never Kaede,” Tsumugi says. “But me, Enoshima Junko.”

“She’s the mastermind behind every game!” Monokuma says. “You can’t have a killing game with Enoshima Junko! Or Monokuma!”

“Tsumugi Shirogane was always just a disguise,” Tsumugi says. “Enoshima Junko is who I really am! For real!”

(BREAK) 

A cloud of smoke puffs out of the base of Tsumugi’s podium, obscuring her form for what Kaede counts as a few seconds at most. The smoke dissipates as quickly as it had come, and a girl with massive amounts of pink hair pulled into pigtails decorated with Monokuma’s face stands where Tsumugi had been.

The girl’s voice is rough, as if trying to put on a punk persona, when she talks. “So you figured it out, huh?”

“Um,” Kaede says. “I didn’t say anything.”

Her words go ignored. “It’s time to ditch that boring disguise and show the world who I really am: Enoshima Junko! Feeling the despair yet?”

Kaede spares a quick glance to the others. Tenko has her brow furrowed in vague confusion, whereas Ryoma stares down the supposed mastermind without a hint of surprise. “So,” he says. “Enoshima Junko is dead.”

“Weren’t you just fucking listening?” Junko says. “I already told ya’ you can’t kill despair.”

“Tsumugi,” Tenko says. “What are you doing? Why are you talking like that?”

“Talking like what?” Junko says. “And would you quit calling me that loser’s name? Like I said, I’m Enoshima Junko, baby!”

The confusion fades from Tenko’s expression, leaving something frustrated in its place. “Tenko means… you’re not talking like a real person. You sound like—”

“Bored!” Junko shouts. “This guessing game you’ve been going back and forth playing is boring!”

Kaede rolls her eyes. “Tsumugi, can we just—”

“As I already informed you,” Junko says, voice suddenly calm. “The persona of Tsumugi Shirogane was simply one I was using until the time of my reveal. Continuing to refer to me by that name is akin to calling an actor the character they play.”

“Okay, whatever,” Kaede says. “It doesn’t really matter who you are. You’re still the mastermind—nothing’s changed. Can’t we just vote and kill you already?”

“I am afraid that is not how the rules of the final trial work,” Junko says. “Though you have made a point to complain about rule changes, mixing things up, so to speak, for the final trial is acceptable.”

“Why didn’t you say that earlier?” Ryoma mumbles to himself.

“Okie dokie!” Junko’s voice rises in pitch to something childish. “So here are the new rules: this isn’t a silly little vote for who killed who, but one for hope and despair! If you all vote for me, then despair loses and you go free! But if even one of you doesn’t, then hope loses and you get to continue your school lives here.”

Kaede raises an eyebrow. “That doesn’t change anything. None of us have any reason not to vote for you.”

“Are you sure about that?” Junko asks. “The outside world might just be a teensy bit different from what—”

“The school is in ruins,” Ryoma says. “Staying here isn’t an option.”

“And even if that wasn’t the case,” Tenko says. “Tenko just wants to go home.”

Junko grins. “Ah-ha! I was hoping one of you would say that.”

“Say what?” Tenko asks, suddenly nervous.

“Like we were trying to say earlier,” Junko says, accompanied by another personality shift. “The world you came from exists only within your memories.”

“We know the world hasn’t been completely destroyed,” Ryoma says. “You couldn’t have an audience if it was.”

“Oh-ho, but consider, peasant, what that means,” Junko says. “The world is watching your struggles, yet no one has come to save you. Even after the foolish broadcast you forced upon the world, the game continues.”

That does seem to take Ryoma aback a bit, and he retreats to tugging at his hat. “The world is cruel,” he says after a moment. “Already knew that before coming here.”

“That’s right,” Kaede says. “And the condition of the outside world doesn’t matter. Staying here is impossible, and we’re not about to let you live after everything you’ve done.”

“And so it comes back to revenge again!” Junko says. “My, what impudence—to shirk your own life to end another!”

“You can say whatever you want,” Kaede says. “It doesn’t change any—”

“Um, Tenko has a question.”

Kaede whips her head around to face her. “Tenko?”

Tenko is nervously holding her hands to her chest, and her words are directed to the floor. “Tenko knows Kaede said that we can’t trust anything Tsumugi says, but… Kiibo was receiving signals from people watching us, and they never tried to do anything to help us. But if Tsumugi wants to bring despair to that audience, then they must be on our side… but then…”

She trails off, and Kaede picks up her point. “Why haven’t they helped us escape?”

“Paints a disturbing picture, doesn’t it?” Junko says in an almost comically downtrodden voice as she tugs at her hair. “An audience that doesn’t want you to despair, but doesn’t want you to escape either? I don’t know what kinda picture that paints of the world, but it sure sounds—”

“Like despair, I’m sure,” Kaede says sharply. 

Ryoma lets out a strained breath. “It’s a good point, though. We’ve been talking about this audience, but we don’t actually know anything about them other than that Tsumugi needed to keep the killing game going to appease them.”

“An audience who just wants to see you all kill each other in the name of hope,” Junko says. “How despair—”

“Okay, Tsumugi, can you just knock it off?” Kaede asks. “We know you’re not actually Enoshima Junko, and you’ve said ‘despair’ so many times it doesn’t even sound like a word anymore. If you want me to take you seriously, just stop it already.”

Junko pauses for a second, the previous personas she had been putting on melting away completely. “Oh? You sound so certain. How do you know I’m not the real Enoshima Junko?”

“She’s dead,” Ryoma says again.

“Please, as if death ever stopped the Ultimate Despair,” Junko says.

“Okay, fine,” Kaede says. “Besides the logical answer that it is literally impossible for a dead teenager from a killing game that happened years ago to be here, the Mother Monokuma told me.”

Junko purses her lips. “Did it now?”

“Mother Monokuma,” Tenko says. “Kiibo told Tenko a little bit about that. It’s the center of the school that controls everything, right?”

“I think so,” Kaede says. “And it told me that Enoshima Junko wasn’t running this game. It also said that Tsumugi isn’t a Remnant of Despair, either.”

Junko stares at her with half lidded eyes before sighing and turning to look at Monokuma giggling behind his paws. “Really?”

“Really!” he chirps. “But I did happen to also let slip that you are definitely one of Enoshima Junko’s followers.”

Junko contemplates this for a moment before saying. “That’s fair, I guess.”

“A stalker hiding outside a celebrity’s bushes is absolutely a follower! So it’s absolutely fair!” Monokuma says.

Junko’s lips twist into a scowl. “Well, that comparison’s a bit unnecessary, don’t you think?”

“Is it wrong?” Monokuma asks, voice teasing.

Junko huffs crossing her arms. Kaede’s eyes dart between them, trying to gauge exactly what she’s hearing. “Are you two… fighting?”

“Fighting is too strong a word for it,” Junko says. “But that’s not important.”

“Does this mean you’re finally admitting that Enoshima isn’t real and you’re just Tsumugi in cosplay?” Ryoma asks.

His question is answered as almost magically, Junko’s appearance reverts back to Tsumugi’s. “I guess, oh,” she clasps her hands. “And I suppose it’s not all bad, since while we’re on the topic, can Kaede tell me why I was able to cosplay as Enoshima Junko just now? This question should be really fast, but I think we should debate it anyway—just to keep the trial moving.”

(Present your Argument) 

“So, maybe I’m not really Enoshima Junko,” Tsumugi says. “And the whole secret identity thing was a lie.”

“Tsumugi gave up really easily,” Tenko says. “Is—is this another trap?”

“No more traps and no more lies, I promise,” Tsumugi says. “In fact, that whole display right now was just a clue about your memories.”

“The Flashback Lights gave us memories of Hope’s Peak, the Tragedy, and the Remnants of Despair,” Ryoma says. “But we also know the Flashback Lights were fabricated by the mastermind.”

“So we can’t trust that any of those things are real,” Tenko says. “But… we don’t even know if there are other memories we were given and can’t trust. Tenko doesn’t remember how she came here, so she doesn’t know what else she doesn’t remember.”

“That’s true, too,” Ryoma says. “But think we can safely say this whole Enoshima thing is just bullshit.”

“Tenko… agrees with that,” Tenko says.

“Hey, now!” Monokuma says. “Don’t you know not to say such hurtful things around a dedicated fan?”

(BREAK) 

“Enoshima Junko…” Kaede says. “She’s not real, is she? You can cosplay her because she’s just a fictional character.”

Tsumugi smiles. “That’s right. You remember my cospox? I know I might be a bit of a liar, but even I can’t fake spontaneously breaking out in a rash.”

“It’s just… cosplay,” Tenko says. “So our memories of Hope’s Peak are fake…”

Ryoma pulls at his hat. “And if that’s not real, the first and second killing games aren’t real either.”

“Right and right again,” Tsumugi says.

“But,” Tenko says, a note of distress creeping into her voice. “Tenko doesn’t get it. What about Rantaro’s game? Rantaro was a real person, wasn’t he? He wasn’t just an actor you hired and killed, right?”

“Oh, no, no,” Tsumugi says. “Rantaro was real. Don’t ask me to cosplay him, unless you want to see something really gross.”

“Then his killing game was real?” Tenko asks. “But that doesn’t make sense—why are some of the games fake and some not?”

Tsumugi’s gaze darkens slightly. “Because sometimes fiction imitates reality, and sometimes reality imitates fiction.”
