“So what are you then,” Ryoma says, narrowing his eyes. “Some freak copying murders they see on T.V.?”

“Hmm, I think I prefer the term ‘cosplaycat criminal,’” Tsumugi says. 

“You,” Kaede says. “You created this entire game just to copy a T.V. show!? You kidnapped us and messed with our memories just so—”

“It’s not a T.V. show,” Tsumugi says with a click of her tongue. “It was more than that—it’s practically a cultural phenomenon. Then it became a T.V. show.”

Tenko gapes at her. “We’re… we’re on T.V.? The people watching us are…”

“Just fans at home,” Tsumugi says. “Just everyday people tuning into the most popular game on air: Dangan Ronpa!”

“Dangan Ronpa!” Monokuma cheers. 

“What…” Ryoma breathes out. “That doesn’t…”

Monokuma pumps his fist in the air again. “Dangan Ronpa!”

“Um, what’s that?” Tenko asks.

“It’s the name of the killing game, of course,” Tsumugi says. “We have many competitors, so it’s necessary to establish your brand and make it memorable.”

“Which is where I come in!” Monokuma says. “The lovable mascot character! And the five less popular mascot characters from this season to turn into cheap merch.”

“‘Season?’” Kaede says. “Wait, does that mean—”

Tsumugi nods. “That there have been previous televised killing games and you guys are just one in a series? You got it!”

“Rantaro’s game… was just another season of a T.V. show?” Tenko asks in horror.

“That’s right,” Tsumugi says. “He was one of the stars of our fifty second season, and you guys are the fifty third!”

Kaede gapes at her. “There’s… there’s been over fifty killing games?”

“H-How many people dead is that?” Tenko asks. 

Ryoma has a grim look on his face. “Over five hundred, at least. Probably more.”

“This…” Kaede says. “What the hell is this!?”

“It’s entertainment,” Tsumugi says. “Your memories of the previous killing games have been erased, but you guys should still know what reality T.V. is. Just think of that but with a little more murder!”

“That’s sick!” Kaede shouts. “No one would watch something that horrible! You’re lying!”

Tsumugi smiles in amusement. “I’m really not, though. I mean, come on, think of the first killing game: a bunch of super cool Ultimates rounded up together in a high stakes mystery game to decide the philosophic fate of the world? Doesn’t that sound exciting? How could anyone not be interested in that?”

“You’re killing people for fun,” Tenko says. “Real people are suffering and dying—nothing can make that okay.”

“But what if it was fiction?” Tsumugi asks. “You might cry when a character is hurt or dies, but in the end, it’s fine, you know?”

“That’s different,” Tenko says. “It’s different with real people with hopes and dreams and families and friends.”

Tsumugi nods happily. “Exactly—I’m glad you get it.”

A disturbed look crosses over Tenko’s face at her words. “Wha… what?”

“Killing real people and killing characters is different,” Tsumugi says. “Which is why hosting killing games is totally okay.”

“What the hell are you saying?” Kaede asks. “How can you say you know how messed up this whole thing is and then just say it’s fine!?”

“You’re not listening, Kaede,” Tsumugi says. “I said killing games are fine because they’re not conducted with real people—simple as that.”

“Tsumugi,” Ryoma says slowly. “We are real. You can’t just say we aren’t.”

She laughs. “Oh, I think I can. None of us here are real. I know it, the audience knows it, and now you guys know it, too. That’s why no one has come to try and rescue you. You don’t try to save your favorite character from their fate, right? That would just be ridiculous.”

“You’re not making any sense,” Kaede says. 

“No, I am, you’re just a little bit confused,” Tsumugi says. “Ryoma and Tenko were on the right track, actually, earlier. You guys actually have no idea who you are and you can’t trust any of your memories.”

“More Flashback Lights were used on us then,” Ryoma says. 

“You should remember, oh, four or so Flashback Lights, I think?” Tsumugi says. “And Ryoma found the encouraging fifth one, right?”

Ryoma’s mouth presses into a thin line as he answers. “I did…”

“I guess that makes sense now, too,” Tsumugi says. “Just a little extra kick of hope to have it all come crumbling down in despair at the end. Shame you were the only one who saw it though—really should have gotten the protagonist in on that.”

“Stop talking about us like that!” Kaede shouts. “Stop lying, stop making things up, and stop trying to—”

“Anyway, about the Flashback Lights,” Tsumugi says. “There was one more way at the beginning when you guys all first arrived. Is there any chance you remember that? Before you stepped out of those lockers the first time. Well, second time.”

“Are you… asking us to remember a memory you erased?” Tenko asks. 

Tsumugi sighs as she crosses her arms. “No luck then, huh? Oh, well. I suppose I could tell you, but I think you’re pretty set on not believing me.”

“Of course we are,” Kaede says. “We have no reason to believe anything you say. You’ve shown us no evidence of anything you’re saying.”

“I know, I know,” Tsumugi says. “Which is why I came prepared with proof. And,” her eyes flash, reveling in whatever she’s about to say, “maybe you won’t believe it if I say it, but you’d believe yourself, right?”

Kaede is about to interrogate her on what that means when a monitor lowers from the ceiling. It displays only static for a moment before clearing to a slightly grainy image of an overhead camera looking down on a girl in a plain high school uniform.

Kaede says, “What…?”

The girl on the screen says, “My name is,” only to be cut off by static. “And I’d like to audition for Dangan Ronpa because, well, I think I’d be good at it. Honestly, I’m perfect for a killing game. I don’t have any faith in humanity.”

“Kaede?” Tenko asks, voice trembling. “What… what is this?”

“I don’t…” Kaede starts to say.

“That’s what always gets people killed—trusting the wrong person. But with me, that wouldn’t be a problem, and spreading distrust among everyone else is sure to make things interesting, don’t you think?” the girl says. “That’s always my favorite part of Dangan Ronpa: navigating that kind of atmosphere of paranoia and learning how to manipulate people. Sure killing someone would be fun, but I think the social part of the game is what really makes a season. And since I just naturally don’t trust people, I’m sure it’d only be a matter of time before I betray someone in some exciting way.”

The video mercilessly returns to fuzz, and when Kaede can bare to take her eyes off the screen, she sees Tsumugi grinning brightly at her. “So, Kaede, what do you think of the old you?”

Chapter End Notes

Sorry for the delay on this one--I forgot what writing trial chapters was like and also learned why Kodaka never had a trial with less than five characters, haha.

Trial XIV

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

“That’s…” Kaede says. “That’s not real.”

Tsumugi smiles. “Oh, Kaede, you know it is. It’s you from before the first Flashback Light.”

Ryoma seems only slightly less unnerved than Kaede. “So there were Flashback Lights we don’t remember, and before them…”

“Before them,” Tsumugi picks up. “You were all dedicated fans happy to audition.”

“We,” Tenko says. “We auditioned?”

Kaede keeps staring at the screen even after the image of herself disappears. She feels numb, almost distant from her body as she mumbles, “Kokichi said something like that. He thought we might have volunteered.”

“And he guessed right,” Tsumugi says. “You can’t host a killing game with unwilling participants. That would just be unethical.”

“N-No!” Tenko shouts. “That doesn’t make any sense! No one would sign up for something as horrible as this! No one would watch something as horrible as this! Whatever you just showed us is fake—there’s no other explanation!”

Tsumugi turns her gaze on her, glasses shining dangerously. “Okay. Then tell me how it’s fake.”

“H-Huh?” Tenko falters.

“Video evidence is pretty conclusive if you ask me,” Tsumugi says. “So tell me how I faked it. If you’re going to accuse me of lying you have to have a theory to back it up, you know.”

“Um,” Tenko says, confidence draining from her voice. “You can dress up like other people, so that’s probably just you in the video.”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “Nope. I can’t cosplay as real people, remember? Come on, Tenko, you can do better than that.”

Tenko flinches at her words. She briefly looks to Kaede for help to see her still completely zoned in on the blank screen. “It’s,” she says. “Tenko still doesn’t believe it’s real because… because Kaede isn’t like that. She would never say things like that.”

“Well, she wouldn’t now,” Tsumugi says. “But before her memories were altered for the killing game, she absolutely did. I already explained the first Flashback Light that gave you memories of your ultimate talents, didn’t I?”

“You… mentioned it,” Ryoma says.

“Yes, well, I suppose you could put two and two together at this point,” Tsumugi says. “But the truth is that all of your talents, back stories, and memories are fake. Everything you remember from before the game was written by a member of our staff to make you more interesting.”

“You,” Tenko says. “What are you saying? That doesn’t make any sense—Tenko is Tenko and—”

“And Tenko Chabashira was the creation of one of our writers,” Tsumugi says. “If you don’t believe me, you can always see for yourself.”

Tenko’s eyes widen at the threat. “No! That’s not—”

“Huh?” Tsumugi says. “You seem scared all of a sudden, but that doesn’t make any sense. It’s just a lie, right? So why are you afraid of seeing what I have to show you?”

“B-Because,” Tenko stammers. “It’s a trick,” she decides on. “You’re just trying to trick and confuse us.”

“But if you don’t believe in a lie, it shouldn’t hold any power over you,” Tsumugi says. “So it shouldn’t be a problem to watch another video I have, don’t you think?”

“Quit tormenting her,” Ryoma says. “Just leave her alone.”

Tsumugi clicks her tongue. “Hey now, I’m the one being attacked here. Tenko accused me of lying when I promised I would tell the truth, and now I’m just trying to set things straight. And besides, hasn’t Tenko always hated people keeping secrets?”

“Shut up,” Ryoma says. “Stop acting like you’re doing us a favor or something. We all know what your real goal is.”

“I sure would hope so,” Tsumugi says. “After all I told you upfront that my goal was to bring you all to despair. Personally, I think I’m doing a pretty good job so far. I mean, learning that your personalities are all fake and you have no where to go back to is pretty rough, isn’t it?”

Tsumugi sends a pointed glance to Kaede, still reeling from what she had been shown. “It’s all pretty tragic,” Tsumugi continues, “when you consider the fact that everything has been scripted. All your relationships and feelings were just little plots for your characters.”

Ryoma’s gaze darkens. “That’s a lie. Your game went off the rails—you basically admitted it yourself. You don’t have that kind of control over us.”

“Oh maybe a few of our creations got a bit out of hand, sure,” Tsumugi says. “But trust me, they were the exceptions. And even for the ones that were a bit hard to handle, their personalities were fake, too. Actually,” she claps her hands. “Would you all like to see the real Kokichi and Maki? They died so bravely to end the game that I think it’s only fair you get to see how much they loved it beforehand.”

Before anyone can protest, the monitor flicks back on. This time, an identical but somehow plainer version of Kokichi looks up at the camera. His voice lacks its characteristic mischief and the raw honesty is somehow deeply unsettling as he says, “I think being in a killing game would be really exciting. If I got in, I know I would do whatever I could to entertain the audience.”

His image fuzzes away, replaced with one of Maki. She wrings her hands nervously as she says, “is there any way to guarantee we get a certain role? Because I want—no, need—to be a killer. The only reason I watch Dangan Ronpa is for the killers, and I only want to be on the show if I can get to be one.”

Like with Kaede’s video before, the screen turns to fuzz when Maki finishes speaking. Kaede distantly watches the images flickering before her. Maki and Kokichi had both angered her more than anyone during the game, but something about hearing those words coming from their mouths feels offensive.

Tsumugi laughs. “It’s kind of funny when you think about it. Kaede, Kokichi, and Maki were more desperate to end the killing game than anyone else, and they’re only like that because of the killing game. If they hadn’t been picked, they probably all would have been at home, eagerly watching.”

“That’s not true,” Kaede says softly. “That’s not us. We don’t know those people.”

“Oh, come on, quit lying to yourselves,” Tsumugi says. “You’re all fictional characters created to kill each other in this fictional world. The sooner you accept that fact, the sooner we can move on.”

“Move on to what?” Ryoma says darkly. “More torture?”

“You’re the one who wanted more information,” Tsumugi says. “You wanted the truth about your situation, so I’m giving it to you. Don’t shoot the messenger.”

Tenko says, “and you’re saying our situation is… us and everyone else who died—we were all just created to kill each other?”

“To entertain the audience,” Kaede says. “Kokichi said the point was to entertain the audience—that there are certain points where we’re supposed to win or ‘overcome despair’ because that’s what the audience wants.”

“And Kokichi also said that he wanted the killing game to be exciting before he even got in,” Tsumugi says.

“No!” Tenko says. “Kokichi may have had a horrible personality, but that was the last thing he wanted. He gave his life to protect us and end the game—you can’t just say that didn’t happen.”

Tsumugi waves a hand dismissively. “Calm down. There’s no need to get so upset. All I’m saying is that Kokichi was just a product of his environment like everyone else who signed up.”

“I assume none of us want to know what that means,” Ryoma says. “But you’re going to tell us anyway.”

“You got it,” Tsumugi says with a laugh. “You all came from a world so advanced that all of its problems have been solved, and there is just too much peace. Everyone is bored out of their minds, and, well, what gets people going more than the heart pounding emotions generated by a killing game?”

“That’s… that’s sick,” Tenko says. “Tenko wants nothing to do with a world like that.”

“Well,” Tsumugi says. “Your options are either to go back to that world or to stay here.”

“We already said it’s impossible to stay at the school,” Ryoma says. “It’s been destroyed. There’s nothing here for us anymore.”

Tsumugi’s gaze darkens. “Maybe—but which would cause more suffering? Staying in the ruins and rebuilding or being forced out into a world that cheered when all of your friends died?”

Her words are met with a moment of silence. Kaede softly mumbles, “I don’t want anything to do with that world.”

Tenko doesn’t seem to hear her as she says, “is it impossible to regain our lost memories?”

“You mean go back to who you were before the killing game?” Tsumugi says. “Are you sure you even want that?”

Tenko hugs herself. “No. Tenko doesn’t know what she was like, and she also knows that if she pushes it, you’re just going to show her some horrible video.”

Tsumugi laughs. “Am I really that predictable?”

“Yes,” Ryoma says. “Now just tell us what the hell you want from us already.”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “It’s not about what I want. The outcome of the vote is completely up to you: hope or despair. You guys have complained enough about how much you hate trials, so I’ll let you end this one early. Just go ahead and vote for whichever option you think is best.” She smiles. “I’m sure you’ll make the right choice.”

(Present your Argument) 

“The only options,” Tsumugi says, “are hope and despair.”

“That’s a sick euphemism for it,” Ryoma mutters.

“You can either choose despair and rebuild your lives here,” Tsumugi says. “Or you can choose hope and try and make it a world that you don’t belong in anymore.”

“Is that really all there is to it?” Tenko asks. “We go outside or we don’t?”

“If you boil it down, basically,” Tsumugi says. “I’ll also be executed if you pick hope.”

“What the hell does ‘hope’ even mean?” Ryoma asks.

“It means you’ve overcome the horrible despair of your existence as nothing more than fictional characters and are willing to brave the fact that you have no futures,” Tsumugi says. “What’s more hopeful than holding on to such blind optimism in the face of utter despair?”

“Despair, hope…” Tenko says. “Both sound horrible… Tenko doesn’t want either.”

“Too bad,” Tsumugi says. “Because hope and despair are the only outcomes of this game! Those are the rules!”

“It’s the Dangan Ronpa way!” Monokuma says.

(BREAK) 

“Wait,” Kaede says, life finally flickering back in her eyes. “The rules…”

“The rules are the rules,” Tsumugi says. “Of course, you’re more than welcome to find out exactly what happened to Maki and Kaito if you feel like breaking them.”

Kaede clenches her jaw. “Just… shut up and answer my question.”

“Oh, that’s the spirit,” Tsumugi says. “You had me thinking I finally got you to fall into despair back there. Although,” she taps her chin in thought. “Is that fighting spirit or is that aggressiveness just your old self? It’s kind of hard to tell with you sometimes, Kaede.”

Kaede barely stops herself from flinching at the accusation. “I get it—you showed me that video not because I used to be someone horrible and manipulative but because I still am.”

“Kaede!” Tenko says. “That’s not true! You’re nothing like—”

“No,” Kaede says. “I am. No matter how much I try to trust or believe, my instincts won’t let me. If I was turned into a fictional character, Tsumugi did a pretty terrible job of erasing my old personality.”

Tsumugi lets out a short laugh. “That’s certainly a way to look at it. I suppose I miscalculated how much you hate yourself.”

“That’s not it,” Kaede says. “I just… I know who I am. And I know you’re the same way.”

That catches Tsumugi off guard, and she raises an eyebrow in response. “Oh? Isn’t that something the villain says to the hero not the other way around?”

“See?” Kaede says. “You’re admitting it—you think you’re fictional, too. You’re exactly the same as us.”

“Oh, I wasn’t denying that,” Tsumugi says. “I just think it’s interesting you made that connection is all.”

“Then what do you think about this connection,” Kaede says. “Monokuma said at the beginning of this trial that the rules state there can only be two survivors, but now you’re saying the only way we can leave is if we choose hope. What happens to the third person if we do what you say?”

Tsumugi’s smile turns dark. “I’m glad you asked.”

The confidence that had been building within Kaede falters at Tsumugi’s calm answer. Tenko says, “The two person rule… Rantaro had said that was important.”

“Oh, it was very important to him,” Tsumugi says. “It’s why he ended up in another killing game, after all.”

“He… what?” Ryoma says.

“That was a good catch, Kaede,” Tsumugi says. “The rules are very strict that only two of you will be leaving even if you do pick hope. The third person will be sacrificed and become a contestant in the next killing game.”

Tenko’s eyes widen. “There really are going to be more killing games.”

“Of course,” Tsumugi says. “And one of you will get to see it first hand as the new Ultimate Survivor! And since I’m such a nice person, I’ll even let you vote which one of you it is. So,” she looks at each of them in turn expectantly, “who volunteers?”

“No one!” Tenko shouts. “If that is the rule, then we choose despair!”

“Tenko?” Ryoma says. “We can’t—”

“Tenko doesn’t care!” Tenko says. “Tenko will live out the rest of her life here before she sacrifices someone else!”

“I told you despair is the right choice,” Tsumugi says.

“No,” Ryoma says. “It’s not. Already told you this isn’t even a choice. And,” he sighs, “it turns out I was right—maybe my memories are all fake, but I really don’t have anyone out there for me. At least, not anyone who would stop me from signing up for a killing game.”

Tenko shakes her head. “Ryoma, she is trying to trick you.”

“Trick me into what?” Ryoma says. “The only trick is that I thought I might have had a future for five minutes. So,” he looks at Tsumugi. “I’ll do it.”

Kaede blinks at him. “Ryoma?”

“No!” Tenko screams again, gripping the edge of her podium in frustration. “Tenko won’t let you!”

He lets out a deep sigh. “Tenko—”

“If you go into another killing game, you’re not just killing yourself, but everyone else Tsumugi will trick into signing up,” Tenko says. “You said you weren’t going to hurt us like that ever again!”

Ryoma tugs at his hat, lowering it over his face. “Well, what the hell else are we supposed to do?”

“Stay here!” Tenko says. “We just stay in the school and—”

“Already told you that’s not a possibility,” Ryoma fires back.

“Tenko knows the school is destroyed,” she says. “But we could still manage, and anything is better than another killing game.”

“Maybe that last part is true,” Ryoma says. “But think about it—if this really is a T.V. show or whatever, then there’s no way staying here for the rest of our lives is an option.”

Tsumugi clicks her tongue. “Oh come now, you don’t think that I was lying about one of your options, do you? Our team here at Dangan Ronpa would be happy to feed and support you.”

Ryoma gives her a dark look. “As I was saying—there’s no way we can trust that. Some of us walking free as a guarantee is better than all of us dying.”

“And guaranteeing that one of us goes to another killing game is worse than anything,” Tenko says. “And—and if one of us does have to, it should be Tenko.”

Kaede looks to her. “Tenko…”

“You can’t be serious,” Ryoma says. “You just said—”

“Tenko just said she would rather die than live because she sacrificed people,” Tenko says. “Tenko is still voting for despair, but if she loses, then she’ll go to the next game.”

“Ah, but if despair wins,” Tsumugi says. “Then the outside world will fall to despair. Who will bring hope to all of the—”

“Fuck the outside world,” Ryoma snaps at her before turning back to Tenko. “Tenko, you know what happened to Rantaro almost better than anyone. Volunteering is the same as killing yourself now.”

Tenko remains firm, crossing her arms defensively. “And Tenko would rather that happens to her than killing one of her friends.”

“You’re not killing me if I go,” Ryoma says. “I’ve already made my peace, and I’ve been fine with this outcome for a long time.”

Tenko shouts something else at him as Kaede bites her lip, looking between them volleying back and forth. Her hands subconsciously clench into fists as her last two remaining friends both keep arguing how they should be the one to die. And Kaede glances across the courtroom to Tsumugi, all too pleased at the scene before her.

Tenko says, “Tenko doesn’t have a future either! If she was just written by someone to die, then—”

“Then we’re the same, and it still doesn’t make sense for you to—”

“Stop,” Kaede says. Neither hear her, and she squeezes her eyes shut for a moment before raising her voice. “I said stop.”

They both abruptly cut themselves off, and Tenko turns to stare at her in horror. “Kaede,” she says. “Not you, too…”

“No,” Kaede says. “I’m not volunteering. I just wanted to say something.”

“Well, go ahead, Kaede,” Tsumugi says. “I’m sure we’d all love to hear it.”

Kaede sends her a brief glare before shifting her focus back to Ryoma and Tenko. “I just thought, standing here, hearing you both scream about how you should be the sacrifice—this is torture.” She points at Tsumugi. “This is Tsumugi torturing us. This is still part of the game.”

“Well, of course it is,” Tsumugi says with a laugh. “I told you this is how the game ends.”

“That’s not what I’m saying,” Kaede says. “I mean that picking hope and suffering like this—forcing us to go through the same pain of losing each other again—is still part of the killing game.”

Tsumugi stops laughing, though her smile remains in place. She repeats, “Like I said, the rules state—”

“Ryoma was right, wasn’t he?” Kaede says. “Despair isn’t a real option, and you have no intentions of us picking it.”

“What makes you say that?” Tsumugi asks. “Come now, if you’re going to argue with me, why don’t you present some evidence?”

(Present your Argument) 

“You’re supposed to pick hope,” Tsumugi says. “Now just what led you to that conclusion?”

“Like I said,” Ryoma interjects. “Picking despair is impossible just logistically speaking.”

“But it’s better than hope,” Tenko says. “Picking hope… picking hope is terrible. Why would anyone agree to something so horrible?”

“I’m not the one voting,” Tsumugi says. “It’s all up to you guys to bring hope to the world. My only task is to bring the world to despair, starting with you three. Why wouldn’t I let you fall deep, deep down into the depths of despair?”

“All this hope and despair talk is really firing me up!” Monokuma cheers. “And if you feel the same way, check out our website for how to become a sponsor and receive even more hope and despair!”

Tsumugi raises an eyebrow at him. “Bit of an odd time to do a plug, don’t you think?”

“One of us has to keep the money rolling in,” Monokuma replies dully. “I’m not gonna be able to roll in salmon if we’re not rolling in dough.”

(BREAK) 

“Your audience,” Kaede says. “You don’t actually want to ‘bring them despair.’ You want to entertain them so they’ll keep watching us—so your sick show will be successful.”

Tsumugi smiles back at her. “Those things aren’t mutually exclusive, you know. Our audience loves despair—the emotional rollercoaster of having your hopes brought up and up, only to come crashing down. You don’t understand what the world outside is like. They have too much hope so they need a little despair, you know?”

“I don’t believe that,” Kaede says. “Ryoma,” she turns to him. “When we were in the school you found a Flashback Light that gave you memories meant to motivate you, right?”

“Right…” he says. “Did think it seemed strange that the mastermind would prepare something like that.”

“Well, obviously I didn’t use it,” Tsumugi says. “And even if I did, what’s so strange about raising your hopes only to crush them? Despair needs hope and hope shines brightest when it overcomes despair. It’s a cycle, and to get one you need to instill the other.”

Kaede points an accusing finger at her. “What you said just now proves it. ‘Hope shines brightest when it overcomes despair.’ This isn’t a real choice or a real challenge—it’s just something you made up to make us think we were going to fail right at the end to create some sort of grand finale.”

“You can think that as much as you want,” Tsumugi says. “But it doesn’t change the fact that—”

“That we’re supposed to win,” Kaede says. “That’s what Kokichi thought. Every trial—including this one—they’re designed for us to win so that your audience can get their happy ending.”

“And continue the cycle…” Tenko picks up.

“I think that’s right,” Kaede says. “Tsumugi would let us think we had a chance so we would keep trying—if we just gave up ‘in despair’ or were all killed at the beginning, then her audience wouldn’t be entertained. Kokichi said that the game was designed for us to succeed sometimes so we would keep playing, and that’s the truth, isn’t it?”

Tsumugi shrugs in response. “Sure, if you feel like relying on Kokichi’s logic. But I already showed you what the real Kokichi was like, don’t you remember?”

Kaede falters slightly at that. “Th-That doesn’t matter. I… I accept whoever I was before, and—”

“Do you accept who everyone else was?” Tsumugi says. “Oh, Kaede, you’re such a caring person that it matters more to you that your beloved friends were good people then that you were.”

“Of course Kaede wants to believe in her friends. We all do,” Tenko says. “Tenko’s friends who she couldn’t save are the reason she’s still fighting and why she refuses to lose anyone else.”

Kaede sees Tsumugi’s lips quirk into a smile at roughly the same time she registers Tenko’s mistake. Ryoma catches it, too, calling out, “Tenko, don’t say things like—”

“Friends you couldn’t save, friends you had to leave behind,” Tsumugi muses. “All of your friends that were created to die specifically to motivate you. Well, I certainly would hope that their scripted deaths are keeping you going. Our writers worked very hard to make sure each and every killing seemed meaningful.”

“Hey!” Kaede interrupts. “Don’t change the topic like that! Answer my question: we’re meant to pick hope, aren’t—”

“You know who I think everyone here really liked? Kaito! It really is a shame all of his motivational speeches and comforting words weren’t real,” Tsumugi says. “Because he was just a fictional character like all of us.”

Ryoma echoes, “‘all of us…’” to himself.

Kaede doesn’t hear him. Though seeing herself and Maki and Kokichi say such horrible things had shaken her, Kaede is all too aware that seeing someone like Kaito or Tenko be smeared is different. “That’s—” Kaede shouts. “That’s not true! You can’t hold that over us because it’s not true!”

Tsumugi sighs. “Kaede, weren’t you paying attention earlier? Tenko said the same thing, and I already told her that if you want to argue, you need proof.”

“I—” Kaede stammers for a second. “I…”

“That’s what I thought,” Tsumugi says. “If you have any more theories, I’d be happy to debunk them, but, really, don’t you think it’s easier if you just accept it at this point? All of you volunteered, had your original personalities erased, and became fictional characters in order to participate in the killing game.”

Kaede glances to Tenko, holding her hands close to heart and seemingly on the verge of tears, then to Ryoma, staring hard on the ground. Tsumugi smirks as she takes them all in as well. “It seems you’re all finally starting to understand the situation you’re in. Everything in this game from the very beginning has been scripted to lead us to this point. The plotlines where you would fall in love or forge ‘unbreakable bonds’ were all written out long beforehand. Your words, your actions, and even your very thoughts are all fiction. And fiction has no place in the outside world.”

“That… that doesn’t matter,” Kaede says. “Because I promised I would kill you, and that’s what I’m going to do.”

“Well, of course you are,” Tsumugi smiles. “Because that’s what your character was written to do from the very beginning: kill the mastermind.”

Kaede clenches her jaw and looks around again, as if something in the trial room would give her the argument she needs. The monitor remains mercifully blank—Tsumugi’s plan to taunt them with more videos seemingly abandoned for the time being—Ryoma and Tenko are unresponsive, Monokuma is grinning happily up on his throne while Tsumugi smirks at her, and all of the portraits of her dead friends are lined up dutifully as always.

Shuichi’s portrait is across from her. It has stared her dead in the face for so long, that any affect it may have had has long since faded. Black and white with a smear of blood on his X almost blotting out his one visible eye completely, the other hidden behind his hat.

Kaede furrows her brow. She doesn’t feel any comfort radiating from it, nor any of the boiling anger from when she had swore to kill in his name. Her eyes trail down to the hat she had discarded on the ground next to her.

“Maybe,” Kaede says. “That is true. Before everything, I was someone horrible, then you changed me, and I wanted nothing more than to kill you. And I still do.”

Tsumugi seems slightly unnerved by Kaede’s calmness, even as she replies. “So you’ve accepted it then?”

“No,” Kaede says. “I think it’s all one big lie. I know it’s all one big lie. Because…” she looks up at Tsumugi. “I might want the same thing I did at the beginning, but I’m not the same person. I’ve outgrown your character—we all have.”

“Do you really think that highly of yourself?” Tsumugi asks, raising an eyebrow.

Kaede shakes her head. “No, you said it all before: I’m bitter and cynical and I don’t like that about myself. But that’s not who you wanted me to be, either. And then you said the same thing to Tenko: she’s different than how you imagined she would be.”

That catches Tenko’s attention enough for her to look up at Kaede. “Kaede? What do you mean?”

“I mean,” Kaede says. “That you’re so different that Tsumugi admitted she can’t predict you anymore. You, me, and Ryoma, too—maybe we were originally created for this game, but we’ve more than taken back control of our lives.”

“Oh, what, because you’ve developed?” Tsumugi asks, a not of hostility in her voice. “That’s what fictional characters do. They have scripted plotlines and then—”

“And what about you?” Ryoma adds. “You said ‘all of us’ are fictional characters. So you wrote your own personality?”

Tsumugi waves a hand. “You’re over thinking it.”

“No, I’m not,” he says. “Are you real or are you fiction?”

“Well, of course I’m fiction,” Tsumugi huffs.

“Then show us your video,” Tenko says. “If your personality was written over, too, then you have to be like us, right? Did you just audition like all of us and then were turned into the mastermind?”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “Tsumugi Shirogane is just a character, but I’m not a participant or survivor the same way all of you are. If you must know, the situation is that you’re the players, and I’m a construct of the game.”

“I don’t think that’s true,” Kaede says. “I don’t think any of this is true.”

“Then show me proof that I’m lying,” Tsumugi says. “You can tell me what you believe in your heart about yourself as much as you want, but I’m telling you that your feelings are—”

“Fiction. You,” Kaede’s eyes flicker over Tsumugi, not in the aggressive glares she had given her earlier but something evaluative. “You really believe what you’re saying is the truth, don’t you? You’ve repeated your own lie back to yourself so many times that you think it’s real. That’s how you’re justify everything you’ve done to us—we’re just characters to you.”

Tsumugi frowns. “Is that honestly—”

“Kaede,” Tenko talks over her. “Do you think that if Tsumugi could see that we were really… she would let us go? Or maybe just feel remorse? She could still change…”

Tenko’s staring at her with hopeful eyes, and all Kaede can think about is how Kaito had told her he doesn’t think there is such a thing as an irredeemable person. Kaede feels something sour in her throat as she responds, “I don’t know, but… I doubt it.”

Tenko’s expression tightens as she simply responds, “So… that is what Kaede really thinks…”

“Are you really trying to psychoanalyze me?” Tsumugi cuts in. “I already told you: I am the mastermind hiding in plain sight. That is my character. We are all characters in Dangan Ronpa, and we can all only exist in Dangan Ronpa. There is no ‘changing’ or ‘outgrowing’ no matter how much you try and convince yourselves because that’s not how this works!”

“No…” Ryoma says slowly. “Starting to think Kaede was right. Kind of.”

“‘Kind of?’” Kaede echoes. “Did you figure something else out, Ryoma?”

“Think so,” Ryoma answers. “Though we should ask Tsumugi since…” his eyes cast over Tsumugi. “Still unsure how much she’s deluding herself.”

Tsumugi’s previous haughty composure is almost completely gone as she snarls at him in the next debate.

(Present your Argument) 

“I don’t know how you all got this into your heads,” Tsumugi says. “But you’re all fiction and nothing more.”

“You’re admitting our thoughts are our own,” Tenko says. “Tenko knew her feelings were real…”

“They’re not!” Tsumugi says. “They were scripted! There’s a writing credit on everything in this world! This world is the ultimate real fiction, and we’re all characters in it!”

“We’re characters,” Ryoma says. “That’s what you think.”

“Of course it is because it’s the truth!” Tsumugi shouts. “Nothing here is real and that’s that!”

“Hey,” Tenko says softly. “Tsumugi said earlier that Rantaro was real, didn’t she?”

Ryoma smiles. “Glad you caught that, too.”

“As in he was a real character and not an actor,” Tsumugi huffs. “No matter how you try to twist my words, the truth doesn’t change. You can pick at it for as long as you like, but as long as you’re fiction—which you are—there is no other choice but for you to accept the story you were written!”

(BREAK) 

“I think,” Kaede says. “I understand now.”

“So we’re all on the same page then,” Ryoma says.

“Tenko thinks so, too,” Tenko chimes in.

Tsumugi is fuming when she speaks. “Obviously, no, plainly none of you understand anything.”

“I can explain it for you,” Kaede says. “Isn’t that what you want my ‘character’ to do, after all? Solve mysteries?”

“There isn’t a mystery,” Tsumugi fires back. “Because I already told you the truth.”

“And that truth is a lie you’ve tricked yourself into believing for so long that you convinced yourself it was real,” Kaede says. “And I refuse to abide by your reality for even another second.”

“Alright!” Tsumugi shouts, throwing her hands in the air. “Just what is it that is making you so sure!? Because there is nothing, and that is the honest truth!”

Kaede straightens her shoulders, finding her center while Tsumugi unravels. “You—you’re why we’re all so sure.”

“I—what!?”

“Your words and what you really believe don’t line up,” Kaede says. “You told us that Rantaro was both a real person and a fictional character.”

“Because it’s real fiction,” Tsumugi says. “Fiction using real people.”

“Then,” Kaede says. “If that is true, and Rantaro and everyone else are just fictional characters parading around in the bodies of real people, why did you tell us you can’t cosplay as him?”

Tsumugi shakes her head. She starts to say, “Because I can’t—” and cuts herself off abruptly.

“If you truly think I’m fictional,” Kaede says. “Then show me proof. You tried it once, and I’m fine with you trying it again. Dress up as me. Be me. Show me I’m not real to you.”

Tsumugi doesn’t respond but her pale face, tightly clenched jaw, and sweat beading on her forehead speak for her.

Tenko says. “You can’t, can you? Tsumugi, you do know that we’re real, and you’ve been hurting us because—”

“No,” Tsumugi says. “No, no, no—you don’t get it. This is fiction! All of this is fiction! We were born for this story, and we die when it ends! That’s it! Why don’t you get that!? Look! Look at this and tell me you’re not fiction!”

Not just the previous monitor, but every display in the room flicks on in a flurry. Each shows what Kaede realizes is a different audition tape, all playing at once.

Tsumugi keeps talking over them, her words start coming out in a torrent, but Kaede holds her ground.

 


(THEORY ARMAMENT) 

“How many times do I have to explain this!?”
“Doesn’t matter if they’re weak or strong—I’ll crush them like a bug.”

“Nothing is real! Your friends, your homes, your memories, your lives—they’re all fiction!”
“I think I’d prefer to be the first victim… surviving sounds too tiring…”

“You can’t ‘outgrow’ what you are! There is no changing! It doesn’t work that way!”
“I want to be someone important, even if only for a little while. Dangan Ronpa can grant that wish, right?”

“We’re not real people—we’re not like everyone on the outside world!”
“I’ll do my best! I promise I’ll be funny and interesting and likable and—”

“This is the only world we belong in: the world of fiction!”
“You can do whatever you would like with my character. I am yours to mold as you see fit.”

“I know you’re fiction—I’ve always known! The fact that I can’t cosplay you is irrelevant!”
“And I’ve thought of the perfect punishment for an Ultimate Detective—everyone will love it!”

“Do I need to show you your audition again!? How can you say that you’re real after seeing that!?”
“Honestly, I just want to fight. I have so much anger, and I want nothing more than to take it out on someone. I’ll make sure to make it the best murder possible.”

“You can’t change what you are! You think anyone cares about something as stupid as how ‘far you’ve come!?’ Just accept that that’s nonsense!”
“Everyone will love me! No matter what happens, my character is gonna make you lots and lots of money guaranteed.”

“People barely change, and we’re not even people!”
“Don’t really care if I live or die, but it sure would be a hell of a way to go.”

“You’re not your own person! You were created!”
“I’m not just gonna survive, I’m gonna kill everybody and win!”

“Stop denying what you are!”
“I want to be on Dangan Ronpa because… because I’d be good at it. That’s all.”

“We are all fiction and there is no denying that truth!” 

 (BREAK)

 



“You’ve told me over and over,” Kaede says, “that the truth is only what everyone believes—what you convince yourself. And,” she looks to Tenko and Ryoma each in turn, “I know what we believe, and the truth is, no matter what you say, you believe it, too.”

“That’s ridiculous!” Tsumugi screams. “You can’t just make something up because it’s more convenient for you!”

“I know,” Kaede says. “It takes a lot to change who you are, but that’s exactly what we’ve done. But even before everything, we were real people. It’s impossible just to take someone’s humanity away, and you know that. No matter how much you distanced yourself from what you were doing by calling us ‘characters,’ you knew you were hurting real people, didn’t you?”

Tsumugi’s eyes burn with rage, but she doesn’t respond other than clenching her jaw in fury.

Monokuma giggles. “Looks like they got you.”

“Shut up!” Tsumugi snaps at him.

Ryoma sighs. “She’s not going to accept it. Sometimes it doesn’t matter how you right are about something.”

“I guess not,” Kaede says. “But I think it’s safe to say that we’re done with this conversation, right?”

“Tenko thinks so,” Tenko says. “Um, Tenko also wants to say something else.”

Tsumugi’s still arguing with Monokuma, but Kaede blithely ignores her as she says to Tenko, “sure, go ahead. I don’t think we have to talk about whatever Tsumugi wants anymore.”

Tenko nods. “Tenko just wanted to say, um, Ryoma,” he blinks up at her in surprise at the address but remains silent as she continues. “Earlier you said we didn’t have futures because of this game and what Tsumugi did to us, but… do you still think that?”

Ryoma pauses for a second. Then, “Not sure. Figured since our personalities and memories were created, we had no place to go or purpose but,” he sends a meaningful look to Kaede. “Think we proved that’s not true. Whatever happens next is probably going to be pretty brutal, but… we don’t just stop existing, do we?”

“And as long as we exist, we have a future,” Kaede says. “Maybe that’s not the most optimistic thing, but it’s true.”

“Tenko is glad,” Tenko says. “She knows she picked despair, but… Tenko doesn’t want to stay here forever.”

Ryoma gives her a knowing half smile. “Didn’t think you did.”

“Yeah, I think staying stuck in ‘fiction land’ starts to do things to your head after a while, too,” Kaede says, sending a pointed look towards Tsumugi. “Kind of a cautionary tale for when you can’t separate yourself from fiction and accept reality, if you think about it.”

“You say that,” Ryoma says. “But are we accepting reality?”

“Tenko thinks we are,” Tenko says. “Thinking you can never change or shouldn’t try… that’s not reality.”

“It’s not, and,” Kaede says, standing up straighter. “Now that we know exactly where we stand with this game, I think we need to make our own choice.”

“Oh?” Monokuma says, cutting into their conversation. “Are you talking about the vote?”

“Th-That’s right!” Tsumugi says. “No matter what you think, the only way out of this game is by choosing hope or despair!”

Kaede shakes her head. “I don’t believe that.”

“What do you mean you ‘don’t believe?’” Tsumugi says. “Hope and despair are your only options, and if you refuse to vote, you die. You’re not really about to throw your lives away after making it this far, are you?”

“Those are the choices you’ve given us,” Kaede says. “But I don’t think I’m going to listen to you anymore.”

“If you try and leave the trial, you’ll be killed,” Tsumugi says. “And you can’t just walk out of the killing game, either.”

“I know,” Kaede says.

“Then what, exactly, do you intend to do?” Tsumugi asks.

“I intend to beat the killing game,” Kaede says. “And make sure you’re punished for everything you’ve done to us.”

Tsumugi lets out a short laugh. “Oh, is this ‘the one to defeat the killing game is not to play?’ Well, I already told you that if you do that, you die.”

“And you don’t want that to happen, either, do you?” Kaede asks. “If we all just die at the end, then your audience would be really upset, wouldn’t they? They would hate that ending, and your fictional world would die along with us.”

Tsumugi narrows her eyes. “What are you getting at?”

“What Kaede’s trying to say,” Ryoma says. “Is that we’re the ones with all the power.”

“How do you have power?” Tsumugi scoffs. “You do what the rules say or you die.”

“Or,” Kaede says. “You do what we say or your whole show—all fifty-three seasons—ends here. Or actually, your show is probably going to end either way, given everything that’s happened. You just get to decide if it’s with a bang or whimper.”

“No survivors or four survivors,” Tenko says. “Tenko thinks that four would be preferable…”

“Three survivors,” Kaede says. “Tsumugi still gets her wish to die at the end.”

Tenko bites her lip. “The game ends with the three of us escaping, and Tsumugi being executed—that’s what Kaede wants.”

“And you think that’s really a possibility?” Tsumugi says. “I’m just as capable of being as spiteful as you, Kaede. I can vote, and you can all die. Dangan Ronpa ends with despair winning once and for all.”

“You’re lying,” Kaede says. “You can’t actually accept an ending like that. You already proved you can’t handle reality—Dangan Ronpa ending would destroy you.”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “I think I’ve heard enough. You can say you’re in control as much as you want, but at the end of the day, I have the power to kill you right now.” She looks up at Kaede, her glasses shining dangerously. “And I’m calling your bluff on betting your lives.”

“You think we wouldn’t?” Kaede asks.

“No,” Tsumugi says. “You all want to live too much—I can see it. I don’t think any of you are willing to die to prove a point to a world you hate. Maybe you’d sacrifice yourself to save your friends, sure, but Kaede, you’re the only person here who would actually die just for revenge.”

Kaede is about to contradict her when she notices Tenko fidgeting restlessly in the corner of her vision. Tenko keeps her gaze focused on the ground, refusing to meet Kaede’s eyes. “That…” Kaede says. “That doesn’t matter.”

“Your plan to defeat the killing game by playing it even harder is only going to get you so far,” Tsumugi says. “You need everyone on your side, and that’s not going to happen. Tenko?” Tenko’s head snaps up at the address towards her. “Are you willing to risk your life so Kaede can murder someone?”

“That’s not what’s happening here,” Kaede says. “And we’re not letting you manipulate us anymore.”

Tsumugi ignores her. “What about you, Ryoma? Do you want to throw away your chance at a future? Do either of you want to be responsible for more killing games?”

Ryoma tugs at his hat. He takes far too much time to eventually say, “Kaede’s right… we’re not listening to you.”

“And all of this,” Tsumugi says, “is based on how much you think you know me. Do you really think I wouldn’t take the people who destroyed my life’s work down with me?”

Kaede takes a deep breath. The control she had so confidently claimed only moments earlier begins to slip through her fingers with each word out of Tsumugi’s mouth. She squeezes her eyes closed, trying to push an answer to come to her through sheer force of will.

Tenko says, “‘Down with you?’ You’d die, too?”

“Of course,” Tsumugi says. “That’s why I don’t care—I’m dying either way. It’s just a question of if you all want to die with me.” She laughs. “Poor Kiibo will be left all alone wondering what happened.”

“Kiibo…” Kaede says. Then louder, “Kiibo, we need to talk to you.”

Tsumugi frowns at her. “I didn’t mean—”

The screen that had shown the videos before flicks on, Kiibo’s face front and center this time. “Yes, Kaede?” he says.

“Have you been listening in this whole time?” Ryoma asks.

“I have,” he says. “I currently have power over all the school’s recording systems.”

“Then,” Tenko says. “Why didn’t you come arlier?”

Ryoma lets out a sigh. “If you say no one asked you to…”

“Oh no,” Kiibo says. “I have simply been testing… more creative uses of my current power over the school.”

“What does that mean?” Ryoma asks.

Tsumugi scowls. “Kiibo is dead and will not be participating in this trial.”

“No,” Kaede says. “I called him for a very specific reason.” She shifts to point at Tsumugi. “If risking our lives is the problem, then I’ll find a solution. After everything you’ve put me through, nothing you could say would make me give up.”

“Yes, yes, you’re very determined,” Tsumugi says. “But Kiibo is supposed to solve that problem how?”

“You said I’m trying to stop the killing game by playing it better than you,” Kaede says. “But instead, I’m going to stop it by taking it over.”

“I didn’t say ‘better than—’” Tsumugi cuts herself off. “What?”

Tenko shoots her a nervous look. “Kaede?”

“Kiibo,” Kaede says. “Just now you said you’ve been getting creative with what you can do. Be honest with me, at this point, how much power does the mastermind actually have?”

“Th-There’s really no need to answer that!” Monokuma says, sweating bullets. “B-Because there’s n-no way a robot could outsmart a bear or—”

“At this juncture, the Monokuma in this room is the only thing I believe I do not have direct control over,” Kiibo says. “Monokuma still has the ability to call in extra weaponry from the outside as he did earlier somehow… but I believe he would have a bit of trouble getting the signal out from down here.”

Tsumugi pales as she sends a panicked look up to Monokuma. He does little to assuage her nerves as he stammers, “C-C’mon, just because w-we’re underground doesn’t mean something as crazy as that.”

“Normally that would be the case,” Kiibo says. “But I suspected this trial would be dangerous, so I took it upon myself while you were arguing to seal this room. Controlling an elevator is barely even half a step above controlling the doors in this academy.”

“So it’s safe to say Kiibo has complete power as long as we’re down here,” Ryoma says. “That changes things a bit. You think so, too, right Tsumugi?”

Tsumugi doesn’t respond. Monokuma says, “knew we shouldn’t have listened to that fan poll about adding a robot…”

Tenko says, “Kaede, did you know about all this? Is that why you called for Kiibo?”

“I actually had no idea,” Kaede says. “There was only one thing that I knew Kiibo had control over that I knew would help us.”

“Whatever it is, I will be sure to do my best to help,” Kiibo says. “As I cannot leave the school, I would like to dedicate my last acts to ensure your escape.”

“Good. Kiibo,” Kaede says, her gaze growing intense as she stares down Tsumugi. “I want you to execute Tsumugi.”

There is a pause. Then Tenko breaths out, “What?”

“That’s… a thing Kiibo can do?” Ryoma acts, his voice surprised though nowhere near as aghast as Tenko’s.

Kaede nods. “It is. Kiibo told me earlier that Miu gave him the power to stop Monokuma’s executions if they use technology. And if he can stop them, then why can’t we use him to create one ourselves?”

“I…” Kiibo says, “do believe I have the ability to do that. Is that your request then, Kaede?”

Tsumugi recovers from her panic enough to say, “S-So what? You know if I die, you’re all still trapped here.”

“Kiibo,” Kaede says. “I want you to use all of the assets Monokuma set aside to execute us and use them to create an execution so big that it will kill Tsumugi and take down the whole school with her.”

“Is that even possible?” Ryoma asks.

“It will take me a second to prepare,” Kiibo says. “But given the sheer magnitude of firepower specifically reserved for Monokuma’s punishments… I believe I could accomplish something of that magnitude.”

“But wait,” Tenko says. “If that’s true, couldn’t Kiibo just destroy the school without harming anyone?”

“That is also within my power, yes,” Kiibo says. “I should warn everyone to be wary of falling debris in either case due to the nature of the cage.”

“I think that’s a risk we’re all willing to take,” Kaede says. “Because now, we don’t even need to bet our lives at all. We win and you lose, Tsumugi. That’s how this ends”

Tsumugi pauses for a moment. “I lost…” She furrows her brow in concentration. “I see.”

Her lack of distress is unsettling, but Kaede continues on. “Here’s what’s going to happen—we’re going to walk out of here, and you’re going to experience all the pain you put everyone you executed through a hundred times over. And then, your sick show is going to be finished. No more killing games, no more Dangan Ronpa, no more anything.”

“I don’t…” Tsumugi says. “I don’t want to live in a world without Dangan Ronpa.”

“And you’re not going to,” Kaede says.

Tsumugi shifts, moving to hug herself. “I never… really got it before. I tried to imagine it, but I couldn’t quite get it. But, of course, the ultimate real fiction could do it.”

“Do… what?” Tenko softly asks.

“I wanted to live in the world of Dangan Ronpa and experience everything, and now I have,” Tsumugi says. “I now know exactly what she must have left like at the very beginning.”

“Who are you talking about?” Tenko asks.

“Ignore her,” Kaede says. “She’s just rambling now to try and save her life.”

“No, I wouldn’t do anything like that now,” Tsumugi says. “I knew as soon as I agreed to be the mastermind that I would die, but even then I didn’t think I would actually die feeling the amount of despair Enoshima Junko must have felt. I,” her face lights up, “I really did it. I became a mastermind just as strong and despicable and full of despair as Enoshima Junko, didn’t I?”

There’s a beat of silence as Tsumugi’s words sink in. Ryoma hesitantly asks, “You’re… fine with this then?”

“I’m more than fine,” Tsumugi says. “I knew I could already hold my head up high as a cosplaycat criminal, but now I can do even more than that. This is… this is the perfect ending for Dangan Ronpa.”

Kaede’s face twists in revulsion. “There’s something wrong with you. I think I’d be less disgusted if you plead for your life or something, but you’re not even human enough to do that, are you?”

“Kaede,” Tenko says, a note of severity creeping into her voice.

“Oh, I have no intention of begging for you to spare me,” Tsumugi says. “This is… this is what I want more than anything. Give me an execution befitting—no, even better—than Enoshima Junko’s and step forward into the world filled with hope!”

Ryoma turns away, pulling at his hat as he mumbles to himself, “I can’t listen to this.”

“I think,” Kaede says. “I think I can agree to that. My only regret is that we weren’t able to do this at the very beginning before Rantaro’s death, even if you would have only counted as another participant.”

“That would have been such a boring story, though,” Tsumugi says. “But this—this is a story that would make any Dangan Ronpa fan proud. I hope you all feel honored to be a part of this.”

“I don’t give a damn about Dangan Ronpa,” Kaede says. “But having any hand in your death is more than enough for me.”

Tsumugi smiles. “I’d say now we should all vote, but there isn’t even really an option for this outcome. Though that’s really not a big deal since the last vote is always just kind of a ceremony thing, to be honest.”

“Aw man, my career ending and my life ending just like that?” Monokuma says. “I’ve been working for fifty years, and I don’t even get to enjoy my retirement!”

“That’s enough,” Kaede says. “I don’t want to hear another word out of either of you ever again! You’ve killed and you’ve ruined lives, and now you’re going to get everything you deserve!”

“That’s right,” Tsumugi says. “It’s punishment time, isn’t it? This is goodbye to Dangan Ronpa.”

“Kiibo,” Kaede says. “Do it. Take this whole school down, too.”

“Understood,” he says. “If you believe this is the best path for ending despair, then I will begin the—”

“Wait!”

The sudden voice breaks through the angry haze that had been clouding Kaede’s mind for just a moment. “What?”

“T-Tenko thinks,” Tenko says. “Tenko thinks we should still vote.”

Kaede stares at her, confused. “Why?”

“If you’re concerned about making it official, don’t worry,” Tsumugi says. “We’ve more than gone off the rails at this point. All that matters is that the end is as big and spectacular as possible.”

“That’s what Tenko doesn’t want,” Tenko says. “Because—because if that does happen, then…”

“Then what?” Kaede asks, impatience creeping into her voice.

“Then the killing games won’t actually end like you said,” Tenko says. “Tenko won’t be a part of that. And,” she takes a breath before straightening her back to stand taller. “And Tenko won’t be a part of killing someone either.”

Kaede feels her mouth fall open in shock. Ryoma is only slightly less bewildered as he says, “Tenko?”

Monokuma giggles. “Ooh, what’s this? A new challenger?”

“Shut up!” Kaede snaps at him. “Tenko, you—”

“Kiibo,” Tenko says. “Tenko thinks that whatever way we choose to escape, it should be unanimous. Do you agree?”

Kaede calls after her again. “Tenko—”

“I… do see the merit in that,” Kiibo says. “If there is any hesitation, I believe it should be properly discussed before taking action.”

“Are you—what!?” Kaede shouts. “Tenko, what are you doing?”

“Tenko is,” she says, “Tenko is arguing against you.”

Chapter End Notes

As you can see the chapter count has been updated! I'm a bit unsure how long the last trial chapter will be (though I predict a bit shorter), and after that there will be the epilogue that will hopefully come out pretty soon after it. Also for those wondering, every line from an audition video is matched with a specific person, though some of them are admittedly a bit (or a lot) harder to decode than others, haha.

Trial XV

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

Even before Shuichi died and everything changed, Tenko can’t recall a time when she hadn’t leapt to Kaede’s side. Even when standing with her had made her heart hurt, Tenko had tried to be a shoulder to lean on in the worst of times. Now she says to her, “Kaede, please, think about what you’re saying.”

“I—what? Of course I am,” Kaede says. “I’ve been thinking about this since the moment I discovered there was a mastermind.”

Tenko looks crestfallen at her answer. “Tenko is sorry to hear that, but,” she shakes her head. “That just means that she apologizes for not talking to you earlier! Tenko is sorry that she has failed you as a friend!”

Kaede’s eyes widen. “What? What are you talking about? You haven’t done anything.”

“No, Tenko didn’t do anything up until now,” she says. “And Tenko is very sorry for that.”

Kaede is still staring at her in shock. Tenko closes her eyes for a brief moment to find and center her energy like her master had taught her so long ago.

(Rebuttal Showdown) 

“I don’t understand what you’re talking about.”

“After everything that’s happened, killing Tsumugi is the only way we can walk away from this.”

“When Rantaro died, I promised him I would kill the mastermind.”

“And it’s not just for him either. Shuichi, Gonta, Himiko—we’re doing this for them.”

“It’s justice.”

(Advance) 

“You don’t really think that.”

“Kaede, you know nothing about these trials is just.”

“I know what you’re going to say.”

“If we kill Tsumugi, then we’re just like her, but that’s not true.”

“Killing the person who is completely unrepentant about torturing us isn’t a slippery slope to hosting killing games.”

“We’re so close to ending not just this game, but every killing game.”

“And this is the way to do it. After this, the killings will stop forever.”

(BREAK) 

“No,” Tenko shakes her head. “Kaede, you know that’s not true. Don’t you remember what Maki said in her message?”

Kaede frowns at her. “She said that Monokuma couldn’t enforce his own rules and the killing game was a sham.”

“Hey now!” Monokuma says. “I’ll have you know—”

“Quiet,” Ryoma snaps at him.

“No,” Tenko says. “Maki said that it’s impossible to end a killing game with more killing. Tsumugi said it, too; we don’t beat anything by following the rules.”

“We’re not following the rules,” Kaede says. “Obviously none of this would have happened if we were working within Monokuma’s rules.”

“Kaede, please think. Monokuma isn’t in control anymore but you are, and you’re doing exactly what would have happened even if—”

“No!” Kaede shouts back. “I’m protecting us! I’m not forcing some weird ‘sacrifice’ thing onto us or—”

“You’re making us kill each other!” Tenko shouts. “And Tenko was absolutely horrified and disgusted with herself every time Monokuma would make her kill her friends so she could live, and she refuses to do it anymore!” Tenko takes a deep breath and says softer, “Kaede, don’t you remember? Even when the culprits hurt our friends, you wanted so badly not to vote for them.”

Kaede clenches her jaw. “This is different. Tsumugi isn’t our friend. She’s the person who forced us into this situation in the first place.”

“I never forced anything,” Tsumugi says. “You signed yourselves up remember?”

Kaede throws a hand in Tsumugi’s direction. “See? Even now she’s mocking us.”

“I’m not making fun of you,” Tsumugi says. “I’m just telling the truth.”

“Tsumugi isn’t the only person behind this,” Tenko says. “She has an entire team—”

“That doesn’t make her less guilty for what she’s done,” Kaede says. “And if we let her live, she’s just going to keep going and make more games and hurt more people.”

“Tenko… Tenko doesn’t know if that’s true. Tsumugi isn’t the person behind all the killing games.”

Kaede crosses her arms. “Well, no, I know that. It’s her audience, and as much as I would like to punish them, too, that’s impossible.”

“It’s supply and demand, really,” Tsumugi says nonchalantly. “The world wants killing games, and Team Dangan Ronpa provides them.”

“You said each ending gives them hope that fuels another season or something,” Ryoma says. “Is that it?”

“And, Kaede,” Tenko says. “An ending where we execute the mastermind and walk away like in all the other games… that won’t do anything but give Tsumugi’s audience hope for the next killing game.”

“It won’t break the cycle…” Ryoma says.

Uncertainty flickers across Kaede’s face for a moment before Tsumugi says, “But who cares about that? The next killing game will be made using fans volunteering—the very same people who cheered you on throughout your game. Don’t you think it’s justice to make them go through what you went through?” She laughs. “Actually, from that perspective, it’s in your best interest to continue the games, don’t you think? You said it yourself, Kaede. You want to punish the world that put you here.”

“That’s not…” Kaede starts to say.

“Stop twisting Kaede’s words!” Tenko shouts. “Tenko knows that Kaede makes mistakes—that she can be vengeful or push too hard—but she’s a good person, and she feels empathy and regret towards everyone she hurts. And… And Tenko knows that if she lets Kaede do this, it will haunt her forever.”

Kaede bites her lip. “I… don’t know about—”

“Kaede,” Tenko says. “Please. You know yourself, and you know your real feelings.”

“I do,” Kaede says slowly, taking a moment to choose her words. “And… and I can handle it. It’s fine. I promise.”

“Fine for who?” Tenko asks.

Kaede shakes her head. “For everyone.”

“When we were both holed up in Tenko’s room,” Ryoma says. “Kaede, you said that you missed everyone who had died, even the people who had betrayed us. And out of everyone, I…” he takes in a deep breath, “maybe it was all made up, but I know what it’s like to have death haunt you.”

Kaede bites her lip, and says under her breath to herself, “that was different…”

Tsumugi scoffs. “Ryoma, you’re really turning around and being all open and forgiving now? Don’t you remember how miserable you were? Your entire life before and during the game has been nothing but pain, and I’m the one who gave you that life.”

Ryoma eyes her wearily. “You want to die… really, really badly, huh?” He shakes his head. “Not sure what to think about that, but I’ve said it a thousand times already, I’ve more than learned my lesson. It’s not my place to decide if someone lives or dies.”

“Well in the trials it is,” Tsumugi says. “It’s everyone’s place—this is everyone’s decision. You made Kiibo agree that you all have to be unanimous in your decision, so abstaining isn’t an option. If you don’t vote to kill me, then that means you think I deserve to live where everyone else has died.”

“No, that’s wrong,” Tenko says. “Everyone deserves to live.”

“I already told you,” Tsumugi says. “I’m not part of ‘everyone.’ My life begins and ends with Dangan Ronpa. And besides, there’s really no need to feel guilty for killing off a fictional character, you know?”

Tenko fidgets, slightly unnerved by her dismissal. “Tsumugi… deserves to live.”

“You really don’t want justice for Himiko, then?” Tsumugi says. “You know I didn’t think twice about strangling her.”

“Tenko knows that,” she says. “And that you lied to Tenko’s face when you pretended to comfort her or act like you were her friend. But Tenko also knew she would be betrayed by someone, and she promised herself that she wouldn’t hurt them the same way they hurt her. That just leads to more anger and pain, and,” she looks to Kaede, “and Tenko is sorry she didn’t help Kaede enough when she saw her going through that, and Ryoma, too, when he was hurt.”

Tsumugi laughs softly. “Honestly, at this point I don’t know if you’re a saint or just hopelessly naïve. Of course the funny thing is that after that wonderful little speech, Kaede still wants my head on a spike. It’s actually kind of pathetic how all of your platitudes have really got you nothing but a pile of corpses for the entire—”

“How dare you!” Kaede shouts at her. “Tenko is the one person here who actually gives a damn about you. Are you really such a disgusting, miserable person that you’d—”

“Ha!” Tsumugi laughs. “Looks like I was right. I think I know Kaede a bit too well. We really are quite alike.”

Kaede is on the verge of yelling at her again, when Tenko says, “Kaede, it’s okay. Please try not to get too angry at Tsumugi.”

Kaede gapes at her. “How can you say that?”

“Tenko is angry, too, and she has always believed in proudly living with your emotions,” she says. “But she doesn’t want Kaede’s anger to consume her anymore. Tenko admires how much you care—it’s one of her favorite things about you—but you care too much and feel too responsible that… you do things. You hurt people. And Tenko promised she would help you, but she hasn’t and—”

“Tenko, no, that’s not…” Kaede shakes her head. “You’re not responsible for me like that.”

“No,” Tenko says. “Tenko knew what you were feeling, and she never—”

“Tenko,” Ryoma says. “Out of all of us, you’re the last person who should be apologizing. Think I understand what you’re trying to say, too, so just… let me say something. It might clear things up, especially if Kaede’s still on the fence. ”

Tenko gives him a measuring looked but nods her head. “Go ahead, Ryoma. Also,” she smiles softly. “Don’t interrupt Tenko like a rude boy.”

He smiles back. “I’ll remember for next time.”

Tsumugi, by contrast, is unmoved. “You know, the group hugs usually come after the trial is ov—”

“Shut up, Tsumugi,” Ryoma says.

(Present your Argument) 

“Does it really matter if the killing games continue?” Tsumugi asks. “After all, it’s really not your problem, you know? You don’t actually care if a few more freaky Dangan Ronpa fans get what they deserve. It’s karma, isn’t it?”

“I don’t…” Kaede starts to say.

“You have a strong sense of justice,” Tsumugi continues. “And punishing the people who made you suffer—isn’t that justice? You even pointed out the game wasn’t fair because it was punishing the wrong people. But you can set it all right and punish the right people.”

“…” Kaede bites her lip.

“You made a promise to everyone, too. The entire time you’ve been here has been leading up to this moment. And there are really no downsides. You get to leave the game and get a little revenge, too.

“So just think about it. Isn’t in your best interest to let the killing games continue?”

(BREAK) 

“Tsumugi,” Ryoma says. “I thought I told you to shut up.”

“I was just saying—”

“Kaede,” he says. “You told me a while ago that the reason you’ve been going for this long is just out of sheer stubbornness, yeah?”

Kaede’s voice is quiet. “I remember.”

“At the time, have to admit, I thought you were pretty cool when you said that. Realize now that you didn’t think there was anything else good about yourself,” Ryoma says. “I understand what it’s like to hate yourself and think it’s too late for you to stop doing bad things. Or when all you want to do is lash out at the things that made you that way.”

Kaede takes a deep breath and rubs at her eyes. “Yeah…”

“Remember you also told me that at the trials, whenever you’d find the culprit, there was never any satisfaction. All you were left with was the anguish on their face,” Ryoma shakes his head. “Tenko was right, and you already know it. Forget Tsumugi. If you do something like this, it’ll hang over your head forever, right?”

He nods to Shuichi’s hat, discarded on the floor, and Kaede follows his gaze. “And you already said you were done punishing yourself.”

Kaede stares at the hat for a long moment before the tears starting to burn behind her eyes become too great to ignore. The second she starts to wipe at her eyes with her sleeves, a dam seems to break, and she struggles to keep her shuddering breaths quiet.

Monokuma lets out a squawk in protest as Tenko steps off of her podium, but she pays him little mind as she hurries to Kaede’s side. Tenko wastes no time wrapping her arms around Kaede’s shoulders to pull her into a comforting hug, even as she protests, muttering, “I’m okay, I’m okay.”

Ryoma sighs as he, too, walks away from his trial stand and over to Kaede. “Sorry, Kaede. I didn’t mean to make you cry. I shouldn’t have said—”

“No,” Kaede says, her words slightly muffled into Tenko’s shoulder. “No, it’s okay.”

Tsumugi says, “The trial isn’t over yet, and you’re not allowed to leave your stands until we’re finished.”

“Tsumugi,” Ryoma says. “We are done.”

“No,” she says. “The trial ends when we come to a consensus and—”

“We know,” Tenko says. “And Tenko thinks we are all agreed.” She pulls away from Kaede just enough to look into her eyes. “Is… Kaede okay with that?”

Kaede nods, and wipes her tears on the back of her hand one last time. “I—I am.” She pauses, taking a deep breath, before looking to both Ryoma and Tenko. “And… thank you.”

“Don’t mention it,” Ryoma says with a gentle smile.

Kaede can’t help but let out a choked laugh. “Sorry. I don’t think that’s possible for me. Seriously, thank you. I think I’m okay now. Or, at least I know I can get through this now.”

Tenko smiles, too, as she finally releases Kaede, though their hands remain intertwined. “Tenko is glad to hear that, but,” she squeezes Kaede’s hand. “She thinks she’ll stay by Kaede’s side if that’s okay.”

“Of course it is,” Kaede says, squeezing back. “I want you both by my side.” She looks down to Ryoma. “Just in case if I’m about to go off the deep end again.”

“Don’t think that will happen now, Kaede,” Ryoma says. “But… think I’ll stick around, too.”

“So,” Tsumugi says. “Instead of the protagonist bringing hope, everyone else brings hope to her. Hmm, well, it’s a bit different from tradition, but I guess it could work.”

Kaede glances across the way to Tsumugi standing alone. “I don’t know what you think ‘hope’ is. I’m not holding out for something better, or thinking that things will just work out. Because you were right.” Kaede glances briefly to Tenko for support and then down to Ryoma. “I hate you. I hate you more than I even thought was possible.”

“Glad to hear it,” Tsumugi says. “But you can’t bring yourself to kill me now or something?”

“No, I know I could, and I know that I hate myself enough to do it, too,” Kaede says. “But if I want to change that—if I want to finally stop punishing myself—then I can’t get stuck on hating you.”

“That’s—oh, that’s just plain nonsense, and you know it,” Tsumugi says.

“You don’t get it,” Ryoma says. “You already explained how you see things. We’re all static to you, but that’s not how real people are.”

Tsumugi shakes her head. “No, that’s exactly how people are. People want the same things over and over again, and they get mad about the same things and make the same mistakes. History repeats itself, and the killing game has repeated itself for this long because that’s just the way things are. You can’t possibly think your little stand now about ‘forgiveness’ or any of that crap actually matters to a world that’s happily watched over fifty seasons of killing games and is dying to watch fifty more.”

Monokuma throws one of his paws in the air. “That’s right! Dangan Ronpa exists because of fans like you and your support! And if you’d like to support your adorable mascot and his plans to get a speedboat even more, then sign up for a premium account at—”

“You can plug the merch later,” Tsumugi snaps. “This is important.”

“Ooh, someone’s getting testy,” Monokuma says. “There’s really no need to get so upset, though. Like you said, even after the show’s over, the audience always comes back for more.”

“I know,” Kaede says. “You’ve made it very clear what your audience is like, and I know that the world out there is probably full of people who are yelling at me to stop talking and kill you.”

Tsumugi laughs. “Oh, you have no idea how right you are. If only you could see what the audience has been saying about you. They’ve been calling for my head for ages now. So many descriptions about just how satisfying it would be for Tenko to bash my head in.” She smiles brightly at Tenko. “You’re really letting them down, you know.”

“If you think Tenko will resort to killing—”

“Oh, no, don’t get upset now,” Tsumugi dismisses with a wave of her hand. “It’s not what I think; I’m just saying what the audience wants. Actually, would you believe how many people were disappointed you weren’t the mastermind? It’s funny, but I guess they just couldn’t resist the potential despair.”

“I get it. The world doesn’t care about us or recognize us as people,” Kaede says. “And I also know that fighting a world like that—trying to tell the very people who would throw their lives away in a second for a chance to participate in a killing game… that’s just impossible isn’t it?”

Tsumugi blinks at her. “Huh? That’s not what you’re—”

“The cycle you were talking about doesn’t just end, does it? Maybe Dangan Ronpa will end after this, but that doesn’t really fix the problem,” Kaede says. “The world that allowed the killing game to happen in the first place still exists. Killing you, yelling at your audience how much I hate them—none of that does anything.”

Tsumugi pauses. “So… what are you going to do then? Are you actually falling into despair over ever changing anything?”

“No,” Kaede says. “I’m breaking the cycle for myself, and maybe…” she sighs, squeezing her eyes shut for a moment. “Maybe if someone like me can let go of their hate and want to change, other people will, too. I’ll just… have to find them when I get out of here.”

“Our lives don’t stop with the killing game,” Ryoma says. “We’re all going to keep living. There isn’t an end of ‘hope’ or ‘despair.’ There’s just life.”

“And Tenko agrees with Kaede,” Tenko says. “There have to be people, other survivors, who know that this is wrong—that there are no people who ‘deserve’ to be put through the killing game and hurt the same way. Tenko is going to keep fighting, Tsumugi, but fighting within your rules does nothing to stop you.”

“And letting me get away scot-free does?” Tsumugi says. “Just listen to yourselves—you’re not making any sense.”

Kaede steps forward. “Tsumugi, you know this isn’t your story anymore. We’re not your characters, and you’re not some final boss we need to defeat.”

“I-I told you that’s nonsense!” Tsumugi snaps. “No matter what you say, you’re fiction, and I’m fiction, and all of this is—”

“That’s why you want to die so badly, isn’t it?” Kaede asks. “You’ve convinced yourself that you can’t live outside of the game. You can’t face going back to the real world.”

She scoffs. “You have no idea what the world outside is like, and you know even less about me.”

“Maybe not the specifics,” Kaede concedes. “But you said we were similar. If you know what I’m thinking, then I can make some guesses about what you’re—”

“No, you idiot!” Tsumugi says. “I know you because I wrote you! An author knows their characters—and, yes, sometimes they project themselves onto their creations—but the characters can never know their creator!”

“You’re contradicting yourself again,” Ryoma says. “You want to be fiction and stand outside of it at the same time. And you still refuse to be honest with yourself, too, it seems.”

Tsumugi’s rebuilt composure fades fast. “I am fiction! All of this is fiction! We were created when the story began, and our lives end when the story finishes! Whatever is on the outside world has nothing to do with us! There is no ‘breaking the cycle’ because the cycle is all of our lives!”

“Tsumugi,” Tenko says. “You knew you were going to die at the end of the killing game from the very beginning, didn’t you?”

“Of course I did,” Tsumugi huffs.

“What were you before the game, then?” Tenko asks. “You had a life before you—”

“That doesn’t matter,” she says. “Dangan Ronpa is my life, and I’ll say it as many times as I need to until you understand!”

(Rebuttal Showdown) 

“You can make up whatever you want to about me, but the truth is I have no existence outside of Dangan Ronpa.”

“Even if you insist that I’m real, my purpose was always to join Dangan Ronpa and become real fiction.”

“You’re all stuck on making up new lies about yourselves, so you have no idea what I’m actually like.”

“If you had half the knowledge I do about our lives, then you’d know that all of us have no future and no past.”

“Whether you live or die at the game’s end—I don’t give a damn because as far as me and everyone at home is concerned, you’re finished as soon as they click off their TVs.”

(Advance) 

Ryoma says, “Why do you care so much about what your audience thinks about you?”

“They’re going to go on with their lives. Why can’t you go on with yours?”

“Fiction is defined by the outside world.”

“The only reason Dangan Ronpa exists is because the outside world wants it.”

“The only reason we exist is because the outside world wants us to.”

“As soon as we fade from memory, we might as well all be dead for all that we’re worth.”

“That is the purpose not just of fiction, but of everyone who wants to mean anything in the world!”

(Advance) 

“You really don’t think you can find your own worth, do you Tsumugi?” Tenko asks.

“You’ve built up Dangan Ronpa so much that you’d rather die than try to move on from it.”

“Why would I want to ‘move on?’ It’s who I am.”

“There is nothing for me in the world besides Dangan Ronpa.”
