“You might lie to yourselves and pretend the outside world will accept you after this, but there is no chance that will happen, especially for me.”

“I’m not your friend, I’m not a person. I exist only for Dangan Ronpa, and in Dangan Ronpa, the mastermind dies at the end.”

“Dying for Dangan Ronpa is the only thing I want.”

(Advance) 

“I’ve decided,” Kaede says.

“I’m not going to punish you by leaving you alive, and I’m not going to put you out of your misery, either.”

“Oh, it is far too late to be wishy-washy like that, Kaede.”

“It’s pointless to try to find the middle ground between hope and despair or lies and the truth, or anything else you can think of.”

“And you want to know why? Because no one wants a story like that!”

“And in this story, you kill the mastermind! You defeat despair and everyone is happy!”

“From the very beginning, that’s how your story was meant to end! There is no changing, there is no moving forward, and there is no ‘breaking the cycle’ for any of us!”

(BREAK) 

Tsumugi’s hands gripping her podium are white knuckled, and she looks half deranged after her one-sided shouting match. “There! That’s everything! That’s—”

“You refuse to move on,” Kaede says.

“Not ‘refuse,’” Tsumugi says. “It’s impossible to—”

“We’re all going to carry what happened here with us forever,” Kaede says. “Even if I tried my hardest for the rest of my life, I don’t think I could ever forget the things I went through or the people I met.”

Tsumugi lets out a clipped laugh. “So you’re traumatized forever—good to know. Seems you finally understand what I’m—”

“That’s not it,” Kaede says. “Everyone who died—Kaito, Miu, Himiko, Gonta, and Rantaro and Shuichi, too—I know I’ll remember them, but I’m not going to torture myself over it anymore.”

“And what does that have to do with—”

“My life is worth more than what you put me through,” Kaede says. “Everyone’s lives are worth so much more than this game, including yours.”

Tsumugi is furious as she shakes her head back and forth, her previous plain hair flurrying around her in a hurricane. “No, no, no! My life is Dangan—”

“Tenko doesn’t forgive you, but she does feel sorry for you, Tsumugi,” Tenko says. “She can’t imagine what it’s like to convince yourself your own life isn’t worth more than a story.”

“Not quite sure I’m as sympathetic,” Ryoma says. “But it’s not our place to decide whether you live or die.”

“Then let me die!” Tsumugi screams. “I choose to die!” Though it has no effect, Tsumugi slams her hand on the voting buttons on her podium. “Kill me! Just kill me already!”

There’s little for the survivors to do than exchange looks with each other as Tsumugi keeps shouting at nothing. “Hard to believe it ends like this,” Ryoma says after a moment. “But the game is finally over, isn’t it?”

“I think so,” Kaede says. She looks up to an overhead monitor. “Kiibo? Are you still there?”

His voice is much weaker than before as he responds, “I am…”

“I want to ask one last time, is there really no way to save you?” Kaede asks.

“No,” Kiibo says. “I have already begun diverting power to my plan to assist in your escape, and… like I predicted, I do not have the ability to escape the school. Unlike all of you, it is impossible for me to exist outside of the killing game.”

“Kiibo,” Tenko says. “Is there really no way to take you with—”

“No,” he says again. “But that is okay. Once my body was destroyed, I got the chance to act for myself, which is more than I believe I was ever meant for. I suppose,” the project of his face smiles sadly, “I should thank Miu for that as well. I just hope helping her friends escape is enough to show my gratitude for everything she did.”

“You’re our friend, too,” Ryoma says, returning his smile. “Even if you are a robot.”

“That is robophobic, even if I do appreciate your lighthearted, friendly ribbing,” Kiibo says.

“No problem,” Ryoma says. “And if it matters, think you were getting more human every second, even now.”

Kiibo goes quiet for a moment. Then, “thank you. I believe the same is true for you. Now is everyone ready?”

Kaede sends a quick look to both Ryoma and Tenko for confirmation before nodding. “I think we’ve been ready since the day we got here.”

“Fair enough,” Kiibo says. “Also, I advise caution. This process is going to be… destructive.”

“That is fine,” Tenko says. “Tenko will protect Kaede and Ryoma from any danger.”

“Make sure you take care of yourself, too,” Ryoma advises. “We didn’t come this far to have anyone get crushed by rubble or something at the last second.”

“Exactly,” Kiibo says. “Please be ready. And goodbye.”

He doesn’t give them the chance to respond, his screen flickering off as Kaede says, “Kiibo—”

The rest of her words die as the floor begins to shake. Monokuma screeches, ducking behind his podium. Tenko says, “We need to get out of here. There is a chance the elevator might collapse if we do not move fast enough.”

“Right,” Kaede says. She starts to head towards the elevator, but notices a tug on her hand as Tenko stays in place. “Tenko?”

“You and Ryoma hurry,” she says. “Tenko will be right there.”

Kaede exchanges a nervous glance with Ryoma as she lets go of Tenko’s hand. “Okay. Just hurry.”

“Tenko will,” she says before darting across the room. Kaede watches her just long enough to realize she’s heading for Tsumugi, hunched over her podium.

“Kaede,” Ryoma says to prompt her. Kaede nods distractedly and follows him to the elevator even as she keeps one eye on Tenko.

It’s difficult to hear the specifics of their conversation over the increasingly loud rumbling, and Kaede has to keep her focus on her steps as the group shudders more with every second. From what she can tell, Tsumugi appears to be dead to the world, shutting out Tenko shaking her shoulders and whispering to her that they need to escape. Kaede has to catch Ryoma once when his bad leg slips out from under him on a particularly strong quake, but they otherwise make it to the elevator unimpeded. He shuffles in behind her, and Kaede holds her hand on the elevator door, biting her lip as Tenko keeps trying and Tsumugi continues to remain unresponsive.

It’s only when the lights of the room begin to flicker and strange things—ropes, nooses, vines, and other things bouncing too wildly for Kaede to properly make out—fall from unseen trapdoors in the ceiling that Tenko wraps her arms around Tsumugi’s waist, physically dragging her out of the collapsing room. The actions causes Tsumugi to spring to life, and she flails wildly in Tenko’s grip, wordlessly screaming at her as she kicks her legs and throws her elbows back against Tenko’s torso.

Kaede feels a lump of anxiety well up in her throat and is half tempted to tell Tenko to leave her behind when Tenko finally pulls the two of them over the elevator’s threshold. “Press the button!” Tenko shouts as soon as they’re through, and Ryoma wastes no time slamming his fist against the elevator’s control panel. Everyone stumbles in their efforts to stay standing as it jolts to life.

As much as Kaede feared for her life at different points in the game, she thinks little compares to the loud groaning of the elevator as it jerks up at alternating speeds. The worry that they all stepped into a death trap only takes a backseat to Tsumugi using the opportunity to wrench herself free from Tenko’s hold. She spins on her heel, one hand clinging to the grate on the door behind her for support, the other trembling as she points it at the others. Before she can get a word out, Tenko stands in front of her, putting her hands up in surrender. Her voice barely rises above the worryingly loud grinding and whirring sounds around them as she says, “Tsumugi, please listen. It’s going to be very dangerous, so we all have to—”

“No! This is all your fault!” she shouts. “I have nothing to do with any of this—just leave me alone, and—”

Tsumugi is cut off as the elevator rocks underneath them, before coming to a stop that almost knocks Kaede off her feet. Ryoma does fall, letting out a hiss as he lands on his bad knee. Tenko abandons confronting Tsumugi to hurry to his side as the door opens with a screech of uneven metal grinding together.

The image before them cracking into view through the elevator doors is somehow even more chaotic than the one they had left behind. There are armies of Monokumas that remind Kaede of the ones at Kokichi’s execution, though they are dressed in a bizarre variety of costumes from tuxedos to witches to ninjas. Giant mechanic bug creatures and fireballs launch into the wall, while steel tennis balls fly a little two low and far too close to them for comfort. The four of them are barely out of the elevator before the building makes a sickening cracking noise, and Kaede doesn’t have to hear Tenko shout in warning for her to start running.

Out in the open, things only grow more surreal. A giant piano rises out of the ground and crashes into the wall of the cage when a rocket ship slams into the side of it, while a series of mobile compactor machines go haywire, running into any and everything. There’s relative safety from being crushed in the open area outside of the shrine of judgment, giving Kaede a moment to catch her breath and witness the sheer mayhem surrounding her. She barely notices a rush of movement in the corner of her eye, until Tsumugi is front and center of her, darting towards the heart of Kiibo’s storm.

Behind her, Tenko is a few paces back, busy supporting Ryoma. She still manages to shout, “Tsumugi! Stop!”

Kaede hesitates for a moment, looking back between Tenko helping Ryoma to safety against a rather sturdy looking collapsed wall. Her leg aches under her, and Tenko screams out her name as she darts after Tsumugi.

The ceiling begins to crack against the assault, and the threat of raining debris looms over every part of the school. From her path, Kaede guesses that Tsumugi is still set on heading for the epicenter where the biggest risk of the school building itself is. The strange Monokumas seem to be on autopilot and ignore her, though they’re still difficult to wade through. None of the variety of other hazards—now saw blades, crossbows, and handguns among them—are particularly set on hurting her, either, but Kaede finds it necessary to weave and dodge the occasional stray bullet and stay vigilant of shrapnel.

Tsumugi is in her sight, and it’s only when they near the central courtyard in front of the school that Kaede sees her target. Monokuma somehow escaped from the trial room, and is standing nonchalantly in front of the school, happily waving goodbye to whatever cameras somehow remain. It takes only a second of thought for Kaede to realize that Tsumugi must intend to die along with him.

The ceiling is coming down not just in fragments, but in great, heavy chunks. They crash to the right and left of Monokuma, but he pays them little mind. Kaede keeps an eye on the remaining pieces barely hanging on, each making echoing cracking noises as they break off. She accordingly swerves out of her path following Tsumugi when one piece looks to be crashing down between them. It lands with a smashing sound, and Kaede has to throw her arms up in front of her face to protect from the dust and dirt that rise up from the ground at its impact.

She coughs and strains her eyes to see through the small cloud forming between her and where Tsumugi had run to. Blurred by the dust, Tsumugi stands proudly at Monokuma’s side. Another loud crack splits the sky above them. Kaede snaps her head up to see a piece that looks less like the clouds she had known and more like just a giant rock spilling down in its long descent.

Tsumugi spies it, too. She doesn’t move, but she doesn’t seem happy with her fate either. Even though her hair is frazzled and her shoulders are heaving from her run, Tsumugi remains blank faced. The closest emotion flickering over her features is one of vague disappointment.

Kaede doesn’t even think. She kicks off the ground, her lungs on fire as she forces her legs to move even faster and reaches out with both hands. Tsumugi finally looks back at her, her mouth moving to say Kaede’s name even as the words are drowned out into nothing.

Kaede leaps forward, colliding with Tsumugi’s body. They hit the ground. Kaede’s world stops.

Chapter End Notes

Though I'm aware it's for the purposes of visually streamlining the game and doesn't really effect anything, it always bothered me in canon that Kiibo started blowing up the cage while they were as far away from the school building as possible and underground but then were suddenly teleported to right in front of the school, haha. But in less pedantic thoughts, it was nice to finally write out a few scenes I had been visualizing for so long. 

Also a shorter chapter than usual (6k rather than the usual 9k) and I think the epilogue the next chapter will be even shorter, though I predict it may have a lengthy author's note, haha. I also hope to get the epilogue out by the end of the year!

III

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes 

The world had shuddered for an uncomfortably long amount of time. A few sturdy walls among the dozens crumbling had fallen in such a way as to offer shelter on the far side of the school. Ryoma had recovered relatively quickly from his fall onto his bad leg—or at least had put on a brave face—but the brief window of possible safety to run through the school had long passed. 

The only thing keeping Tenko from running after Kaede into certain death was the fact that she had no idea where in the school to go. She had watched her for as long as she could, but when Kaede disappeared up the stairs to the main courtyard, Tenko knew there was nothing more she could do other than have faith in her. She still kept her eyes trained on the path up towards where Kaede had gone, just on the off chance that she would manage to return unscathed through the blizzard of mechanic bugs, knives, and heavy duty machinery. Tenko tried to keep the thought of how the chaos that Kaede was lost somewhere in was composed of props for Monakuma’s unused executions at bay. 

It was too loud to talk, and there was nothing for either Tenko or Ryoma to do than sit sequestered in their hiding spot, hands over their ears to keep out some of the din. The sounds of the dome crashing down peaked and deescalated with due time, the sounds of the world splintering in two slowly fading into a few scattered cracks as the last few stubborn pieces tries to hold on. 

After the barrage that had just assaulted her ears, Ryoma’s voice sounds almost foreign. “Looks like… we’re all clear.”

With a cautious glance, Tenko pulls herself to her feet and takes a hesitant step out of their shelter. Her sandal crunches the broken glass strewn over the ground, but other than that, the world remains silent. She pauses, half looking at the aftermath of Kiibo’s assault and half taking in the sky—the real sky. Tenko hears Ryoma attempting to stand with some effort behind her, but any thoughts of helping him are cut off when she hears something she hadn’t known she had missed. 

Ryoma comes to stand beside her opening his mouth to offer further comment when Tenko very softly says, “There are birds calling.”

He pauses. The quiet sounds of life that had been exiled by the killing game seem to meet him all at once. Ryoma had never had a particular affinity for nature, but he can’t help but say, “Wow…”

“Yeah,” Tenko says back.

It’s almost memorizing enough to get lost in. Tenko says, “We need to find Kaede.”

“Right,” Ryoma says. 

Tenko takes a few impatient steps, Ryoma trailing behind. Navigating the debris coating the school grounds brings his progress to a crawl. The task takes most of his focus, but Ryoma spares a glance up to see Tenko waiting for him a few feet ahead, standing stiffly and biting her lip. “You can go on ahead.”

“No,” Tenko says. “It’s fine. We’ll go together.”

“Tenko,” he says. “You don’t have to worry about me. The killing game is over—we’re free.”

His comment makes Tenko deflate and relax her posture. “Yeah… we are.”

“Nothing is going to happen to me,” Ryoma says. “So go. You always talk about being honest with your emotions, and, well,” he shrugs. “Don’t have your talent, but even I can tell what your heart wants.”

“Ah…” Tenko flushes faintly. She barely resists stammering, instead bowing her head to Ryoma. “Thank you, Ryoma. Tenko promises she will be right back, and she will bring Kaede with her.”

“Counting on you,” he says as parting words. Tenko turns her back to him and weaves her way through the rubble at a pace Ryoma could not hope to match. 

Though alone, Ryoma finds it impossible to feel as isolated as he did at the game’s beginning. He pauses for a moment, standing in the ruins of his former prison, and plucks a cigarette from his pocket. Ryoma thinks he feels slightly hotter than he had during the game’s run, absently noting he’s not entirely sure what season it is outside. Without Tenko to talk to, the sounds of nature rush back in. A different bird twitters, and insects chirp their own songs. 

Ryoma bites down on his candy cigarette as he picks his own way through the maze after Tenko. Her calls for Kaede echo distantly, and Ryoma takes a moment to tap the severed head of a Monokuma half buried in dirt with his crutch. 

-

Everything is dark—everything except for a slight crack up and to her right. Kaede lies flat on her back in the door, and she squints her eyes against the invading light, half confused about what it actually is. She reaches up towards it with both hands, making contact with something solid and metal that refuses to budge at her exploratory touch. Kaede takes a deep breath, gathers whatever energy she can and shoves. It shifts with great resistance, and the light above her head grows. 

It’s not enough to free her, but Kaede takes a break, breathing heavily from the exertion. There’s a whining sound next to her, but her companion is too busy lying on her stomach, crying into the dirt to assist in their escape. As Kaede readies herself for another push, she registers that it’s not a rock over them, but a thin, sturdy metal plate. She’s confused for only a moment before she remembers the machines meant for a construction site that had been running wild and just who was controlling them. Kaede lets out a soft laugh. No one’s listening to her as she says, “Kiibo, I’ll thank you for saving me if I can get out of here.”

Another push frees her enough to sit up on her elbows, providing a slightly better vantage point. “Tsumugi,” Kaede says. “I get you’re having a crisis right now, but it’d be really great if you could help just a litt—”

“Kaede! Kaede!”

Kaede perks up, whipping her head towards the source of the noise. She struggles to sit up further to make herself more visible as she calls back, “I’m here!”

Tenko doesn’t call her name again, and instead Kaede listens to the sounds of her footsteps pounding closer and closer across the charred ground. It’s only a few moments before Tenko is in full view, surveying the various piles of debris for signs of life. With a bit more shifting Kaede manages to raise one of her arms above her head, and she waves it as she calls, “Here!”

Tenko spins towards her and is at her side in seconds, helping to shove the metal plate the rest of the way off of her. Tsumugi doesn’t seem to react to her presence or the light slowly pouring over her. Tenko’s eyes widen at the sight of her. “Kaede, you…”

“Yeah,” Kaede says. “I did.” Tenko only nods in response, still speechless. Kaede clears her throat, “I can tell you the details once I get a little more breathing room.”

“Right,” Tenko says, snapping her attention back to freeing Kaede. “This wasn’t,” she says between her grunts of exertion, “a very safe hiding spot.”

“No,” Kaede says. “I wasn’t really thinking about that. My guess is Kiibo came through one last time.”

Tenko stops pushing for a second to glance somewhere behind Kaede. “He…” she sighs. “Tenko wishes we could thank him.”

Kaede follows her gaze and spies a broken monitor in a pile with a few rocks and other destroyed furniture from the school building. “Me, too.”

With Tenko’s help, it doesn’t take long to move the plate far enough off of Kaede to provide her room to pull herself out with little trouble. Kaede raises a hand to Tenko for support, which she bypasses, instead helping by lifting her by the waist. Kaede wobbles a bit as she attempts to stand, though Tenko supports her without needing to be asked. Once steadied, Kaede says, “Alright—I think I’m good. Maybe a bit dizzy.”

Tenko scrunches her brow in concern. “You didn’t hit your head or anything, did you?”

“No, well, maybe a little when I hit the ground, but that’s not a big deal,” Kaede says. “I think it’s just the adrenaline rush. Or maybe the opposite—that thing where your body just collapses after you ran a marathon.”

“That does sound about right,” Tenko agrees. “And… we’re almost done.”

Kaede lets out a breath as she fully takes in her surroundings for the first time. “Almost done running,” she says to herself.

Making sure Kaede isn’t about to fall over one last time, Tenko releases her and moves to kneel beside Tsumugi. “Tsumugi, please take Tenko’s hand.”

Tsumugi pays her about as much attention as she had to Kaede previously. At the very least, Kaede muses, she’s sitting up now, though her face is buried in her hands, and she appears to have no intention of moving. “I don’t think you’re going to have much luck, Tenko,” she says. “She can get out on her own when she wants to, so I think we can just leave her for now.”

Tenko doesn’t respond to Kaede, instead shifting the plate back even further off of Tsumugi. “Was it hard saving her?” she asks after a moment. 

“Yeah,” Kaede says. “I don’t think I’ve ever tackled anyone before, though, so that was an interesting experience. But then again, I’ve also never had five near misses at getting my head caved-in in a row.”

Tenko smiles softly up at her. “That’s not quiet what Tenko meant.”

Kaede smiles back. “I know. And the answer is yes.”

“Then why?” Tsumugi’s voice croaks, startlingly both girls. “Why did you…”

Tsumugi’s hands trembling hands have fallen into her lap. Her face is red and smeared with dirt, and Kaede absently realizes she probably doesn’t look much better. “I already told you,” Kaede says, though her voice has no bite in it. “I finally have a chance to be free—I’m not going to waste it on hating you.”

“But you could have died,” she says softly. “You hate me and you still…”

“Out of everything I think I’ve learned about myself,” Kaede says. “The number one thing is that I’m willing to risk my life for things that I know are too important to live without.”

“I’m important?” Tsumugi asks.

“No,” Kaede says. “But moving beyond this place is.”

Tenko tries offering Tsumugi her hand again. “The game is over, Tsumugi. It’s time to leave.”

Tsumugi stares down at her hands. “The… the story’s over then. That’s it, no more… no more anything for anyone.”

“But that’s a lie, isn’t it?” Kaede says. “You can stay here and keep lying to yourself, if you want, but you have to leave fiction behind at some point.”

“You,” Tsumugi’s hands curl and uncurl into fists as she repeats her words from the trial. “You just don’t get it. I’m not real—I’m not.”

In this state, she reminds Kaede more of a discarded doll than a person. She says, “Then I think you’re on your own.”

Tsumugi doesn’t say anything more, but her body seems to shudder just for a second as if she were holding back a sob.

Kaede turns to Tenko. “Where’s Ryoma?”

Tenko glances over her shoulder. “He told Tenko to go on ahead, but he might have a bit of trouble getting around, given…” a cursory look around speaks volumes for her, “everything.”

“Let’s go meet him then,” Kaede says. “And then, let’s see what the world’s actually like.”

Tenko stands and reaches a hand out to Kaede to help her navigate the small pile of rubble they had been standing in. Tsumugi stares at her hands and at their backs and up into the real sun until it hurts too much.

They find Ryoma about halfway from the spot where Tenko had left him. His eyes widen, then his face falls into a smile at seeing Kaede. “Nice to see you again, Kaede. You sure know how to stir things up, huh?”

“I should probably break that habit,” Kaede says. “One of the many things I’ll have to start working on.”

“Don’t say that,” Tenko says. “Kaede is a wonderful person. But… it would be nice if she was a little less reckless.”

“Think Tenko’s heart can only take so much,” Ryoma says. “By the way, Tsumugi…?”

“Is alive,” Kaede answers. 

Ryoma glances between Tenko and Kaede, though neither seem inclined to elaborate. “Alright then.” He turns to stare back out through the collapsed walls. “What do you think is out there?”

“Tenko doesn’t think Tsumugi was lying from the way she was acting,” Tenko says. “Some of it was pretty hard to believe, in hindsight, though, so maybe she did lie about a few things. But also a world that can produce someone like Tsumugi must be…”

“Slightly terrifying, yeah,” Ryoma says. “But then again, after the killing game, don’t think there’s much that can rattle me.”

“You know, I think I thought something like that over and over again during the game,” Kaede says. “And I was wrong every time.”

“Also true,” Ryoma concedes. 

“Tenko thinks that’s okay, though,” Tenko says. “No matter what happened to us, we still felt everything just as strongly. Tenko thinks she prefers that over becoming numbed to tragedy.”

Kaede takes her hand again. “And that means we’re going to experience whatever comes next proudly with all of our emotions. So now, we just kind of need to think what actually is next.”

“Hospital should be the first stop,” Ryoma says. “Tenko, you did great, but, well, you’re no Ultimate Doctor.”

“Tenko would be more offended by that if it weren’t true,” Tenko says. 

“After that,” Ryoma continues, “don’t know. Maybe I’ll pick up tennis for the hell of it, or see if I actually like cats and bugs and animals or something.”

“Tenko thinks she’d like to train or travel,” she says, “and meet as many people as possible and treat them with kindness.”

Ryoma smirks at her. “By ‘people’ do you mean ‘girls?’” 

“It would be preferable if they were girls, yes,” Tenko says. “But awful boys deserve kindness, too. Some awful boys.”

“Maybe you could teach them some manners,” he says.

“Tenko doesn’t think that’s possible,” she says, returning his teasing look. “She hasn’t met a single boy capable of learning so far.”

Ryoma lets out a low pitched laugh. “Fair enough. What about you, Kaede?”

“I don’t know. I have no plans,” Kaede says with a laugh. “Pets and travel sounds good. Maybe I’ll play piano until my hands fall off or try to protest anything else related to killing games. I think I’m going to do whatever I need to stay on the path of becoming someone I like. And then just hope—no,” she shakes her head, “do everything I can to make sure that that’s enough.”

Kaede feels Tenko squeeze her hand. “Tenko thinks that is very admirable, Kaede.”

“Also sounds like the hard work’s just beginning, then,” Ryoma says. 

“Oh, I know,” Kaede says. “I think I can handle it, though. I think we all can. We should make it a promise, too.”

“Tenko agrees,” Tenko says. “Tenko doesn’t want to forget what happened here, but she also wants to move forward.”

“Think I can agree to that, too,” Ryoma says. “Face reality, try to change for the better… all sounds good.”

Kaede takes a deep breath. “Then we better get started.”

The easiest path out to navigate is the areas around where a giant piano had smashed straight through the outer wall. Kaede glances up at the massive instrument broken on its side. She has few doubts she came very close to seeing it up close and personal for its original purpose, but the thought doesn’t even make her shudder. Tenko says, “Kaede, watch your step here,” and Kaede turns away.

From the ruins of the killing game, the three survivors slowly but surely stumble out of the rubble. The first step outside where the cage had been feels both significant and somehow no different at all. 

Then, “Wait! Wait!”

Kaede turns her head. Tsumugi trips and falters in her path, but she keeps calling out to them. Tenko says, “Tsumugi? Why are you—”

Tsumugi comes to a stuttering stop as if she physically cannot leave the school. “You,” she says. “You can’t just leave me here. I—we—we all have no where to go. So you can’t—”

“Thought you wanted to stay in the school,” Ryoma says. 

Her hands fist in her skirt. “I can’t. There’s nothing left, and it’s all your fault so you have to take responsibility.”

Kaede furrows her brow. “You can’t be serious.”

“Oh, yes, I can,” Tsumugi say. “This school was our entire world, and now it’s gone, so someone has to do something about it. And since you didn’t let me die, you have to take responsibility for your actions.”

For a moment, Kaede wants only to point out how childish her argument sounds. But Tenko whispers to Kaede first. “She still can’t accept it.”

“I think you’re right,” Kaede whispers back. Then, to Tsumugi, “Now that your life isn’t someone’s ‘writing credit’ or whatever, you have no idea what to do. Is that right?”

Tsumugi nods. “There’s nothing for me out there, so—so you need to do something.”

“Tsumugi,” Kaede says. “I don’t like you or forgive you for what you’ve done to us. So all I can say to you is this: take responsibility for your own life.”

“No, no,” Tsumugi shakes her head. “That’s not—”

Kaede turns away from her. She looks at both Ryoma and Tenko for confirmation, and the three walk away from the wreckage. 

Tsumugi stares wide eyed and open mouthed at their departure. She can feel her knees shaking, and she knows her legs are about to give out from under her if she stays still for another moment. Her first step is more an awkward lurch, and the uneven ground gives her trouble in her rush out of the killing game. 

-


Rantaro Theater 

I held my hand out into the darkness and pulled people in, one right after another after another after another. They were scared or in pain or at peace. But the pain and the confusion faded away. The sadness still hasn’t faded for some, but I know it will. I’ll hold my hand out to them until it does. 

I’d offer my hand to the person who led me to the darkness. They wouldn’t take it, but I would hold it out to them. There is more death to be had, but not now. They cannot reach the ending they want. They cannot come to the dark with me. 

We are at the end. They are happy and they are sad and they have their lives. I am not real, but I am me. Their end isn’t their end, but it is the path they have found. I could not walk it with them. So many of my friends could not walk it with them. I will hold their hands until they find peace with that. 

I wish I had been smarter or luckier or heard the steps coming up fast behind me. I wish there had been no arrow, pot, wax, chain, or fire. No knife, sword, cable, statue, or bullet. I wish for a lot of things. I wish for peace. 

One day they will reach the dark. For now, they are happy and sad and alive. I am not with them, but I have not been left behind. The one who led me here is still lost. But they have an end. I wish for them to find peace. 

Chapter End Notes

Over the course of this fic, quite a few people have commented that they thought there was some secret hidden in the summary, and, well, there kind of was, haha. I’ll admit some parts of the description are a bit of an artifact from when I first started this story and didn’t have a solid grasp on what its direction was. However, I also feel like I’ve had things like the title and summary be what they are for far too long to change them, which is probably just as well since I have no idea what I would potentially change them to. Overall, though, I am happy with what this project became. 

One of the questions I do want to answer here is why I wrote this fic. My first answer is that V3 posed an interesting question in its first chapter and gave enough of a potential path for it to come to fruition in chapter six. There was even an incredibly handy divergent point in the first chapter trial wherein Shuichi decides he can’t go through with outing Kaede, but then does a 180 in thoughts and pulls himself together because the plot kind of needs him to. The second answer is that I love V3. It’s definitely a flawed game, but it inspired me to start writing and to write a lot. I suppose some people write love letters, and I wrote a love novel, haha. 

I also learned a lot about writing while doing this to the point where I have a bit of trouble going back and reading the first few chapters. It got to the point where when a very nice person did a recording of chapter one, it took me forever to listen to because I kept getting embarrassed (the recording is posted on chapter one and chapter thirty-six I if you want to check it out!). There are certain points in the fic that I feel drag and others where I wish I had been better about planting earlier foreshadowing, and many other smaller points I know I would fix if I were to do this again (though in spite of me occasionally entertaining the idea of a talent swap au, I’d like to think I have enough self-control not to launch another project like this so soon, haha). However, as a final project, there is a lot I am very happy with, not to mention that I am just grateful for the sheer process teaching so much about writing. 

As for the future, I intend to post some more oneshots and maybe impromptu start another multi-chaptered fic or two, though I’m less sure if I’ll hold myself as strictly to finishing those, which I hope is reasonable given what I have finished, haha. And, of course, I also hope to continue reading and commenting on all the wonderful fics other authors in this fandom have written!

And, of course, I have to mention the amazing reception this fic has gotten. The attention I have gotten has almost been overwhelming sometimes, but it is absolutely that support that has kept me going to this point. Though I am not expecting 400 comments on this chapter (though that would be amazing, if not a bit terrifying, haha), I would love to hear from everyone who has been following along, whether on this chapter or the fic as a whole, especially since as this is the last chapter, I want to respond and interact with as many comments as I can. I also got a curiouscat thing on twitter, in case anyone happens to have shorter, more direct questions or want to ask non-fic related things. This fic might be a love letter to V3, but it only exists because of the support from the fandom. I can’t thank you all enough!

Please drop by the archive and comment to let the author know if you enjoyed their work!
